Text of the Book

In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
The King, the Truth, the Manifest.
Praise be to God, and may God bless Muhammad, the Chosen Prophet, and his pure family, and grant them peace.

Abu Ali Muhammad bin Al-Hussein Al-Hatimi, the philologist scribe, said:
Even if the meanings of literature are like devoid ruins, with altered states, effaced courtyards, and erased landmarks and signs of dwellings, spoken of only by the tongues of calamities, they are today, through the Chief Abu al-Faraj Muhammad bin al-Abbas, adorned with horses, true in exploration, their quarters marked by the spring rains. They flourish with freshness and bliss, and their scent is complete with fragrance and breeze. May the knots of virtue remain organized by him, its neglected parts marked by his glory, and its obscure parts made known by his merits, as long as the tubes of spears scatter, a flower smiles at the selection of rain, and a tear remains confused in an eye.

I find the Chief strongly attached to my discussing with him the dispute that occurred between me and Abu al-Tayyib Ahmad bin al-Hussein al-Mutanabbi, in the gathering where I recounted his traces, and news of which traveled to the edges of the lands. He is fond of repeating chapters of it related to my memory of it, disputing its scattered collection, pointing to the day that dispute broke out—a specific indication of the month, year, and time—and to what that dispute yielded for me in terms of fame, spreading reputation, and precedence in overtaking him, while I was in a state of inexperience and tender youth, reaching a goal in whose track only the seasoned men of virtue run. This is in addition to the elegance of the place, the brilliance of the Sultan, and the support of helpers and aides. And the spreading of my merit which was folded in those days, and my virtues which were obscured by the attacks of the envious and the age of youth.

He wanted me—may God prolong his power—to compose a treatise that encompasses its scattered parts and organizes the dispersed chapters and verses. I find myself not as enthusiastic for that as I used to be, nor do I rush to speak about it with the eagerness I once had. This is for reasons, the most specific of which is my rising above mentioning him now, with the blossoming of my branch, its fruiting, the smiling of its flowers, and the spreading of its lights. And to protect myself from the biting words of boys who have no minds, who descend into his faction and join his line. Then, because I extended the rein of speech with the man to a length that perhaps he who narrates it or reports it might be accused [of exaggeration], even though the situation is more famous in news and more lasting in trace than for its morning to be abrogated or its lamp extinguished.

Notables of the people attended the gathering, whose importance is pointed to and whose news is trusted, including a judge whose word is final, a sheikh of literature whose testimony is accepted, and a youth from the sons of scribes whose water of modesty flows in the lines of his face. The Vizier Abu Muhammad al-Hasan bin Muhammad al-Muhallabi, may God have mercy on him, had there a vanguard of his vanguards, a scout of his scouts, and an eye of his eyes, sharp and kindled. For he—may God brighten his face—when Abu al-Tayyib became heavy in his service, and did poorly in descending to accept his favors, and was not successful in soliciting rain from his palm—which was dripping with fingers, pouring with silver and gold—he tasked me with tearing his sanctity and ripping his skin. He entrusted me with tracking his defects, examining his poems, and forcing him to leave Iraq and compelling him out of hatred for his stay, after he had gone to extremes in drawing him near and honoring him.

It suffices me that the Chief knows the truth of the situation, the truth of the speech, the excellence of the deed, and my rising in the prime of youth with what the determination of men fell short of. I came to him in the forenoon, when the sun cast its spears upon the earth, so I combined in his house the noon and afternoon prayers. I departed from him when the sun had shaken off its dye, and approached the darkness with its child (sunset). I had retrieved in the moment what I could retrieve of that dispute and rectified what fate aided me in gathering of it. The support of the present group in organizing and gathering it, observing what issued from me and him, and alerting to what was hidden from my memory, is what roused my mind, even if it was wandering, and struck the flint of my thought, even if it was flying sparks.

So I bound it in a treatise that branded the forehead of literature, and the mouths of narrators carried it in every direction. Since the Chief preferred that I name it after him and present it for his examination and criticism, I attach the wing of this introduction to it, refine what I see needs refining of its wording, and absolve myself to him from responsibility regarding the length of my breath in it, for my hand and tongue run in the arena of eloquence like the running of racehorses on the morning of the bet. I hope that success aids it through his beautiful opinion, and that it falls in the position I intended for it by complying with his decree. I will follow this with disputes I had with Abu al-Tayyib regarding his poetry in several gatherings other than this one, and with places I reviewed of his borrowings, thefts, and lapses he dropped in his poetry, in which no review or dispute occurred, so that it may be more enjoyable for its reader and more comprehensive of what I intended in it. I weave some into others without distinguishing last from first, or past from future, and I pair the speech with what increases the truth in clarity, from a witness...

related to it, or a verse that suits a verse, or a verse whose beginning was mentioned so I completed its end, or its end so I attached its beginning, or a meaning to which I joined its likeness. Indeed, speech is "possessor of pregnancy" (fruitful/generative), and the proverb goes: "Speech has branches/shun". Their saying "Dhu Laqah" (possessor of pregnancy/milk) comes from the pregnant she-camel, and 'Laqah' is the pregnancy. The meaning is speech that joins to speech just as the fetus joins the mother when it is in her womb. It is also said: "Hayy al-Laqah" (A tribe of Laqah) if they are mighty, not joining anyone, not submitting to a king, and cannot be overcome, like the she-camel when pregnant, the stallion cannot approach her.

As for their saying "Dhu Shujun" (possessor of branches), it is from the branches of the valley, its paths, and its bends. A person may be in a conversation, then exit from it to another, then return to his first conversation; likened to one walking in a valley where a path appears to him, so he takes it, and that leads him to the main road. Let not the Chief find the paths of speech too long, even if I lengthen them, for I have given the pen the reins of thought, and I have been fair with all fairness in refining what I recounted about the man. I deleted superfluous words and clothed his arguments in expressions which, perhaps if he had relied upon them, his material would have fallen short in expressing them.

I name this treatise "Al-Muwadidhah" (The Clarifying/Exposing One), likening it to the *Muwadidhah* head wound, which is the one that exposes the whiteness of the bone, as Tarfa said:
'And a clarifying wound exposing the bone repels from you the arrogance of the broad man / With the edge of your sword or your tongue... the original words like the desire of words.'
This is taken from the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'And the wound of the tongue is like the wound of the hand.'
Hassan said:
'My tongue and my sword are both sharp / And my tongue reaches what my sword does not reach.'
Jarir said:
'My tongue and my sword are both sharp / But the sword has a less severe impact than my tongue.'
From God Almighty, I seek aid and success.

When Ahmad bin al-Hasan al-Mutanabbi—whom the youths of the Levant and the coasts nickname "Al-Mutami'" (The Greed-Inducer) because of his saying: 'He makes the birds greedy for them due to the length of eating them / Until they almost land on their living ones'—arrived...

in the City of Peace (Baghdad), returning from Egypt and exposing himself to the Vizier Abu Muhammad al-Muhallabi to camp with him and stay by his side: He wrapped himself in the cloak of pride, dragged the tails of arrogance, turned his cheek (in disdain) to the Iraqis, sharpened his edge for dispute, distanced his side in haughtiness, and bent his side in tyranny and turning away. He would not meet anyone without turning away from him in arrogance, and embellishing speech to him in a deception that made him imagine—out of vanity—that literature was restricted to him, and that poetry was a sea whose fresh water no one else reached, and a garden whose flowers no one else saw. So he harvests its fruits and picks its clusters without anyone contending with him; and every runner in an empty space rejoices, and for every news, there is a settling place.

He remained running on this path for a little while, in which I let him drag the halter of transgression, prancing in its folds, until he imagined he was the forerunner who could not be raced in a track, nor could his cheek-strap be equaled by another cheek-strap (in a race). And that he was the lord of speech, the deflowerer of virgin words, the owner of the bondage of eloquence in prose and verse, and the unique one of his age who could not be rivaled in merit and knowledge. His tread became heavy on many who branded themselves with the brand of literature and drew from its water source. So they lowered some of their heads, lowered some of their wings, and settled their gazes on submitting to him.

It displeased Mu'izz al-Dawla—when his situation was depicted—that a man should arrive at his court, which is the abode of the Caliphate, the seat of might, and the egg of the kingdom, coming from the court of Sayf al-Dawla who was a distinct enemy, and find no one in his kingdom to equal him in his craft. And he (Mu'izz al-Dawla) is the possessor of the proud soul, the Kisra-like determination, and the ambition that if it intended the world (Time), the vicissitudes of Time would not act upon the free, nor would its circles turn against them.

Abu Muhammad al-Muhallabi imagined, guessing at the unseen, that no one could compete with him, nor see himself as his equal, nor be capable of distressing him, let alone latching onto any of his meanings. Chiefs have ways of aggrandizing those they aggrandize, honoring those they honor, and respecting those they observe and dignify. Perhaps the state changes with them, and they are about to move from this characteristic; and that was the image of the Vizier Abu Muhammad in his returning from this opinion of him. There was no merit by which Abu al-Tayyib (Al-Mutanabbi) was distinguished from the hybrid novice among the sons of literature—let alone the purebred veteran—except poetry. For by my life, his branches in it were fresh and his fruits sweet.

I rose to face him, tracking his flaws, clipping his nails (curbing his power), broadcasting his secrets, spreading his folds, criticizing his verses regarding what they allowed, and intending that a house pointed to as possessing mastery should gather us. So I and he would run in a track where the forerunner is known from the overtaken, and the catcher from the one falling short of catching up. I was at that time possessing of a pouring cloud, a kindled flint in every virtue, and a nature resembling the clarity of wine when embroidered by bubbles and embroidered by cups. This, while the pool of youth was clear, its garment ample, the brocade of life fresh, its winds moist, its clouds pouring, youth having sharpness, and the approach of Time having a brightness. Horses on the day of the bet are by the luck of their owners, not by their veins and lineage. Every man has a share of the favorability of his time, in whose shade a need is fulfilled, a demand is reached, and a desire and doctrine are expanded.

Until, when obstacles of days prevented our meeting, I headed to his residence. Beneath me was a swift mule looking with the eyes of a marked hawk, and peering with the likes of eagle's primaries. She protects you from her front with the half of her rear (due to speed/agility). Topped by a magnificent saddle like a glowing star, beneath it a cloud led by the rein of the south wind. Before me were several handsome servants, Mamluks and freeborn, falling like unique pearls from their strings. I did not mention this to boast or multiply it, but I mentioned it because Abu al-Tayyib witnessed all of it in the moment, yet its magnificence did not awe him, nor did its glitter attract him, nor did what he witnessed of that beautiful group which filled his gaze and heart increase him in anything but vanity in himself, dragging the cloak of his arrogance, and turning his face away from me.

He was staying there with some youngsters whom scholars would not accept, nor had the mill of examination ground them, nor had they worn out thoughts in studying literature, nor distinguished between sweet speech and bitter, easy and rugged. The utmost limit of one of them was studying the poetry of Abu Tammam and dealing with speech on scraps of his meanings, and on what narrators attach of what is permissible in it. Who is there for the Chief to undertake this, even if occupying oneself with others—observing the poetry of the stallions who spoke naturally by their instincts, ran on their habits, did not affect it artificially nor force it arbitrarily—and researching their purposes which they aimed for, is more worthy?

So I found there youths taking something (of knowledge). When my presence was announced, and permission was sought for me to enter, he rose from his seat quickly and hid his person from me, concealing himself. I hurried him while dismounting the mule, and he saw me as I reached where his gaze took him. I entered, and the group magnified my status and seated me in his seat. Suddenly, beneath him were worn-out mats of worship upon which accidents had insisted, so they were fading traces and scattered wires. There was such bad manners at the meeting that I fold the rein of speech regarding it. It was only the time it took for me to sit until he came out to me. I stood up and fulfilled the right of greeting without disputing with him regarding standing, because he only intended by his rising from the place not to stand up for me, while the purpose in meeting him was other than that. So I rubbed what happened against my side (ignored it) and folded my flank over it. When I met him, I exemplified with the poet's saying:
'And in walking to you is shame upon me / But passion prevented settling.'
So he exemplified with the saying of another:
'People are miserable and others are miserable because of them / And God makes peoples happy through peoples.
The livelihood of a youth is not from the virtue of his trick / But lucks, livelihoods, and shares.
Like the game, the skilled shooter is denied it, and / One who is not a shooter shoots and attains it.'
Suddenly he was wearing seven tunics (aqbiya), each tunic a different color. We were in the heat of midsummer and the ember of summer, on a day when the deposits of skulls almost melted. Worthy of the saying of Mudris bin Rab'i:
'And a day wherein the sun seemed resident / On the desert, knowing no doctrine but the desert.'
And the saying of another:
'And a day wherein salt seemed scattered in its middle / You see its wild animals riding the forelocks in it.'

I sat poised (ready to jump/leave), and he sat prepared (digging in). He turned away from me playfully, and I turned away from him absentmindedly. I reprimanded myself for visiting him and ridiculed my opinion for undertaking the burden of meeting him. He remained for a little while turning his shoulder, not lending me his gaze, turning towards that rabble in front of him. Everyone was gesturing to him, signaling with their eyes, pointing to my place with their hands, waking him from the slumber of his ignorance, but he refused except turning away, aversion, arrogance, and haughtiness. Then he saw fit to turn his side to me and accept me with some acceptance.

I swore by loyalty—for it is among the beauties of oaths—that he did not add more than saying: "What is your news?" I said: "In news am I, were it not for what I brought upon myself by visiting you, and the brand of humiliation I marked my status with by visiting you, and the burden my opinion bore of striving to the likes of you, among those whom experience has not refined nor insight disciplined." Then I descended upon him like a torrent to the bottom of a valley and said: "Explain to me, from where comes your haughtiness, your vanity, and your arrogance? What necessitates what you are upon of being full of yourself, and throwing your importance to where your reach falls short and your arm does not extend? Is there here a lineage you attribute to glory by, or an honor you cling to its tails, or a sultan you dominate by his might, or knowledge by which you are pointed out? If you estimated yourself by your worth, or weighed yourself with your balance, and vanity did not take you away, you would not exceed being a poet earning a living."

His color changed, his spit dried up, and he began to soften in apology, desiring pardon and forgiveness, repeating oaths that he did not recognize me nor intended to slight me. I said: "O you, if your visitor is noble in his lineage, you ignored his lineage; or great in his literature, you belittled his literature; or advanced with his sultan, you lowered his rank. Is glory an inheritance for you excluding others? No, by God, but you extended pride as a curtain over your deficiency, and struck it as a tent blocking your discussion." He repeated the apology, so I said: "I have no excuse for you with persistence."

The group began urging me to be easy with him and accept his excuse, and to use the patience that prudent men use when angry. I remained on one path of reprimanding him, rebuking him, and criticizing his character, while he emphasized the oath that he did not know me with a knowledge that would seize the opportunity to fulfill my right. I said: "Was permission not sought from you by my name and lineage? Was there no one in this group who knew me if you were ignorant of me? And suppose that is so, did you not see my appearance? Did you not smell the scent of my perfume? Did I not distinguish myself in your soul from others?"

While I filled his hearing with blame and refutation, he was saying: "Ease up on yourself, restrain your sharpness, hold back your assault, be patient, for patience is among the traits of the likes of you." Then I softened my side to him, my nature became gentle in his hand, and I was ashamed to exceed the limit I had reached in punishing him. That was after I broke him in as one breaks in a young camel or a colt weaned from its mother. He turned to me glorifying, and expanded in praising me, magnifying. He swore that he had been yearning to meet me since arriving in Iraq, promising himself a meeting with me, and longing to attach to the causes of my friendship.

When he exhausted this meaning, permission was sought for a young man from the Kufan Talibids (descendants of Abu Talib), so he permitted him. Suddenly, a youth with slender flanks, swayed by the intoxication of youth, his water smiling in the lines of his face. He spoke and expressed himself; behold, a melodious utterance, a sweet tongue, humorous morals, and a ready answer, with the patience of the mature and the dignity of the sheikhs. I admired what I witnessed of his traits, and what I discerned of his virtue possessed me.

He recited verses to him (Al-Mutanabbi), among which was the saying of Adi bin Zaid:
'Like statues of ivory in the niches, or / Like eggs in the garden, a flower shining.'
Abu al-Tayyib said: "He likened women to ivory images. Niches are the fronts of councils. He mentioned eggs in the garden for their beauty and smoothness."
The Talibi turned to me and said: "What do you say? The meaning is what he mentioned." He said: "Then what is his saying 'a flower shining'?" He (Al-Mutanabbi) said: "To be more beautiful for it." This did not satisfy him. So I said to him: "He likened the colors of the clothes upon them to the colors of the blossoms of gardens, and its flower is its redness and yellowness." He liked that. So he asked him about his saying in this poem:
'Then after success, kingship, and nation (immah) / The graves hid them there, then they became
As if they were dry leaves which the East Wind (Saba) and West Wind (Dabur) played with.'

Abu al-Tayyib said: "[The meaning is] survival, and 'Immah' is grace/blessing."
He (the Talibi) said: "How did he combine the East Wind and the West Wind, when one is soft and the other is severe?"
He said: "To correct the meter and rhyme."
The Talibi turned to me, so I said: "He only chose the East Wind with the West Wind, bringing the softest wind with the strongest wind, because people, some die by severity and some by ease. Some are snatched by death this way, and some that way; in any case, it comes and takes."
Abu al-Tayyib said: "We have not heard of this."
I said: "Nor of anything else." Then I said: "It is fair not to transgress from your poetry to another's, for in examining its beauties and harvesting its branches is distraction enough from others. There are things struggling in my chest regarding it, about which I would like to review speech with you."
He said: "And what are they?"
[I said]: "Tell me about your saying:
'Fear God and cover that beauty with a veil / For if you appear, the chaste young women menstruate in their cheeks.'
Is this how one flirts with lovers?"
He said: "Is it not thus in your Book?" He disbelieved, may God curse him.
I said: "Where?"
He said: "The Almighty said: 'When they saw him, they magnified him (akbarnahu)' meaning they menstruated out of desire for him and admiration of his image."
I said: "No one from the verifiers among the people of knowledge said this, nor did a trustworthy person testify to it. Only an odd verse, not attributed to anyone, was narrated:
'We come to women during their purity and do not / Come to women when they magnify (akbarna) a magnifying (menstruate).'
He said: "Then what is the meaning of 'akbarnahu'?"
I said: "They deemed him great. It cannot mean 'they menstruated', because the estimation of the speech necessitates that, if 'Ikbar' meant menstruation. I said: And the proof that its meaning is 'they deemed him great' is their saying: 'This is not a human; this is but a noble angel.'"

He said: "Then forgive this saying for my saying in this poem:
'And a dark night, as if we / A Mahyal (mirror/illusion) was polished for us in it, so the smooth deserts guided us.'
'It would not have ceased, were it not for the light of your face, its darkness / Nor would the camels have traversed it were it not for the she-camels.'
'They sang of Ibn Ishaq, Al-Hussein, so / Their camel-humps shook hands with their saddles and pads.'
'A youth like the dark cloud, feared and hoped for / Rain is hoped from him and thunderbolts are feared.'
'If the Indian swords are slack with heads and necks / Then they are their combs and they are the necklaces.'
'As if you, in giving, are a hater of wealth / And in every war, a lover of death.'
'Fates do not provide to him whom you deprive / Nor do they deprive security to him whom you provide.'
'Yours is the good, other than you is wealth / And other than me is joining other than Latakia.'
'It is the furthest goal and seeing you is the wish / Your home is the world and you are the creatures.'"

I said to him: "As for your saying 'And a dark night, as if we...', it is from the saying of Muhammad bin Munadhir:
'When we saw, the Mt. Al-Malamal became for us / A day by the mention of Harun.'
'If we travel by night and you are in front of us / The light of your face suffices as a guide for the mounts.'
'Does it not increase the white camels in lightness of arm / Even if they are weary, that you are in front of me?'

Marwan the Elder took this and said to Al-Mahdi:
'To the Chosen One, the Mahdi, our camels waded / The darkness of the night, trampling the leather strap...'
'The light of Imam Muhammad is for them / A guide by which they travel at night if the night darkens.'

Idris bin Abi Hafsa took this meaning and said:
'When she came to you, and she was struggling / Satisfaction approached between her hands with my leading ropes.'
'She has before you a light by which she seeks illumination / And from your hope, in her heels, is a driver.'

Ashja' said:
'If the dawn is absent, we wade by his face / The darkness of night until the dawn becomes clear to us.'

Al-Abbas bin Al-Ahnaf transferred the meaning and said:
'If there were no moon when I visit you / Guiding to the path of the clear road.'
'The illuminating longing for your memory would have kindled / Until the earth lit up between my ribs.'

Al-Qasafi said, and did well:
'I remembered you one day, so the light of your mention / Lit the darkness of night until its darknesses cleared from me.'
'By God, I do not know, is it a light poured out / Because of your memory, or does the heater heat the night?'

Some natural Syrian poets said, and upon him I relied (referring to Al-Mutanabbi's likely source):
'And a night whose two ends we connected by night travel / While an eager longing for your connection was serious.'
'Darknesses from its gloom persisted upon us / Returning the rugged road as the path of ways.'
'So I called out "O Asma" by your name, and it cleared / And every pitch-black darkness shone from it.'
'By you (we are ransomed), you are a guide by whose mention we were saved / When the palms of perils had clutched us.'
'I granted you my sincerity and purified my love for you / Even if you did not let me cross your mind.'

As for your saying 'The Indian swords became...', it is from the saying of Abu al-Hawl al-Himyari:

'A sword which the spirit fed until it seemed / A messenger from God for seizing souls.'
As for your saying:
'As if you, in giving, are a hater of wealth / And in every war, a lover of death.'
It is from the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'He hastened until he who witnessed the war said / Is it a meeting of enemies or a meeting of loved ones?'
As for your saying 'A youth like the dark cloud, feared and hoped for', it is from the saying of Bashar:
'People hope for and fear your two states / As if you are Paradise and Hellfire.'
And your saying: 'And your home is the world', is from the saying of Ali bin Jabala:
'Let me roam the earth seeking wealth / For Karkh is not the world, nor is the person Qasim.'
And your saying: 'And you are the creatures', is from the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'It is not denounced for God / To gather the world (universe) in one person.'
And Abu Nuwas took it from the saying of Jarir:
'If Banu Tamim are angry with you / You think all people are angry.'
So Abu Nuwas transferred it from the tribe to a man. So you have no meaning in this rhyme scheme except as a follower, nor excellence you pointed to except as one seeking east (imitation) and copying. And upon that, you are regarding what you stole as some moderns said:
'A youth who says poetry, except that he / In what we know, steals the stolen.'

He (Al-Mutanabbi) said in some of his formulation: "So where are you regarding his saying in the other poem:
'I remembered what is between Al-Udhayb and Bariq / The dragging place of our spear-shafts and the running place of the racing horses.'
'And the companionship of a people who slaughter their hunted game / With the remnants of what they broke in the partings (of hair/heads).' (Using broken swords/combs).
'And a night we pillowed Al-Thuwayya under it / As if its soil was ambergris in the elbows.'

I said: The last verse is taken from the saying of Abu Uyayna:
'In a planting like maidens and a soil / As if its earth is rose water on musk.'
Or from the saying of Abdul Samad bin Al-Mu'adhdhal:
'Its dew erases in it a curly dusty land / As if its earth is rose water and ambergris.'
Ibn Al-Mu'tazz took it from both of them and said:
'As if censers of ambergris diffused / Or a musk pod was crumbled over your soil.'
'And as if the pebbles of your land are jewels / And as if rose water is the drops of your dew.'
Then I said to him: "Where is [anything] from your love poetry that matches this?"

Two of those present set themselves apart to record what arises from Abu al-Tayyib's answers to what I present, and two to record what I mention and enumerate. When the scope of speech expanded, its sea surged, its waves threw (foam), and it overwhelmed them with what they could not independently draw in a book, they limited themselves to recording it quickly (shorthand/notes), and on the words at the beginnings of the verses, and glimpses they discarded as glimpses of the arguments in their notebooks. Their determinations were alerted to be gentle in gathering that because of what I expected of their attributing it to him, and nothing happened without my knowledge encompassing it.

I said: "Tell me about your saying:
'If some people are a sword for a state / Then among people are bugles for it and drums.'
Is this pure praise or hybrid?"
He said: "Rather, from its hybrid."
I said: "What forced you to it?"
[He said]: "It is a slip of the slips of the mind, from which rises my saying:
'Indeed, he who was named against us is fair / And indeed, he who named him a sword is unjust to him.'
'Not every sword cuts the heads with its edge / And cuts, for the changes of time, its noble deeds.'
And my saying in this meaning:
'The mind is bewildered in a sword whose origin is Rabi'a / And the Merciful is its maker (printer) and Glory is the polisher.'
And in this I say, pointing to this meaning, and mentioning the state of a messenger who had come to him from the King of the Romans:
'And how was this messenger guided in his land / While the dust clouds have not settled since I marched in it?'
'And from which water was he quenching his horses / While the watering places have not cleared from the mixture of blood?'"

I said: "You took your saying 'And Glory is the polisher' from the saying of Abu Tammam:
'Pouring, by which they polished their honors / Indeed generosity is the polisher of lineages.'
And you took your saying 'While the watering places have not cleared from the mixture of blood' from the saying of Abu Sa'd al-Makhzumi:
'He does not drink water except from a well of blood / Nor does a neighbor spend the night with him in fear.'
And Abu Sa'd took it from Bashar:
'A youth who does not spend the night on grudge / Nor drinks water except with blood.'

He said: "And my saying:
'Is there not for the Caliphate a compassionate one / For the sword of its state, the sharp cutter?'
'It cuts its neck without a striker / And travels to them without a carrier.'
And my saying in this meaning:
'The shoulder of the glorious King is its sword-belt / And in the hand of the Giant of Heavens is its hilt.'

I said: "You took this from the saying of Abu Tammam:
'Indeed he has failed whose heart's core / Is the grave of a spearhead whose worker (wielder) is in the hand of God.'

He said: "And my saying also in this meaning:
'Do you think the white swords of India are its origin / And that you are from them? Evil is what you imagine.'
'If they heard the name of the Prince, you would think them / Out of pride, smiling in their scabbards.'

I said: "The second is from the saying of my father, moving from one direction to another:
'The sun and the illuminating moon act proud / If we say: They are like the Prince.'

I said: "Tell me about your saying in the elegy of Sayf al-Dawla's mother:
'Nor are there among those in her funeral merchants / Whose farewell is the shaking of sandals.'
Is this how the likes of her is eulogized, when she was the Balqis of her age, a great destiny, and a huge kingdom, recently and of old?"

He said: "Am I not in this poem [saying]:
'The princes walked around her barefoot / As if the pebbles were of the down of ostriches.'
'And the cheeks appeared humble / Placing the soul in the most expensive places.'
'Calamity came to them while they were heedless / So the tear of sadness is in the tear of coquetry.'"
And he recited verses from the beauties of this poem.

[I said]: "The first verse of these verses is from the saying of Al-Sanawbari:
'A sleeper of the forenoon, hedgehogs are more gone (more awake/active) than him / When sleep overcomes him, the awakening of foxes.'
Or from the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'If she lay on the thorns of the caltrop / Under the heavy tread, she would find it like fennec fur.'
And the last verse of these verses looks at the saying of Al-Abbas bin Al-Ahnaf a hidden look. It is from his meanings which he invented:
'She wept, not comforting with weeping / You see the tear in her eyes as a stranger.'
Upon that, it is obligatory not to deny an excellence your poetry organized, nor a rare meaning your thought cast about in the lands. But you are in the verse of the poem and the verses an excellence that critics of speech and masters of eloquence are not ignorant of, concise in its expression, creative in its composition, correct in its meaning, and sound in its wording. Then you pair that with verses silly in wording and meaning, and with verses whose meanings and some words you raid like the raid of wolves on the flock of sheep, so the poem comes with poetry without resemblance.

One of the most obscene defects is that the word does not fall accompanying its sister, nor pairing with what neighbors it. Marwan bin Saeed bin Abbad bin Habib bin Al-Muhallab bin Abi Sufra said, addressing Abdullah bin Muhammad Abi Uyayna:
'What is wrong with your poetry, mixed and different / A verse worthy of praise and a verse falling, senile?'
Umar bin Laja' said to a cousin of his: 'I am more poetic than you.' He said: 'How?' He said: 'Because I say the verse and its brother, and you say the verse and its cousin.'
Do you not see the saying of the poet:
'And poetry like the dung of the ram, differentiated between it / Is the tongue of a claimant, an intruder in poetry.'
He says: It is different in meanings, contrasting in structures, running on no suitability nor similarity nor closeness, because the dung of the ram falls scattered, separated, contrasting.
Al-Kumait said:
'We saw in it white women, soft / White, in whom coquetry and coolness of teeth were complete.'
Nusayb criticized this on him and said: 'Why didn't you say as Dhu al-Rumma said:
'Dark-lipped, in her lips is a dark red color / And in the gums and in her canine teeth is coolness.'
This, by my life, is an obscene defect because the speech did not run on a system, nor arrived on conjunction and mixture, nor was consistent in coupling. One of the things speech needs is to be organized on the pattern of similarity and placed on the drawing of resemblance.

Among what you went in this way is your saying:
'How far is defect and decrease from my traits / I am the Pleiades and these two are gray hair and old age.'
This is also speech running on no suitability; because the Pleiades is not of the genus of gray hair and old age, nor are they of its genus. The face of speech was to say: I am the Pleiades in unveiling and height, and these two are Suha (star) in hiding and fading. Or to say: I am youth and these two are gray hair and old age.

Perhaps you presented the verse comprising, depositing of the impossible meaning, what agitates the poem entirely, even if it was of the core of wording and the hilt of eloquence, like your saying in the poem whose beginning is:
'A flock whose beauties are denied to their possessors.'
As if this verse is from the speech of Shibli or Samnun the Sufi. Then you flirted and said:
'I, despite my fondness for what is in her veil / Am chaste regarding what is in her trousers.'
How different is this from the saying of the first one:
'No, by Him to whom foreheads prostrate / I have no news of what is under her tail.'
Abu al-Tayyib said: "Is that so? And upon this, what I said is not more obscene than the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'Many a pregnant one like you I visited at night and a nursing one / So I distracted her from an amulet-possessing one-year-old child.'

'When he cried behind her, she turned to him / With a half, and beneath me her half did not shift.'
I said: Imru' al-Qais was hated (by women), and the pregnant one is the one desiring men. So he says: If I distract her, I am more loved than others. And you took this verse from a safer verse, more noble in wording:
'No, by Him to whom foreheads prostrate / I have no news of what is under her dress.
Nor of her mouth, nor did I intend her / It was nothing but conversation and looking.'
And your other saying in this manner is higher and more noble, which is:
'He repels a hand from her dress while he is capable / And disobeys passion in her phantom while he is sleeping.'

He said: "Did I not say in the second poem:
'I kissed them, the blazes of the horses, as if / The hands of Banu... were on their foreheads.'
And in it I say:
'And troops with troops, I left them / Food for wild beasts from their foods.'

I said: "As for the first verse, it is from Abu Nuwas describing hunting dogs:
'White-faced (blazed) and white-footed / As if our hands were on their chests.'
And the second verse is from his saying in this Urjuza:
'With dogs prancing in their straps / Counting the eye of the wild beast among their foods.'
And Abu Nuwas took it from the saying of Abu al-Najm:
'Counting the herds of the curved sands among her wealth.'

Perhaps you brought the hollow verse and the defective one. He said: "What is the defective and the hollow?" I said: "Yunus bin Habib narrated that the hollow is the corrupt of filling (padding), and the defective is what its two ends are defective. The limits of poetry are four: Wording, Meaning, Meter, and Rhyme. Its words must be sweet, accompanying; its meanings and metaphors appropriate; and its similes sound. And it should be easy of prosody, graceful of weight, chosen of rhyme, splendid of beginning. Perhaps you left empty, broke promise, excused (fell short), and wove thinly, and I do not see you looking at the necessity of these words."

He said: "And what necessity is there for them! You only cite them out of permissiveness, passion for lengthening, and dragging yourself with false claims."
I said: "Do not lengthen the rein of speech in what goes out of the schools of the people of virtue, lest you hear of speech what your patience narrows from. For Imru' al-Qais said:
'If a man does not store his tongue regarding it / He is not a storer of anything else.'
Rather, it is said of the poet if he comes with verses comprising original meanings and chosen words, then cites in their midst a verse empty of this description: He has left empty. And it is said of him if he comes with a meaning he did not fulfill: He has excused. And if he differs between the rhyme of the second hemistich and the rhyme of the first hemistich in the opening of the poem: He has broken promise. As Dhu al-Rumma said:
'O stay safe, O house of Mayy on the decay / And may the rain cease not pouring on your sandy hill.'
So as if when he said 'Ala al-Bila' (on the decay), he promised to compose a poem on [that] rhyme, and as if when he said 'Al-Qatru' (The Rain), he broke that promise by making it an R-rhyme."

Then I said: "And among your love poetry in which you diverged from the schools of the natural and refined poets is your saying:
'Thick (Rabhlah), dark her kissing place (lips) / Tall (Sabhlah), white her stripped place (body).'
Rabhlah: The large, good-bodied. Sabhlah: The tall, large. And a man is Sabhal Rabhal. Therefore, these two words are detested in the words of the moderns, because they are from the rough words of the Arabs. You took them as a copy from the saying of some Arab dandling a little daughter of his:
'Sabhlah Rabhlah / Growing the growth of the palm tree.'

I said: "Tell me about your saying describing a horse:
'He has exceeded in the leg the ostriches (Naqaniq) / And exceeded in the ear the leverets (Haraniq).'
'And exceeded in caution the magpies (Aqaqiq).'
He said: "What is in that?"
I said: "Your daring to organize this fallen speech and your boldness in striking the hearing with the likes of it, not shy nor observant. What do you intend by your saying 'Exceeded'? Did he exceed in the strength of the leg or in its length? And in the creation of the ear of the leveret or in the delicacy of its hearing? How silly is this in wording and how little its share of clarity. You only went in your saying:
'He exceeded in the leg the ostriches'
to the saying of Abu Duwad:
'He has the two legs of a male ostrich, dyed / Surprised by terror.'
And in your saying:
'And exceeded in caution the magpies'
the saying of some Arab:
'I was afflicted with a woman like the stick / More thieving and more malicious than a Kundush (magpie).'
And their saying: 'He is more cautious than a Kundush', which is the magpie. And you have heard the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'He has the two flanks of a gazelle and the two legs of an ostrich / And the jog of a wolf and the gallop of a fox.'

Let these words that led you into the wilderness distract you from the whisperings of your thought, and look at his combining of these divergent words and separate parts. For he likened in this verse four things, since the output of this expression is in simile, so that the intended meaning falls into clarity: that he has two flanks like the flanks of a gazelle, two legs like the leg of an ostrich, a jog like the jog of a wolf, and a gallop like the gallop of a fox. You strayed in these verses of yours from the path of excellence and extinguished with these anxious words the lamp of clarity.

He said: "So in it I say:
'He shows you clumsiness while he is the eye of the skilled.'"
That saying of his angered me and I said: "I see you count against us, yes!"
He said: "God forbid."
I said: "As for this, it is stripped, the stripping of the hide, from the Rajaz poet describing a she-camel:
'Clumsy except that she is skilled.'
Or from the saying of Hamid bin Thaur:
'So he said: Sleepy, and he was not sleeping / To the skilled of the foot, clumsy of the hand.'
These two verses are among the most concise of what the Arabs said. And what runs with them in brevity, good conciseness, and nearness of source is the saying of the other describing an arrow:
'He left a disease and went on healthy.'
And like it is the saying of the other describing a wild beast and an arrow:
'Until it escaped from his hollow and did not escape.'
Abu Nuwas said:
'The making of the gentle one and the snatching of the clumsy one.'
As if it is from the saying of Hamid bin Thaur:
'The clumsy one built his house, while she is gentle / For him, with stairs between two safe woods.'

And in this (poem) he says describing the horse:
'He outstripped the old horses (Madhaki) while he was in the Aqaiq (foal hair/womb).'
He only took it from the saying of the Rajaz poet:
'The ulcerated one has won while he is crouching / So how will he not win when he races?'
He means that his mother won while he was in her belly.

Then I said: "You were cold (dull) in this Urjuza according to your habit when you said:
'The snow resided in it like elbows / Knotting above the tooth the spit of the spitter.'
I call God to witness that this is of lean speech and fallen poetry." One of his followers said: "Is it said to the speech of the likes of him 'lean'?" [I said]: "Yes, is he not the one who says:
'The slave, his morals do not exceed / His private parts, the teeth, or his molar.'
And among his coldness is his saying:
'And you only trick in untying it / As if you are the sailor with his rope.'
And like this is his saying:
'For a Sari (traveler/noble) his clothing is rough cotton / And the Marwi cloth of Marw is the clothing of monkeys.'
And his saying:
'I was among people in a gathering / So here I am in a gathering of monkeys.'
'So do not listen to the liars / And do not care for the plot of the Jews.'

And of ugly simile is your saying describing a battalion:
'And a gathered, sword-bearing, spring-time (Rab'iyya) one / The pebbles shout in it the shouting of the stork.'
You took it from the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'And a town of shouting rocks.'
Better than this is the saying of Al-Nami in a word he praised Sayf al-Dawla with, the first of which is 'Stop, and upon him is the tear, for he is a dune'. He said in it:
'They stutter the words of the pebbles with hooves / If you speak to them, their non-Arabic speech expresses love.'
He said: "Do not the sounds of pebbles under the hooves of horses resemble the sounds of storks?"
I said: "Suppose it resembles it, is it among the beautiful similes? Do you not see that they condemned the saying of Labid:
'... and leaving like onions'
while it is a valid simile, and blamed the saying of the other:
'And the horses raid from through the dust / Like dates scattered from behind the cutter.'
And the good is the saying of the poet:
[Missing Verse Context] He says: They came out equal like the equality of the fingers of the one warming himself at the fire.

And of his rough wording is his saying:
'Where is the dirt (Turab) before his weaning / And he eats it before reaching the eating (age).'
The word 'Turab' (dirt), despite the soundness of its source, is very rough. He relied in this verse on the most delicate verse in its meaning and most touching in wording, which is the saying of Muhammad bin Yazid al-Umawi al-Sulami:
'Death weaned you before weaning / And decrease contained you before completion.'

And of the trivial speech, its fallen, and its obscure is his saying:
'You belittled every great one and rose above / Until it was as if you reached the age of a boy.'
This is of the closed, anxious copying, and it is, with its anxiety, taken from the sweetest and soundest wording. Some of the early poets in the Umayyad state said:
'You reached, for ten that passed of your years / What the gray-haired master reaches.
Your concern in them is great matters / And the concern of your peers is to play.'
And better than his saying 'You belittled every great one' is the saying of the first:
'He has ambitions that have no end to their greatness / And his smallest ambition is greater than Time.'
And of his coldness is his saying:

'A noble one, you shook the people when you reached him / As if they were what dried of the provisions of a traveler.'
Fie on this simile, and error to this representation, and oh mercy for the one praised by it and the one faced with its corruption.

And his saying also:
'He bites the ember and the iron, the enemies / Before him, the biting of the sugar of Ahwaz.'
And in this poem he says describing a sword:
'The sword-belts of Time carried it until / It is in need of a stitcher.'
Although he took it from the saying of Al-Buhturi describing a sword:
'Its old sword-belts carried a legume / From the era of Ad, fresh, not withered.'
By my life, he surpassed the stallion poets in his description of this sword, and ran with them in the race of excellence, but they fell short of the goal of his precedence. Al-Mutanabbi's saying describing his sword: 'It is in need of a stitcher' distracted us from the saying of Tarfa describing his sword:
'A brother of trust, not turning away from a strike / If it is said "Gently", his separator (the blow) says "Enough".
A sharp sword, if you rise victorious with it / The return (second strike) suffices you from the start (first strike), not weak.'
And from the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'A copy cuts the double Saluqi armor / And kindles the fire of the firefly with the blades.'
His saying: "If it is said gently" means if he says gently, the separator between me and the struck one says: It has completed what was intended of cutting.
And the saying of Abu al-Najm:
'It scatters, with the trembling of the right hand of the one exerting himself / The thick part of the forearm, the breaking of the cutter.'

I said: He is the one saying:
'Who is for me regarding Fahm, a people of an age who claim / That the Indian (sword) counts Baqil among them.'
If Baqil were the sayer of this poetry, he would be mourned for a period. How great is his admiration for the diminutive, yet no sweet diminutive happens for him in it. Perhaps he wanted to match the saying of Al-Qutami:
'Experience and calmness may make him last, indeed I / See the heedlessness of life before experiences.'
Or the saying of Al-Najashi:
'A little tribe that does not betray a covenant / Nor wrongs people a grain of mustard.'
But there came to us from his diminutive what went out of this door, so he strayed in it from the path of correctness, and he is the one saying:
'A little tribe, you are you, and you are of them / And your grandfather is Bishr the King, the Ham (Head/Owl).'
This, even if it is cheating as the Chief sees, is indicative of the stutter of its sayer. And how is it not attributed to coldness (dullness) when he comes with this and its likes!

And of the hybrid speech and base meaning is his saying:
By my life, this is of the results of his mind, the inventions of his thought, and the daughters of his chest. Likewise his saying also:
'So in every day this Domesticus is advancing / His back of the neck blames his face for advancing.'
This is of the lean antithesis, and sufficient is the saying of Abdul Samad bin Al-Mu'adhdhal:
'The beauty of your back of the neck revealed the beauty of faces.'
And sharing in this meaning is the saying of the other:
'His back of the neck is a face, then the face of whom / His back of the neck is a face resembles the soul.'
And what was criticized of Dhu al-Rumma is his saying:
'And Mayya is the best of the two worlds (humans and jinn) in neck / And throat, and the best of them in the back of the head.'

And of what you do not see doubt in its coldness nor in the stutter of its sayer:
'So pattern the water of his leg and sprinkle it in / The cities, you will be safe with the confident from the earthquake.'
And of the stutter and weak wording and severe need is his saying:
'The pouring cloud, son of the pouring cloud / Son of the pouring cloud, son of the pouring cloud.'
I wish Abu al-Tayyib conversed with the stars of darkness a whole night until its morning greeted him with its face when this verse was organized for him, and it will come later.

And of the most hybrid oaths and weakest knots of speech is his saying:
'If the like of you was or is to be / Then I am innocent at that time from Islam.'
He only imitated the saying of some judge in the days of Al-Ma'mun:
'I am innocent from Islam if this which / The slanderers told you about me is as they said.
But when they saw you fond / Of my connection, they advised each other with gossip and plotted.'
As if he did not hear the oath of Al-Nabigha in his saying addressing Al-Nu'man:
'I did not call for a thing you hate / If so, then may my whip not be raised to my hand.
If so, then may my Lord punish me a punishment / By which the eye of who comes to you with envy is cooled.'
Looking at this meaning is his saying in the other poem:
'If the palm of the right hand repelled you in fear / I would single out the right hand from the left.'
To the saying of Amr bin Qami'a:
'So I did not say what they spoke falsely / Nor did I hate that it be said.
If it was true as they reported / Then a right hand did not connect for me to a left.'

And from here Al-Nabigha took his saying:
'If so, may my whip not be raised to my hand.'
Suppose he did not intend this, did he not narrate the saying of Abu Sa'd al-Makhzumi:
'No, by Him who created the reddish wine from gold / And water from silver, he who is stingy does not rule.'
Nor did he narrate the saying of Ali bin Muhammad Al-Alawi Al-Basri:
'He meets spears with his throat and chest / And sets up his skull in place of the helmet.
And says to the side (body/horse): Be patient for the edge of the spears / For you would destroy the pillar of glory if you were not covered (forgiven/protected).
When he contemplates the figure of an approaching guest / Wearing the garment of a dusty night.
He signaled to the large camel: This is a night visitor / The enemies will slaughter me if you are not slaughtered.'

Lean speech and objectionable is his saying:
'A youth, a thousand parts is his opinion in his time / The least small part, some of it is the whole opinion.'
And his saying:
'So all of you came the coming of his father / And every deed of all of you is wonderful.'
This is disturbed wording and collapsing order. And his saying:
'O you in whose shade we seek refuge from Time / Forever, and drive away Iblis with his name.'
'Best on the palaces, and the worst of them / Takes refuge in ruins and inhabits the tombs.'
In this poem he says 'The best of birds are on palaces', while among the birds that inhabit built palaces are storks and owls, and they are not the best of birds.

And of the trivial speech is his saying:
'Until the people say: What is a sane one / And the treasury says: What is a Muslim.'
Only the saying of Ubayd bin Ayyub Al-Anbari, one of the thieves, harmed him:
'He would not give the likes of it in the likes of him / Except one of noble nature or a madman.'
Abu Nuwas went to this in his saying, where his mind strayed from the path of correctness in it:
'He gave money generously until it was said: Is this one sane?'
Abu Tammam said:
'He ceased not raving about noble deeds and dew / Until we thought he was feverish.'
Al-Buhturi said, and improved his expression:
'If a group protected generosity, it became difficult / With him, a mad determination in spending it.'
All these intended the saying of the first:
'In the love of him whose gifts are hoped for / They sought rain from Quraysh, every deceived one.
You think regarding him, when you deceive him... / About his money, while he is raising religion and piety.'
So he fell into the wilderness, and Abu al-Tayyib rolled in their traces on the top of his head. Abu Tammam had touched upon this meaning, so he stepped over the defect in it:
'Heights distracted him, so he does not count / Misery as misery nor bliss as bliss.'

And his saying:
'As if I rolled out the earth from my experience of it / And Alexander built the Dam from my determination.'
This is a reprehensible wording and a simile not approved. He only intended by it the saying of Abu Tammam, although there is no good in it either:
'So I smashed a dam, the dam of Gog, before him / Out of worry, no drop emptied on its anvil.'

And of what has no benefit is your saying:
'Near, far, answering, hating, joyous / Mightiest, sweet, bitter, soft, fierce.'
'Generous, refusing, jealous, fulfilling, brother of trust / Curly, noble, prohibitor, scarred, satisfied, intelligent.'
He took his saying 'Sweet, bitter' from the saying of Al-Shanfara, rather from the saying of Al-Hudhali:
'Sweet and bitter like the curve of the arrow shaft, its bitterness / In every vessel the night decreed, he wears.'
And of what has no benefit also is your saying:
'The pouring cloud, son of the pouring / Son of the pouring cloud, son of the pouring cloud.'
And like this is your saying also:
'I stab her with the spear, I strike her / With the sword, her chief, her burier.'
'Her most knightly knight and her longest / In reach, and her raider and her master.'
'Sun of her forenoon, moon of her night / Pearl of her necklaces, her chrysolite.'
It is, with that, composed a composition on the saying of Abu Bakr Duraid in a poem the first of which is 'I have no concern with length...':
'I mourn her... / Youth of Ya'rub and her defender.
Her drawn sword and her warrior / Her chief, her fortress, her lion.
I stab her with the spear and strike her / For her worries... her advancer.
Her lion, her star, her thick-necked one.'
Several verses ran in this manner. We have not heard of anyone likening a man to chrysolite before him, and this is of his virgin meanings and his free words.

And of hybrid speech is his saying also:
'He is not like the sea of water, its bottom is drained / To where the water ends, a whale and a frog.'
And of the leanness in which there is no doubt is his saying:
'The leanness of my life is that my dignity be lean / And it is not lean that food be lean.'

And more hybrid than this in wording and less in share of clarity is his saying:
'A writer, for knowledge in the land of his chest anchored / Mountains; the mountains of the earth beside them are a hill.'
'Generous, his palm rose in good and evil / A rising, so time wished its name was a palm (Kaff - also means stop).'
'So there is no inferior below whom rain is hoped for / Nor does the generosity end behind whom there is a successor.'
And his saying:
'And a forgiveness, if other than anger were from it / Their heads would have been made soles for sandals.'
And his saying describing rain:
'For its scraper on the graves is a heavy rain / Like the legs of horses seeing the nosebags.'
He was only deceived by the saying of Zuhair:
'... it scrapes the hills...' he did not mention the verse.
As for a rain-seeker asking for rain for graves that scrapes their soil and unearths their dirt, no one has said this. Rain is only sought for the dwellings of loved ones and for the graves of the noble so that land may be protected and those lands become grassy so they can be grazed. Then its people remember, and mercy is asked for who the soil hid in it. And everyone who is far from it yearns. Then they guard in the watering against effacing its dwellings and traces, as Tarfa said:
'So may there water your dwellings, without spoiling them / The pouring of spring and a continuous rain pouring.'
Another said:
'May God water a watering of mercy the people of a town.'
He guarded by his saying 'watering of mercy' a subtle guarding. As for seeking rain for it that effaces the trace, its impact like the impact of horses' legs striking the ground until it demolishes and digs it, then no.

And his saying:
'And I think he thought the spearheads sweet / Or thought them Barni dates and Azad dates.'
Kuthayyir was criticized for his saying, which is less than this:
'And they are sweeter, if you tasted one day / On the palates, than the dates of Ibn Tab.'
It was changed against him, so he made it: 'Than the honey of saliva', and there is no good in either. Then he said:
'So he became a prisoner, his clothes wet / With blood, and he wet the thighs with his urine.'
Likewise his saying: 'Al-Azada'. This is an anxious rhyme, attracted, imported, defective, unacceptable. The path of the poet is to care for refining the rhyme, for it is the center of the verse, whether that poetry is praise or blame, erotic or genealogical, description or simile. And to contemplate the purpose his thought aims for, so he waits in which meters it is better continuing, and with which rhymes it is more steady. So he clothes it in its most honorable exhibitions, highlights it in its safest expressions, and relies on establishing meanings in their seats and placing them in their locations. It was narrated about Al-Hutay'ah that he said: 'Refine the rhymes, for they are the hooves of poetry.'

So what a difference between your saying 'Al-Afkhadha' (The Thighs) and the saying of Al-Hutay'ah:
'They are the people who, when / A darkness of days befalls, they illuminate.'
For his saying 'they illuminate' has a subtle position; that is because it is a word that cannot be exchanged for another, nor changed with what fills its place.
Likewise the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'Like the chamomile on the morning after its rain / Its upper parts dried and its bottom is wet.'
For his saying 'And its bottom is wet' has a wondrous position in this place; that is because the blossoms... He disliked likening the mouth to it in this state, so the mouth would be like riding one part over another. So he likened it to chamomile when the sun hits it; he said: 'Its upper parts dried', he meant spread out and its wrinkling went away. Then he said: 'And its bottom is wet', so he guarded against it being withered and dry.

And your saying: 'He wet his clothes... and wet the thighs with his urine' looks at the saying of the first:
'I swore I would not bury your dead / So smoke the man and his shirt.'
He says: That if he stabs him, he defecates in his saddle. He alluded to that with this eloquent, innovative allusion, and expressed with this sturdy phrase. Among the saying in the revealing structures is the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'For indeed he will not boast over you like a boaster / Weak, nor will the like of a defeated one defeat you.'
And the saying of Zuhair:
'I know what is in today and yesterday before it / But I am blind to the knowledge of what is in tomorrow.'

And of his anxious words and obscure meanings is his saying:
'The clouds did not imitate your gift, but / It became feverish with it, so its pouring is the sweat of fever (Ruhada').'
He only looked at the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'Indeed the clouds are shy when they look / At your dew, so they measured it by what is in them.
Until they intend to stop, but prevents them / Fear of punishment for disobeying their Creator.'
And of this path is his saying:
'He almost, from the health of determination / Does what is almost not done (passive/affected).'
And of his affected, arbitrary exit which differed from the schools of the moderns is his saying:
'I love you, or they say an ant dragged / Thabir (mountain) and the son of Ibrahim was terrified (Ri'an).'

Ri'an is from Raw' (terror). How far is this speech from excellence, and how intense its difference from clarity, and how indicative it is of the narrow capacity of its sayer, and of the corruption of his imagination. I do not think he heard the saying of Mansur Al-Namari:
'Are you serious? Do you know that many a night / As if its darkness spreads from your locks of hair.
I was patient for it until it revealed a blaze / Like the blaze of Yahya when Ja'far is mentioned.'
Nor did he review the saying of Muhammad bin Wahib:
'His lips ceased not kissing me / And the pitcher and the cup gave me a second drink.
Until the night claimed back its robe / And a brightness appeared through its blackness.
And the morning appeared as if its rising / Was the face of the Caliph when he is praised.'
Nor the saying of Al-Buhturi describing a house:
'If I were given wishes in them / I would have watered them with the palm of Ibrahim.'
You took this and said:
'May a morning cloud among the clouds water your resting place / A match to the gift of your palm in giving.'
Nor his saying:
'They endured a night before Qasan which almost did not / Its ends catch up after its two sides.
Where gifts are flashing, unveiled / To every poor person, and promises are distinct.'
Nor his saying:
'Anemones carrying dew as if it is / Tears of youthful passion on the cheeks of the virgins.
As if the hand of Al-Fath bin Khaqan approached / Following them with those flashing thunders.'
Yes, you have read this, for you took the meaning in it and said:
'Return the connection, may a cloud water your remnants / If your connection were like it, it would not have cleared.
Thundering, showing you the sky as fire and the desert / As the sea, and the hills as a fertile garden.
Like the fingertips of Abdul Wahid who / Quenched and secured whom he wills and frightened.'

Of the best exits is the saying of Abu Tammam:
'Offense of accidents, derive a tunnel / For the kindness of Ibn Hassan has overshadowed you.'
And his saying:
'His two eyes did to the lover what / The gifts of your two hands do to hopes.'
And his saying:
'Do not deny the void of the noble from wealth / For the flood is war to the high place.
And look at the trotting of the mounts urged by / The reviver of poetry to the destroyer of wealth.
He spread hope for us despite calamities / With which the deaths of hopes increased.
The most expensive virgins of poetry are that their dowries / Are expensive with the noble when they become cheap.'

And of his closed generosity and rough erotic introduction is his saying:
'If they blamed regarding her, I answered that he / Is the two beloveds of my heart, my heart is Juml.'
And of the closed locked (meaning) is his saying:
'A land in which is the honor of others like it / If the like of you were found in others.'
He says: This land has an honor by your settling in it, and if the like of you were cast in another land other than it, it would be like this one.
His saying:
'Who is in the creation among the noble? And do not say / Who is in you, O Sham, other than Shuja' is intended?'
He wants: Do not say who is in you, O Sham, but who in all creation is intended.
And of the closed in it is his saying:
'How can Adam be the father of creation / While your father is Muhammad and you are the two heavy ones (Thaqalan - Jinn and Mankind)?'
The estimation of the speech: How can Adam be the father of creation while your father is Muhammad and you are the Thaqalan? Perhaps he means you are mankind and Jinn, and Adam is one of mankind, and your father is Muhammad, so how can Adam be the father of creation? He separated the subject which is 'Your father' and the predicate which is 'Muhammad' by the sentence which is his saying 'And the Thaqalan are you'. This is severe arbitrariness, and a path far from eloquence.

And of the obscure ambiguous is his saying:
'And how many and how many a need you permitted / Its appointment is closer than me to myself.'
This is of the reprehensible speech, and hateful composition. He only went to the shortness of his appointment's time, and the nearness of his promise in fulfilling it, but he expressed this meaning badly, every badness.
And of this genus is his saying:
'And the distance of our distance is the distance of nearness / And the nearness of our nearness is the nearness of distance.'
He says: The furthest of what was between us of distance, so he made it like the distance of nearness which was between us, and the nearest of our nearness he made like the nearness of distance that was between us. He went to the idea that his nearness to him was according to what was between him and him of distance.

And of the worst expression is his saying describing a horse:
'A swimmer (horse), she has from her, upon her, witnesses.'
And his saying:
'I chose the dark one of the two, O rain / And he who has in favors the news.'

He wants: I chose the dark one from these two mares, O man who runs in his generosity the course of rain. This is speech whose affectation and hatred witness its distance from the path of clarity.

And of his hybrid speech is his saying in satirizing Ibn Kayghalagh:
'And if he points while speaking, it is as if he is / An ape laughing or an old woman slapping.'
Abu al-Tayyib said: "Did you not review in this poem my saying:
'Ibn Kayghalagh protects the road while his wife / Between her legs is the main road.'"
I said: "This is from the saying of Al-Farazdaq:
'And you left your wife, O Jarir, as if she is / For the people, kneeling, a paved road.'"
Jarir said replying to him in it:
'And the perineum of Ji'thin is like the paved road.'
In this poem he says:
'He looks at you with chastity while he has / That the Magians are correct in what they judge.'
This is from the saying of Abu Tammam:
'My father is ransom for one whom if her father saw her / Approaching, he would say: I wish I were a Magian.'
He said: "There is no sin on me in a verse that deviates from the path of excellence, and wording that escapes the trap of clarity."

I said: "Tell me about your saying:
'I wore out, the wearing out of ruins, if I did not stand at them / The standing of a miser whose ring was lost in the dirt.'
How did you say it, 'Shahih' (miser) or 'Shajij' (wounded)?"
He said: "I said it with Ha (miser) only. This is a meaning I invented."
[I said]: "You only attracted it from the saying of Himyan bin Quhafa:
'So they are bewildered like the misplacers of the ring.'
So between the two words is a far distance. You have been desolate in your saying:
'I wore out, the wearing out of ruins, if I did not stand at them.'
And you did badly in the expression of what you took, so you completed the verse with it. Look at the saying of Abu Nuwas in the meaning of Himyan's verse, how wonderful it is, how good his method, how eloquent and clear when he says:
'My weeping has been long at the trace of the dwellings / And my repetition in them and my suffering have been long.
As if I am seeking in the dwellings a game / I see it in front of me once and behind me.'"

I said: "You have repeated the meaning of your saying 'I wore out, the wearing out of ruins', so you said, except that it did not come concise like your conciseness previously:
'Every thunderous rain ceased not to dissolve them / And sickness dissolves me until they resembled my body.'
You intended in this verse the best verse and most noble expression, so you returned it in his expression in an attracted expression, and words not sweet. Muhammad bin Wahib said:
'Two ruins, eternity has been long upon them / They were effaced, so there is no sign nor goal.
They wore wear-and-tear, as if they found / After the loved ones the like of what I find.'
If there were nothing in these two verses of the beauties of wording except his saying 'They wore wear-and-tear', it is a fitting, sweet metaphor. If a sayer wished to say it is in this place better situated than with it in the saying of Al-Ja'di:
'I wore people so I annihilated them / And I annihilated after people, people.'
Or from the saying of the other:
'The bedfellow did not turn her to him / She collapsed on him so she was a clothing.'
Although some Arabs have said, and fulfilled every speech:
'Do you not see that the wind between Muwaysil / And Jawa, if it blows on you, becomes sweet?'
And the other did well, all wellness, by his saying:
'To whom belongs a ruin I stood at, hindering / Asking its worn-out, distant quarter?
To Salma, no change to the quarter of Salma / And she clothed the thunderers and the lightnings.'
And the saying of Muhammad bin Wahib:
'They wore wear-and-tear as if they found'
is taken from the saying of Mu'alla Al-Tai:
'They wore wear-and-tear until as if their traces / Tasted passion or tasted the abandonment of loved ones.'
From this Al-Buhturi took his saying:
'Between Al-Shaqiqa and Al-Liwa and Al-Ajra' / Traces held back against the winds of the four (directions).
As if their dwellings contained what / The entrails of the pained lover contained.'

And like your badness in taking these two verses in your saying:
'And how many a youth, critically ill, belongs to passion / And how many a killed martyr belongs to distance.'
For you stole the second hemistich of this verse with the most obscene theft from Jamil, and from the beauties of his saying:
'For every conversation among them is cheerfulness / And every killed one among them is a martyr.'
I did not think a possessor of thought would permit violating the sanctity of this verse, and come to these moist, sweet words and transform them into that trivial wording and crumbling composition.

And of his exchanging the good deed with the bad is his saying:
'He cheered up before my greeting to him / And threw his money before the pillow.'
Were it not for his permissiveness in taking these meanings in which their owners preceded, and were first to invent, his tongue would have been flawed as the tongue of the fondled weaned camel is flawed. What does he do with his saying:
'He cheered up before my greeting to him'
with the saying of Zuhair:

'You see him when you come to him cheering up / As if you are giving him what you are asking him.'
A poet took his saying 'As if you are giving him what you are asking him' and said regarding Al-Sari bin Abdullah:
'As if he who comes to Al-Sari with a need / Made his camel kneel to him with what he came to ask.'
Al-Kumait took it and said:
'As if I came to him giving him glad tidings / And did not come desiring and attracting.'
And with the saying of some Arabs:
'When the askers come to him, there kindle / Upon him the lamps of cheerfulness and joy.
He has for those with needs a favor as if it is / The falling places of cloud water in the barren land.'

And of what he stole and did not increase upon but repeating its wording in a different meter from the stolen verse is his saying:
'For the wound bleeds after a while / If the building is upon corruption.'
For you took it in wording and meaning from the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'If the wound is mended upon corruption / The negligence of the doctor appears in it.'

And of this type is your saying:
'So she went, and modesty had dyed her whiteness / My color, just as gold dyes silver.'
So what do you do with this alongside the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'Wide-eyed in whiteness, yellow in whiteness / As if she is silver touched by gold.'
From this ember Bashar borrowed his saying:
'He insisted on me in play / A possessor of rest from fatigue.
A body of silver that has / Imbibed gold.'
From here Abu al-Shis transferred his saying describing wine:
'As if its cups are silver / That has been lined with red gold.'

And of your falling short in taking is your saying:
'Not by my people was I honored, but they were honored by me / And by myself I boasted, not by my ancestors.'
For you took it from the saying of the first:
'The soul of Isam ennobled Isam / And taught him attacking and advancing.
And made him a hero king.'
What do you do with your saying and the saying of others in this meaning alongside the saying of Amir bin Al-Tufayl:
'Amir did not make me a master by inheritance / God refused that I rise by mother or father.
But I protect its sanctuary and prevent / Its harm, and throw who threw it with a troop.'

And of your falling short in what you stole is your saying:
'They departed with a tender girl having a buttock / That almost, at standing, makes her sit.'
For you took it with the saying of the moderns:
'She walks and her buttocks make her sit / So as if she is walking backwards.'
This is the excuse (falling short). Do you not see that you did not fulfill the meaning because you only took the first half of this verse and left his saying: 'So as if she is walking backwards.'

And of the severe falling short is your saying:
'Are the watchers safe from your visiting in the darkness / Since where you were, from the darkness is light?'
This is of severe affectation, far from sound wording. Then you said:
'Anxiety of the beautiful woman, while she is musk, is her tearing (exposing) / And her marching at night, while she is the sun.'
In your saying 'hatkuha' (her tearing) is tearing of the sanctity of her love. You stole the first verse from the saying of the poet:
'She smiled so the darkness cleared and she did not / Hide, and she was before hiding it.'
And from the saying of the other:
'A moon, his beauty told on him / How can the night hide a rising full moon?'
You took the second verse from the saying of Bashar:
'My hope, do not come in moonlight / For a hadith, confident of the armor.
And beware perfume this night of yours / It is a slanderer (informant) if it spreads.'
Bashar took the first verse from the saying of Omar bin Abi Rabi'a:
'She said: You spoke truth, but in moonlight / Did you not see until you came the armor?'

Then I said to him: "And another from your saying:
'He sought the emirate in the frontiers while his upbringing / Was between Karkhaya and Kalwadha.'
From where did you get this dialect in 'Kalwadha'? I do not think you took it except from the sailors."
He said: "How?"
I said: "You erred in it an error in which you stumbled, straying from the face of correctness."
He said: "Why?"
I said: "Because the correct form is 'Kalwadh' with a Kasra on the Kaf and sukun and dropping the Ya."
He said: "What is Al-Kalwadh?"
I said: "The Ark of the Torah, the city was named after it."
He said: "What is the proof of this?"
I said: "The Rajaz poet:
'As if the sounds of the saddle... / The writing of scrolls on Kalwadh.'
Al-Kalwadh: The Ark of the Torah of Moses. It was narrated in some accounts that he was buried in this place, so because of it, it was named Kalwadh."
He lowered his head, not returning an answer, then said: "Knowledge of this did not reach me before, and your saying is accepted and the benefit is not denied."

I said: "And you erred in your saying:

'A hand reached you, equal with it are / The grey hawk (Al-Baziy) and the piebald crow.'
For you emphasized (shaddada) the Ya in 'Al-Bazi', which has no basis, and you connected the cutting Hamza in 'Al-Ashhab'. I do not know anyone of the eloquent who emphasized the Ya in 'Al-Bazi' except Al-Buhturi, and upon him you relied, and on the wording of his verse you leaned in his saying:
'And the whiteness of the hawk (Al-Baziy) is better in color / If you contemplate, than the blackness of the crow.'
This has been refuted against Al-Buhturi and he was faulted for his emphasizing the Ya. What is heard in that are two dialects: One is Baz and Buzah, just as you say Qadin and Qudah, and Ramin and Rumah. Imru' al-Qais said:
'On a hawk (Bazin) in the sky, soaring.'
The second dialect is 'Baz' with Hamza and 'Ab'uz', just as you say Kalb and Aklub, and it collects as Bi'zan; that came in eloquent poetry.

He said: "I did not say it like that, but I said 'Al-Bazi l-Ashhab' (The hawk, the grey) with a sukun."
I said: "You cut the connecting Hamza in 'Al-Bazi l-Ashhab' (making it Al-Bazi Al-Ashhab) and connected a cutting Hamza, so you combined two necessities in one verse."
He said: "The like of that has come in poetry."
[I said]: "It only came as an oddity and is not permissible for a modern."
He said: "Al-Tirimmah said:
'O long night, will you not clear (ala asbih)' so he connected."
I said: "Al-Tirimmah is a villager, and the correct narration is:
'O night which was long, become morning / With smiling, and the morning in you is not more comfortable.'

I said: "You also erred in your saying:
'And that you were yesterday dreaming / The Sheikh of Ma'add while you are its beardless one.'
For you treated the hidden pronoun in your saying 'Annk' (That you) the same way as with the apparent, and there is severe ugliness in it. 'Annk' meaning 'Annaka' is only good with the apparent, like the saying of the poet:
'And a day she comes to us with a divided face / As if [she is] a doe reaching for the leafy Salam tree.'
And the saying of the other:
'And a chest shining of throat / As if its breasts are two boxes.'
He said: "The other said:
'So know that you (Annk) in the day of ease asked me / For your separation; I did not clear while you were a friend.'
I said to him: "This is permissible upon necessity, and the face of its permissibility is very weak. Analogy does not carry oddities and necessities. Although you looked at the saying of Abu Tammam:
'And that you, if you dressed him in might, bestowing / And clothed him in that majesty, favoring.'

Then I said: "You also erred in your saying:
'His noble deeds defeated all noble deeds / Until it was as if noble deeds were tribes.'
'And they killed Dafr and Al-Duhaym, so you do not see / The Mother of Al-Duhaym and the Mother of Dafr bereaving.'
He said: "What is the face of the error?"
I said: "What did you intend by your saying 'And they killed Dafr and Al-Duhaym'?"
He said: "They are names of the Calamity, and the World may be called Dafr."
I said: "This is an error regarding Al-Dafr; no one said it, nor did a narrator narrate it, nor did a claimant claim it of the Arabs.
