As for Al-Dafr, it is the stench; and the report about Umar, God have mercy on him, is 'Wa Dafrah' (Oh stench). The Arabs nickname the World 'Umm Dafr' (Mother of Stench) because of the dunghills in it. And it is said: I pushed him a push (Dafartuhu dafran) if I pushed his chest. And they said to the slave girl 'Ya Dafar' due to her stench. And it is said: 'Dafran Dafran' to what so-and-so brings, if he made the matter ugly or stinking. The author of Kitab al-Ain said: Al-Dafr is the falling of worms into food and meat, and the World is Dafrah, i.e., stinking. Similar to this Ibn Duraid mentioned in Al-Jamhara. This is the saying of the people of knowledge and the repository of language books, and no one is known to have claimed that the Calamity is called Dafr, nor that the World is called Dafr.

As for Al-Duhaym, it is one of the names of the Calamity; the origin of that is that a she-camel belonging to some kings was called Al-Duhaym. He killed a people and sent their heads on her in a sack. When she came, they said: She has ostrich eggs on her. The messenger said: Look at what the eggs hatch. When he looked at the heads of his children, he said:
'And at Al-Duhaym, if her rope were untied / And she ascended, she would not lack a driver from the Jinn.'
He means that the Jinn help in doing the hateful deed. Then their pessimism with this name increased until they made the Calamity 'Duhaym'."

He said: "If the World is nicknamed Umm Dafr, it is also named Dafr because of their nicknaming of these things."
I said: "The matter is contrary to what you imagined. If the matter were so, the World would be named Shamlah, because they nicknamed it Umm Shamlah. Muhammad bin al-Hasan bin Miqsam recited to us, saying: Ahmad bin Yahya recited to us, [from] Ibn al-A'rabi:
'From Umm Shamlah, her calamities shoot us / Deceptive, from which terrors are seen.'
And wine would be named Khall (Vinegar), because they nicknamed it Umm al-Khall as the poet said:
'I threw Umm al-Khall (Wine) with the love of his heart / So he did not recover from it for three nights.'

And no one of the scholars, by whose light one is illuminated and whose fresh water is approached, claimed that. And this world would be named Hubayn, because of their nicknaming it Umm Hubayn. And the fever would be named Mildam [because they nicknamed] it Umm Mildam. So your saying: 'Umm al-Duhaym and Umm Dafr are bereaving' has no consistency in its meaning. The outcome of the meaning in your verse is that the Mother of Stench and the Mother of Calamity are bereaving (lost a child). This is of the detested meanings that disgrace their speaker, degrade his worth, and brand his poetry with the brand of deficiency, because it combined corruption of meaning and error in language.

In this poem you say:
'If the birth of every living thing were good like him / Women would give birth while having no midwives.'
I do not see you intended anything but that they expand until the woman does not feel, at her labor, the exit of the fetus from her. Otherwise, what is the face of dropping her need for the midwife at her birth? Did you not hear the saying of the first:
'A mother carried him, blessing him / As if she did not know of the pregnancy.
A bright, masculine one carried him / Radiant, daughter of the bright noble women.'
So you brought what a possessor of sound strength and sharp mind does not bring. How beautiful is what Al-Karous bin Zaid al-Tai said:
'If Ma'qil rejoiced at me in my hardship / The midwives surely rejoiced at me at their hands.
He raised his voice with him when he raised his voice / Beautiful faces, soft of fingertips.
When he was clothed in sword-belts and leaned / Attacking with the tips of withered spears.
The enemies realized that his spearhead / Prolongs the whining, the whining of bereaving mothers.'
This saying enraged him and changed his color, and he sought rest in the saying of a fool, deficient in mind, who was in his presence: "Glory be to God, how wonderful is the beginning of this poem:
'You have, O dwellings, dwellings in the hearts / You became desolate while they are populated with you.'
He did not complete the verse before I said to him: More wonderful than it—may God wake your slumber—is that he stole this from it, which is the saying of Abu Tammam:
'I stood while my entrails were a dwelling for grief / In it, while it is a desert whose dwellings are effaced.'
Abu Tammam followed in this saying Dhi'b al-Khuza'i:
'Is there anyone for an eye that ceases not to be sleepless / And O who is for a heart that ceases not to be hunted?
Passion shot him until when it pierced his heart / It repeated in his entrails and scattered.
My heart built for me a dwelling in his heart / And the eye gave you a seat from its pupil.'
Qais bin Mu'adh pointed to this by his saying:
'She traveled in the black of the heart until when / The journey ended with her and she sought the sanctuary of the heart, she settled.
So the eye has pouring if the heart gets bored of her / And the heart has whispers if the eye gets bored.
By God, there is nothing in the heart of love / For another besides her, whether she did much or little.'
And here is Abu Uthman al-Najim saying, despite the lateness of his time:
'If the distance of his dwellings saddened me regarding him / And my paths narrowed against me in his love.
I turned to a person of his, not distant / His dwellings are between the entrails and the chest bones.'

I said: "And you erred in your saying:
'A king whose days boasted (zahat) of his place / Until they boasted of him over the days.'
It was correct to say: 'Zuhiyat' (Passive: were made proud) by his place. Do you think that with your virtue and extensive literature, you did not study the book 'Al-Fasih' and what it contains of his saying: 'You have been proud (Zuhiyat) against us, O man, and you are proud (Mazhu). Likewise it is said: The man was proud (Zuhiya) and the woman was proud (Zuhiyat), just as it is said the man bragged (Nukhiya) and the woman bragged from Nakhwa (pride), so they are Mankhuwan. Aisha, may God be pleased with her, said: "Jewelry is borrowed for brides, and so-and-so is too proud (Tuzha) to wear it." And 'Zaha' is not said except for plants when they yellow and their color (Zahw) appears, i.e., their yellowness. The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, forbade selling dates until they color (Yazhu). Some of our companions say until they color (Yuzhi) from Azha. And it was mentioned that 'Yazhu' is an error. And Al-Zahw is the unripe date when it colors. It is said: The unripe date colored (Azha), and Izha', they claimed, in the unripe date is that it yellows and reddens. Al-Asma'i says until the unripe date colors (Yuzha), with a Fatha on the Ha, and refuses anything else. The yellow unripe date. And Al-Zahw is lying; he recited:
'With Ibn Imran is a lie (Zahw) without wet dates / And with him are wet dates on the palm tree, forbidden.'
He says with him is a lie, not unripe dates. And the other said:
'And do not speak a lie (Zahwan) regarding what you tell us / Gray hair has not left for me a lie (Zahwan) nor blindness.'
Al-Zahw is also: The beautiful appearance; and Al-Zahw is pride. The poet said:
'Whenever I wish, other than the pride of kings / I make you a group at a water pond.'

Al-Zahw is also that the camels drink then extend in seeking pasture and do not graze around the water. It is said: The camels extended (Zahat al-ibil zahwan). And the wind shakes (Tazhi) the plant if it moves it. And the mirage lifts (Yazhi) the company as if raising it, and waves lift (Tazhi) the ship.

I said: "And you also erred in your saying:
'And the earth narrowed until their escapee became / If he saw other than a thing, he thought it a man.'
Do you know a visible object that sight perceives to which the name 'thing' does not apply? I think you looked in it to the saying of Jarir:
'You ceased not to think every thing after them / Horses attacking you and men.'
So you shifted the meaning from its direction, and expressed it with other than its expression. Jarir's saying is of the pleasant imagery. Al-Akhtal claimed he took it from the saying of God Almighty: 'They think every shout is against them', and it is fitting that he took it from the saying of Al-Awwam bin Shawdhab Al-Shaybani:
'If it were a sparrow, you would have thought it / A marked (horse) calling Ubayd and Aznam.'
And of the pleasant imagery is the saying of the other regarding the imagination of the drunkard:
'I ceased not drinking wine until I thought myself / A prince over whom I wished to be prince.
Until I thought the night and the approaching morning / Two horses strutting, a black and a blond.'
And of what is appreciated in this meaning is the saying of Thabit Qutna:
'I became intoxicated until I imagined my mount / Had seven ears that grew on it after me.
Until I thought the land a sea and imagined myself / Hanging the bright stars at the edges of my cloak.'
My father recited to me, saying: Abu Umar bin Sa'd al-Qutrubulli the scribe recited to me, saying: Tha'lab recited to me for Tuhaym al-Asadi, and this is attributed to Ibn al-A'rabi:
'And one extending over the reddish wine, he came early to it / Among youths skilled in the morning drink.
Every creature he saw, he thought it a cup / And every person he saw, he imagined him the cupbearer.
Until he sipped it, he did not linger and it did not cease / To leave him prostrate, having no charmer (healer).'

Then I said: "And you erred in your saying addressing Kafur al-Ikhshidi:
'He exposes the sun whenever the sun rises / With an illuminating black sun.'
How is the sun, whose dye is whiteness and light, described with blackness? And what is the face of borrowing the sun for the black, if you went in that to metaphor?"
He said: "I only went to the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'For you are a sun and the kings are stars / If it rises, no star appears from them.'"
I said to him: "He only went in this to the fact that he, in his glory and sovereignty and by adding kings to him, is like the sun covering the stars at its rising. You only intended that this praised one, in his descriptions, exposes the rising sun, and he is with that a black sun, and the sun is not black except in the state of its eclipse. You only went in this to the blackness of his skin, and you blamed him in the apparent speech by your saying 'black' a blame; with it, the praise returned as satire. There is no difference in my view between your saying this in his praise, and your saying in the other word in his blame:
'Indeed a man whom a pregnant woman manages / Is oppressed, hot of eye, stricken in heart.'

I said: "And you erred in his saying opening a poem you praised this man with; for you said:
'Enough as a disease for you that you see death as a cure / And sufficient for deaths that they be wishes.'
For you opened his praise with what elegies are opened with, and you reckoned him to be the food of deaths shortly by confronting him with them. It is the way of the poet to investigate for his poem the best beginning, just as he investigates for it the best ending upon reaching his need, and to make the opening of his speech the best he can in wording and meaning. And to begin his poem with what suits the meaning he intended. For Abu Nuwas, if he were blaming with his saying:
'O Quarter of Decay, indeed humbleness is apparent / Upon you, and indeed I did not deny you my affection.'
Or finding slow, his beginning would not have been disapproved. But Al-Barmaki flew into a rage from him upon his reciting this poetry to him, for he took it as an evil omen. When he reached his saying:
'Peace be upon the world if you are lost / O sons of Barmak, from goers and comers.'
His evil omen was confirmed, and days did not pass until Al-Rashid fell upon the Barmakids.
Likewise Al-Buhturi, if he were satirizing with his saying:
'Woe to you from a night whose end was long / And the nearing of the departure of a tribe whose camels are bridled.'

He would have been doing well; because every class of speech decrees a type of beginning and a form of opening not suitable for another. Abu Sa'id said when he recited to him: "Woe to you from a night", rather woe and war to you. So the praising seeker of favor should open his poetry with what is indicative of his purpose and pointing to his desire. And not to mix it with what is taken as a bad omen and is deemed rough in his speech: like the obituary of youth, the separation of loved ones, the blaming of time, the cutting off of peers, and the mention of desolate ruins and effaced, decaying traces. It has been said that Al-Aswad bin Al-Mundhir, when Al-A'sha recited to him:
'What is the crying of the old man at the ruins / And my asking, so what does my asking return?'
He blamed this opening and hated it. It reached us about the Caliphs of Banu Marwan that one asked Dhu al-Rumma to recite something, so he recited:
'What is the matter with your eye, the water pours from it?'
So he rejected him and silenced him. Al-Ja'di recited to some kings his poem in which he says:
'I wore people so I annihilated them / And I annihilated after people, people.'
He said: That is due to the excess of your bad luck. Abu Dulaf bin Isa asked Rashid bin Ishaq the Scribe to recite some of what he lamented his goods with, so he recited:
'Alas, the penis you used to know has gone.'
So Abu Dulaf lowered his eyes and said: Rather your mother used to know it. When Al-Akhtal recited to Abdul Malik:
'The residents lightened (left), so they departed from you or went early.'
He said: Rather from you, taking it as a bad omen. This was the case of Jarir with him when he recited:
'Are you waking up? But your heart is not waking.'
For he replied to him and said: Rather your heart.

Then I said: "And you erred in your saying:
'Is it not strange that your description is miraculous / And that my thoughts limp (Tazla') in your high qualities?'
So you borrowed 'limping' for your thoughts, and it is an ugly metaphor, and you wondered at what is not to be wondered at, because he whose description is miraculous, the falling short of thoughts and their confusion in his high qualities is not denied. You only transferred it from the saying of Abu Tammam and corrupted it:
'His wishes ascended a mountain of might; if the wind / Ascended with it a span, it would return limping.'
Makhlad said describing a desert:
'Heavenly, the wind asks its generosity to descend / And the wind limps in it in the clear paths.'
He said: "I only ran on the custom of the Arabs in metaphor."
I said: "Yes, except that it is a reprehensible, anxious metaphor that settled in other than its place, and fell in other than its location. Metaphor, if its position in clarity is not above the position of reality (literal meaning), is not a subtle metaphor. The reality of metaphor is that it is the transfer of a word from a thing it was made for, to a thing it was not made for. It is of three types, do you know them?"
He said: "What do I have to do with this?"
I said: "Then I mention them by necessity, to show that you are isolated from excellence in your saying:
'For my thoughts limp in your high qualities.'
The first of them: The Approved Metaphor, which is that whose position in clarity is above the position of reality, like the saying of God Almighty 'Indeed, when the water tyranized (Tagha - rose high)'. The reality of Tagha is 'Ala' (rose). When He, the Almighty, said Tagha, He made it an excessive rise, so this metaphor had a share in clarity that reality did not have. And of the approved metaphors is the saying of Al-A'sha:
'And I robbed the buxom girl / The beautiful, the beauty of her youth.'
He means I enjoyed her until I exhausted her youth. Aws bin Hajar said:
'You see the earth from us in the space sick / Burdened from us by a huge army.'
His borrowing sickness for the earth is an exaggeration in describing the large number of their count and the impact of their horses' hooves. As if the earth carried a weight from them it could not rise with, so that earned it a sickness. The reality of sickness is decrease, so as if the capacity of the earth failed, and its powers fell short and decreased from independence with what they burdened it. The poet said:
'And a night that was sick from every side / Neither sun nor moon lights up in it.'
He means by his saying 'sick' the decrease of its light. And of the subtle metaphors is the saying of the other:
'They arrived for a midday rest while the pebbles were ignited / And the saliva of the sun melted over the skulls.'
He borrowed 'ignition' for the pebbles, informing of the burning of the heat. And he borrowed 'saliva' for the sun informing of the intensity of the heat. And from here you took your saying:
'And for the sun upon the working camels is saliva.'
And the saying of the other:
'I saw the virtue of the Qurashi when / I saw the horses saddled with spears.'
He borrowed 'saddled' (Tusraj - implies lit/saddled) for spears, i.e., kindled, informing of their spreading and interlacing, and the intensity of stabbing and its heat, as if they are flaming due to their collision and interlacing as Imru' al-Qais said:
'If they ride horses and put on armor / They burn (with zeal/heat), while the day is cold.'

The Second Type: And it is the Reprehensible Metaphor; and it was only named reprehensible because they borrowed for what reasons, names and words of what does not reason, like the saying of Al-Hutay'ah:

'The children did not cease until I saw him / On the young camel with a leg and a hoof.'
This poet only described a man who was hosted and honored, so he said: The maids and children did not cease to honor him until I saw him having ridden his mount and departed thankful from them. The meaning is in the utmost beauty, except that he said at the end of the verse 'He passes it with a leg and a hoof', so it became ugly when he borrowed for the man the place of his foot 'a hoof'. From this is the saying of Al-Hutay'ah also:
'They hosted your neighbor, the craving one, when you shunned him / And his lips (Mashafir - camel lips) shrank from the cold of the drink.'
So he made a 'Mashfar' (camel lip) for him in place of the lip. From it is the saying of the other:
'I will prevent her or I will place her affair / To a king whose hooves (Azlaf - cloven hooves) have not split.'
So he made a 'Zilf' (cloven hoof) for the king in place of the nail, and it did not satisfy him until he said: 'Have not split'.

The Third Type: Of metaphor is better than the second because they borrowed for what does not reason a name for what reasons, like the saying of Hamid bin Thaur Al-Hilali:
'I wondered at her, how is her singing / Eloquent while she did not open a mouth with her logic.'
This poet described a pigeon and wanted to say 'did not open a beak', so he said 'did not open a mouth', so it was good. If a human said 'did not open a beak', it would be ugly and bad in wording. Although Al-Asma'i mentioned that 'Fam' (mouth) is used for all animals. The Rajaz poet said describing a horse:
'And a pouring runner... / How the surface of the ground kissed his foot.'
So he made a 'foot' for him in place of his hoof, so it was better than the saying of the other in place of the man's foot 'his hoof'.

I said: "And the metaphor you used contradicts these three divisions, because suspicion (Dhann) does not have a real action for which you borrowed limping (Dhal') in its place. It is only said: Distant suspicion, false suspicion, Alma'i (brilliant) suspicion, and correct suspicion. These are all appropriate metaphors. It was not heard from an eloquent poet nor a pure Arab: Limping suspicion. Borrowing limping for the wind, even if distant, is more appropriate and closer, because it is said: Weary (Hasra) wind, and sick wind, meaning its fatigue and the decrease of its blowing. So it was permissible to place limping in place of fatigue, because it is of the genus of the shortcoming of blowing. Likewise, limping in the wind is placed other than its place, and it is only said in this meaning 'Weary wind'; and weary is not in reality, it is only cited as a metaphor. And the position of 'weary' in clarity is better than the position of 'limping'. So you exchanged an appropriate, subtle metaphor from their saying: Distant suspicion, false suspicion, brilliant and correct suspicion, with a hidden, distant metaphor from your saying: 'In your high qualities limp'. And the case of the foot, hoof, mouth, and beak benefits the case, because they are borrowed names placed in the places of real names."

And of the distant metaphor is your saying:
'Lion of lions, the thick-necked, his dye / Is death; the shoulder muscles (Farisa) of death tremble from him.'
You made 'Fara'is' (shoulder muscles) for death, and it is the plural of 'Farisa', and the face is to pluralize 'Farisa' as 'Fara'is'. The 'Farisa' is a piece of flesh under the shoulder said to be a killing spot. It is a very distant metaphor.

He strayed from the answer, and the key to this door was obscure to him, and he heard what his happiness did not run with hearing the like of, because the valley he walks in his poetry is different from it. When he affects this track, and deals with craft in his poetry, and does not perfect his excellence in it, he runs in it on his first shape. Do you not see his saying:
'And many a sleeve (Kumm) the Lord kissed before him / And every brave one (Kami) standing, shrinking.'
So he made a pun with 'Qabl' and 'Qublah' and 'Kumm' and 'Kami', so his wording was not pure, nor did his nature aid him in excellence, and his material was cut off before correctness.

Then I said to him: "And you erred in your saying:
'Armor (La'mah) overflowing (Fada), wide (Ada), smooth / The two hands of David perfected its weaving.'
Because it is not said 'Fada' armor, it is only said: 'Mufada', and its plural is 'Mufad'. Armor is also called 'Fadfada' and 'Fadafida' if it is wide. Imru' al-Qais said, and some of our companions narrate it for Abu Duwad:
'And I prepared for war a wide one (Fadfada) / Shrinking in folding like the file.'
If you derived 'Fada' from the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'Her sleeves overflow (Tafidu) on the person / Like the overflow of the flood on the cricket.'
The face is to say 'Fa'ida' not 'Fada'. This word did not come in pure Arabic poetry, nor in eloquent generated speech. We have not heard of 'Fada' except from this verse of yours, and from the verse of Abu al-Shis:
'And dwellings for the peer he thinks overflowing (Fada) / The blood hung on his wide (Fadfad) dress.'
Abu al-Shis is using of this word what has no origin, and is not permissible in language. He only intended the pun so he dropped this dropping.

Then I said: "And you also erred in your saying:
'If I attain what I hoped from you, then perhaps / I drank of water whose watering place makes birds incapable.'"

He said: "And what is the face of the error?" I said: "You made him a miser from whom nothing is reached. And you likened yourself in your reaching what you reached from him to your drinking from water whose watering place makes birds incapable, due to the distance of its drinking place and the vastness of its demand."

"And you erred in your saying, misleading:
'So they passed every saffron-dyed one / And given to drink the milk of the Sha'il.'
The 'Sha'il': It is the one whose milk has risen (Shaala) from the she-camels, rose. And the plural of Sha'il is 'Shul', and they are the she-camels with little milk. It is said 'Shawwalat': If her milk became little. So how did you single her out with the milk of the Sha'il despite its scarcity and height? It was more appropriate that you make her abundant, not possessing little milk, as Mutayr bin Al-Ashyam said, and he was a describer of horses:
'I reserved for her four distinct (camels) / And made her hoof write that it would seek.
And I said to their caretaker: Quench her / Loudly and do not do badly by increasing.'
He was not pleased to limit her to one until he mentioned four for her feeding. And you, when you limited her to one, you made her a Sha'il."
He said: "I only intended that she be preferred with milk, despite its scarcity and height, over the dependents due to her nobility and generosity."
I said: "And you, if you intended that and went to it, you inform of the hardship, severity, and interruption of milk. This is falling short regarding the mare despite preferring her, and invalidating her feeding and disturbing her strength. Mutayr is more praiseworthy than him and more indicative of good feeding. It is said a she-camel 'Sha'ila' and 'Sha'il' also, and its plural is 'Shul', and 'Sha'ila' for the one who raised her tail, to be known that she is pregnant, and its plural is 'Shul'. Abu al-Najm said:
'As if in the tails of the Shul / From the dung of summer are the horns of the mountain goat.'"

Then I said: "And you erred in the poem which begins:
'Every claimant of sound mind claims you.'
By saying:
'The passing thoughts twist between us / And mention the approach of the Prince, so it becomes sweet to me (Tahlu li).'
For you brought a verse with a Ridf (letter of prolongation before the rhyme letter) in a poem without Ridf, and this is odd (Shadh)."
He said: "This, even if it is odd as you mentioned, is sweet on the tongue, not anxious in recitation. The like of it has come for the Arabs:
'And by roaming, the youth attained the best of what he attained / And man is nothing but by turning and roaming (Tawf).'
Then he said:
'Separation of a beloved and ending of passion / So do not blame me, what I hide has appeared to you.'"

I said: "By my life, a people with no knowledge see this as odd, and do not see the Waw preceded by Fatha nor the Ya as odd Ridf. They claim they are not letters of prolongation (Madd), because the sound does not extend with them like its extension with Ya and Waw preceded by Kasra and Damma. That is a mistake from its sayer, since the Fatha before them opened them from their genus, since their exit in both cases is from one place in the mouth. So their form in pronunciation is one, but the Fatha moves them slightly, so the sound does not extend with it the full extension, but it extends an extension by which they deserve to be called letters of prolongation. So if a verse comes for the Arabs containing Ridf with what has no Ridf together, and it is counted as odd—just as they have Iqwa, Ikfa, and Ita (defects of rhyme)—then it is not for a modern poet to commit the like of that, nor permit in his rhymes any defects, even if they exist in their poems by way of oddities. Do you not see the saying of Ibn Bayd addressing Khalid al-Qasri who had imprisoned him:
'Pale, inner like the chest of a Yemeni (sword) / Sharp of impact, wrapped in other than a scabbard.
And when complete, it returned as a sharp nerves / And the edge of the whetstone polished its two blades.
It was not a crime that caught me / From my left nor did my right commit it.
But a noble brother and friend committed it / And upon its people Baraqish (a dog) committed a crime (Tajni).'
Is it permissible for a modern to come with the like of this and use it or its like as proof? No."

He said: "You have spoken much about what I do not count any of. I only run on my nature, and say what my tongue permits."

And of what is held against him in rhyming is his saying:
'I am, with the slanderers if I mentioned you, more resembling / Dew comes and is spread about you, so you hate it.'
'And if I saw you without an army, intervening / I was certain that God seeks victory.'
What is the rhyme letter (Rawi) in these two verses?
He said: "The Ha."
I said to him: "If you made the Ha the rhyme letter, that is not permissible. Because the Ha of the pronoun cannot be a Rawi, except if what is before it is silent (Sukun), like the saying of Tarfa:
'O gazelle whose two earrings flash.
Were it not for the sitting king / His mouth would have kissed me.'

If you made the Ra the rhyme letter and the Ha a connection (Sillah), which is the [correct] face, then what do you do with your saying: 'If I mentioned you, I resemble (Ashbahu)'? Unless you go to the idea that he did not rhyme the hemistichs (Tasri')."

He turned to me and said: "Be fair, for fairness is of your traits. And look closely, the looking of your like, whose foot has advanced in knowledge and to whose position is pointed. Do not give authority to passion over opinion. Who is he whose beginnings were consistent and whose ends and fronts of poetry were similar? And who is he who is innocent of defect? And evil is he who follows a composer or a prose writer, whether of poetry or another. I am not an innovation among them. If you were fair to yourself, and threw the cloak of zeal off your shoulder, you would find yourself, in all that you listed of my lapses and announced of my verses, refuted. Because he who does well in much, his badness in the little easy is forgiven.

This is Imru' al-Qais, and he is the Imam of poets, and the one surpassing them with the sleeves of meanings, and the owner of the rod and precedence to every refined word, invented meaning, and innovative simile. He has done well in places, was mediocre in places, and did badly in a state just as he did well in a state. Is he not the one saying in his B-rhyme poem:
'Do you not see that whenever I came as a night visitor / I found in her a scent even if she did not perfume herself?'
Measure this against his saying describing this woman:
'The chief of peers to her, not blameworthy / Nor possessor of a creation (body) if you contemplated, side.'
He is the one saying in it describing a horse:
'When we rode, the children of our family said / Come, until the game comes, let us gather firewood.'
This is the utmost description in confidence of the horse's precedence and his catching what he seeks. Measure this against his saying describing this horse:
'For scolding is a blaze, and for the leg is a flow of milk / And for the whip from him is the fall of a polished variegated (skin).'
He is the one who says in the L-rhyme poem describing an eagle:
'It hunts the rabbits of Al-An'am in the forenoon / And foxes or Ural (goats/sheep) have gathered from it.'
Then he said following it:
'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry / At her nest, are jujube and worn-out dates.'
How far is the difference between the two verses, and how intense the contradiction between the two speeches. And he is the one saying:
'From the mention of Layla, and where is Layla / And the best of what you sought is what is attained.'
This is of the best speech, easiest, most sturdy, most wandering as a proverb, and sweetest as a drink. And he said in the other in its manner:
'Is it from the mention of Layla when she distanced from you, you shy away / And shorten a step from her and evade.
You evade, and how many a desert is before her / And of barren land before her and thieves.'
So contemplate the disparity between the two speeches, and the distance of their station in eloquence."

I said to him: "So what defect is in this?"
He said: "By my life, there is no defect in it, but it is not like the first nor close to it."
I said to him: "Upon that, he did not mistake as you mistook, nor err as you erred."
He said: "So be it. And this is Al-Nabigha Al-Dhubyani, and a group counted him more poetic than Imru' al-Qais, and others counted him following him, and to this I went. He says in his Ayin-rhyme poem which traveled the path of the sun:
'For you are like the night that catches me / Even if I thought that the distance from you is wide.'
This is an eye of the seeing eyes of poetry, and a blaze of its high blazes. Then he said following it, so he fell below it a fall witnessed by:
'Hooks, crooked, in sturdy ropes / Hands extend with them to you, pulling.'
I said: "What is in this verse? He only went in this to the fact that he, in his power over him, is like one in whose hand are crooked hooks with which he pulls what he wishes to pull from a well or otherwise. From here the first took his saying describing a horse:
'I came to him in the morning before his birds were cancelled / My companion hiding and other than him hiding.
The wild animals do not despair of him chasing them / As if he is hung from them by a hook.'"

He said: "And among what Al-Nabigha preceded in and people followed him in is his saying:
'Except that her two anklets, even if you said they are wide / Are silent from fullness and lack of speech (sound).'
Then he said and did badly and went far:
'If she trembled, the coward feared for her earrings / And whoever hangs where it hung fears.'
Because this is proof of excessive length of the neck."

I said to him: "And what proof is in the verse of its excess and its exit from the limit of moderation approved in the likes of it? He only went to the fact that she is tall-necked, for she combined with the goodness of the neck the length of stature, so the dropping place of her earring was far because of the perfection of her creation and the length of her neck. And she trembled with an earring, so the coward among her family and whoever manages her affair of father and mother and nurse fears the loss of her earrings. So he deleted, since there remained in the speech proof of what was deleted from it." The group appreciated that.

Then he said: "This is Zuhair, and his place in skill and purification of poetry and refining of wording is the known place. He says:

'Upon their wealthy ones is a right for who comes to them / And with the poor ones is generosity and giving.
A people sought after them to overtake them / But they did not do, nor were they blamed, nor did they fall short.
Whatever good they came with, indeed / Fathers of their fathers inherited it before.
Does the spear grow anything but its bamboo / And is the palm tree planted except in its growing places?'
He said: "This is of the secret of speech and its essence. Then he said in this poem:
'So I swore earnestly by the pebbled place of Mina / And where the front parts (of heads) and lice were shaven.'
This is of the lowest and vilest wording."
I said: "There is nothing in it that is considered rough except his saying 'Al-Qaml' (Lice), and as for the rest of the meaning of that, he only ran in it on the custom of the Arabs in their oaths. And Zuhair is the sayer:
'It is equal to him any time you came to him / Is it an hour of bad luck feared or with happiness?
If praise immortalized a man, he would not die / But the praise of a man is not immortalizing.'"
He said: "And this is a noble wording that organized two wandering proverbs that traveled east and west. Then he said in it:
'Pious, pure, he did not increase spoil / By the marriage of a relative nor by a Haqlad.'
He said: "And this wording with its roughness and anxiety did not unite with what preceded of that sturdy wording in one chest."
I said: "The man only ran in his saying 'Bi Haqlad'—which is the narrow-minded, ill-natured one—according to his language and tongue. Because it is a strange word, it had to be pointed out against him to his equals. The meaning in this verse is subtle; and that is that he intended that he does not oppress a relative or a lonely one, nor does he violate his right from a spoil he witnesses with him, deeming him weak and dominating him and seizing his share to increase it for his benefactor and to save his quarter-share. So he denied from him what others stoop to."

He said: "And of his famous verses which he was not preceded to nor disputed in:
'Indeed the right, its cutting points are three / Oath, or judgment (Nifar), or proof (Jala').'
He means that rights are only established by one of these three: either an oath, or a trial, or an argument."
He said: "And in it he says:
'He chews a morsel in which there is raw meat (Anid) / It stank, so it is a disease under the flank.'
Talajlaj: You move it and do not swallow it. Anid: Did not ripen. Asallat: Smelled bad. The difference between this and what preceded is not hidden from one who attached himself to knowledge and attributed himself to its people."

I said: "I do not know a criticism on the verse more than his use of words from the language that are not wild nor abandoned. And the meaning with that is not impossible nor hybrid, so what face is there to comment on it from what has no comment in it?"

He said: "And this is Al-A'sha, the most erotic of them, the most satirical, and the most praising, and he is the sayer:
'Both your parents were a branch, a pillar / But they increased and you became decreasing.
You spend the night in the winter full, your bellies / And your female neighbors are hungry, spending the night empty.'
This is of the most satirical verse said without obscenity. And he is the sayer:
'A youth whom if the sun called, it would cast its veil / Or the traveling moon, it would cast the keys.'"

Some of those present said: "What is the meaning of 'Yunadi'?"
I said: "Sits with her in one club (Nadin), which is the council."
He said: "Then what is the meaning of 'Qina'aha' (her veil)?"
I said: "He meant her light."
He said: "Then what is his saying 'La-alqa al-Maqalida' (would cast the keys)?"
I said: "He means it would surrender beauty to him and delegate it, just as it is said: I cast my keys to so-and-so, meaning I delegated my affair to him."

Abu al-Tayyib said: "As if the words and his saying did not gather in one mind nor did a thought cast them both, for he said praising Alqama:
'Does the sun deny, the sun of the day / And the dazzling moon, the leper?'
If the word 'Al-Abras' (The Leper) were in the Book of God Almighty, it would have muddied the drink of its eloquence. And when God Almighty mentioned what He intended, He alluded to it with the best metonymy from His saying, His Name be exalted: 'White without evil (Soo').' And he also said:
'So I shot a heedless one before it from his sheep / And hit the grain of her heart and her spleen.'"
I said: "He only specified the spleen because it is a killing spot."
He said: "Suppose that is so, is not the word 'spleen' far from the words of lovers?"

Then he said: "So these prominent ones in the arenas of poetry, the forerunners to the sweet of speech and its bitter, and those on whose precedence in its types and opening of what was closed of its doors consensus has fallen, there is none of them but one has buzzed around his poetry (criticized), and who has breached excellence despite the support of his excellence. Speech does not all run on one norm, nor does it come equitable nor equal. There must be a lapse by which a mind errs, and a stumble by which a tongue slips. Who is this whose speech was consistent, or whose poetry was safe from tracking? I am not an innovation among them, and if you were fair to yourself, you would find it refuted."

I said to him: "As for what you imagined that you tracked against these four who are the knights of poetry and princes of speech, doubt has cast its shadow over all of it, and I have clarified that they are on the path of correctness in it. I argued in every verse with what, if you lent it your ear and turned your contemplation to it, you would have turned away from the sleeping place of the road and the trifles of speech and the decorations of suspicions, and known that there is no similarity between what you brought arguing with and what I attached to you. But you run the run of the unruly horse out of vanity in yourself, and throwing your ambition to where there is no ascent for it. You place it where it does not deserve to be placed and weigh it with the unjust balance to aggrandize it.

And I said: "And you have also erred in your saying:
'Go far! You went far a whiteness that has no whiteness / Indeed you are blacker in my eye than darkness (Dhulam).'
It is, despite what is in it, taken from the saying of Abu Tammam:
'He has a view in the eye, white, pure / But he is in the heart black, dark.'
So you intended these sound, noble words, and brought them in a corrupt, unsound expression. And your saying 'La-anta aswadu' (Indeed you are blacker) is an error, even if they recited:
[Missing verse fragment]"
I said: "This is a generated modern verse, not a proof. But they have recited:
'A girl in the past Ramadan / Whiter (Abyada) than the sister of Bani Ibad / Cutting the talk with oaths.'
And they mentioned the saying of Tarfa:
'As for the kings, I am today dirtier (Awsakha) than them / In honor, and whiter (Abyada) than them in the shirt of the cook.'
These are oddities that are not permitted for a modern. People with no knowledge of the essence of speech interpreted the verse of Al-Mutanabbi with a distant interpretation and said: He meant 'Indeed you, O Black one, are in my eye from the darkness.' This is a distant interpretation. How do you say 'O Black one' while he is white? The face of speech, if he intended this, was to say: 'And you, with your whiteness, are black as if you are from the blackness of darkness.' If he had gone to that and expressed it with an acceptable phrase by which understanding occurs and ambiguity vanishes, the purpose would have been correct. But he made it vague and secretive.

I said to him: "And among what you also erred in its description and fabricated from two places is your saying:
'A guest visited my head, not shy (Muhtashim) / The sword is better in action than it on the hair (Limam).'
As for the fabrication, your saying 'A guest visited my head', this is from the saying of Di'bil. Though you have left some of the meaning and did not fulfill it, because he said:
'I love gray hair since it was called a guest.'
So he named it a guest. Then he mentioned his love for it, then followed that by mentioning the cause of his love, saying:
'Like my love for the guests descending.'
Di'bil took it from the saying of the first:
'He threw down his staff and loosened his turban / And said: A guest. So I said: Gray hair? He said: Yes.'
In his saying 'and loosened his turban' is a subtle meaning, which is that he meant he is in a matter of peace not war, as the other said:
'I am the son of Jala and the climber of peaks / When I put down the turban you will know me.'
He mentioned that because he did not put down the turban in peace. And it was said he meant by his saying 'When I put down the turban', i.e., when I get angry.

And you took your saying:
'And the sword is better in action than it on the hair'
from the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'I wish the whiteness of the sword on the day I met my fate / Instead of the whiteness of gray hair, was on my parting.'

As for the error, your saying: 'Not shy (Muhtashim)', you mean 'not withdrawn/reserved'. This is contrary to what the verifiers of the people of knowledge hold; since 'Hishma' in the speech of the Arabs is anger. And the 'Hasham' of a man were named Hasham because they get angry for him."

He said: "Did not the poet say:
'I fear repeating my saying "Eat" so I shame him (Uhshimuhu) / And silence descends him from me on stinginess.'"
I said: "This is a generated modern verse, not a proof. But they have recited:
'By your life, indeed the hospitality of Abu Khubaib / Is slow of cooking, shaming (Mahshum) the eater.'
It was said: Its meaning is angering the eater because it does not satisfy him; and it was said: The eater is withdrawn from his eating. The first is the relied upon. And 'Hishma' is among what the common people placed in other than its place.

And of what you also dropped in and did badly in taking:
'The polite, the refined, the proud, the sharp / The intelligent, the curly (Ja'd), the Chief, the Hero.'
For you copied from the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'The days made peace with me when I became inviolable / By the shade of the Chief, possessor of favor.
With the polite, the refined, the virtuous, the moon / The proud, the scarred, the loyal, the hero.'
I did not think anyone would dare on this as you dared on it, for the young literature students who engage in composing poetry rise above its like.

I do not find for 'Ja'd' (curly) a way in praise either, since 'Ja'd' is the short one. He said:
'O many a curly one (Ja'd) of them, if you knew / Strikes the strike of the lank-haired, the advancing ones.
White curly ones, as if their eyes / Are kohled in the battles with darkness.'

He means 'Al-Ji'ad' the short ones. Al-Bahili mentioned that he described them with cowardice, because the coward's eye turns black in distress. And it is said: So-and-so is 'Ja'd al-Raha' (Curly of palm) if he is stingy, and he recited:
'Lank of fingertips with what is in the saddle of his companion / Curly of fingertips with what is in his own saddle, short.'
It is said: So-and-so is 'Ja'd al-Raha' if stingy, and 'Ja'd al-Khulq' if tight-natured, and 'Ja'd al-Yad' if short-fingered. The wolf is nicknamed 'Abu Ja'da' because of his curled nature. 'Sha'r Ja'd' (Curly hair) is from this. And he recited: 'Lank of fingertips...' and mentioned the verse.

And of what you took and cut off its meaning and corrupted is your saying:
'Veiling their horses with white swords, taking / The heads of warriors on their spears as tassels.'
Because heads are not likened to tassels when on spears, except if they have hair and braids, otherwise they are likened to crowns. Do you not see the saying of Abu Tammam, from whom you stole the meaning and twisted it:
'From every possessor of hair whose braids covered / The chest of the spear, so it was almost seen as a flag.'
So the hair with the tassel is a valid simile, and the head is likened to the crown so the representation is correct. Muslim bin Al-Walid said in likening them to crowns:
'He clothes the swords with the souls of the oath-breakers / And makes the heads crowns of the withered spears.'
Muslim took it from the saying of the first:
'As if the heads of the people atop our spears / When pointed, are the crowns of Khosrau and Caesar.'
Not every head has hair, and if it does not have hair or a braid, it has no share in being likened to a flag.

I said: "And you also erred in your saying, along with the weakness of your wording and the silliness of your expression:
'Possessor of high deeds, let him who ascends ascend / Thus, thus, or else no, no.'
'An honor that butts the stars with its two horns / And a might that shakes the mountains.'
For you raided in the first verse Bakr bin Al-Nattah in his saying:
'He meets the dew with a face... / And the chests of spears with a bold face.
Thus, thus are the high deeds / The paths of glory are not the paths of joking.'
Your saying 'Fala la' (Or else no, no) is very weak, and you are fond of repeating this word."
He said: "How?"
I said: "Are you not the sayer:
'The answer to my questioner: Does he have an equal? / And do you have in your question No, No, No?'

And you took the second verse from the saying of Abu Tammam and corrupted it:
'An ambition that butts the stars, and a grandfather (luck) / Familiar with the low ground, so he is low.'
He said: "And with what did I corrupt it?"
I said: "Because you made for the honor of the man two horns."
He said: "And what do you know?"
I said: "You say 'Butts the stars with its two horns (Rawqayhi)', and the Rawqan are the two horns?"
He said: "Yes, it is a metaphor."
By my life, even if it is a metaphor, it is a malicious metaphor running in the 'Mu'azala' (intercourse/obscenity) which Umar bin Al-Khattab, may God be pleased with him, denied for Zuhair, and mentioned his avoidance of it. He said: 'He did not couple (Yu'adhil) between two words', i.e., interlace the word, if one of them was not of the genus of the other, nor suitable for it nor derived from it. It is said: 'Ta'adhalat al-Jaradatan' (The two locusts coupled) if one mounted the other and interlaced in it.

And of the pleasant verses of meaning:
'They took their bows with their right hands / Coupling the coupling of ants.'
He says: The arrows ran out and the darts perished, so they took the bows with their right hands striking each other with them and fighting, and they interlaced one another like the mounting of ants and their interlacing, because shooting is only with the left. The blamed Mu'azala is the worst metaphor, as Aws bin Hajar said:
'And possessor of worn clothes, naked are her veins / She pours water on a truncated foal (Tawlab).' 
He made for the woman a 'Tawlab', and the Tawlab is the foal of a donkey, just as you made for honor two horns. This is of the furthest metaphors and most divergent from the schools of skilled poets. The speech on types of metaphor has preceded. If you lent what I say a fair ear, you would know that confronting a king of kings like Sayf al-Dawla—with the greatness of his affair, the nobility of his authority, and his encompassing the traits of generosity excluding many kings of his time—with the like of what you confronted him with of that metaphor, is of the great matters which he who has been broken in by experience and whose speech has been educated by deliberation does not undertake. Every metaphor is subtle, and necessitates eloquence of statement by reality not acting in its place, because reality, if it stood in its place, would be more worthy of it than the metaphor. Do you not see the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'And I have gone early while the birds are in their nests / With a stripped (short-haired horse), the shackle of the wild beasts, huge.'

This type of metaphor is called 'Irdaf' (Consequence/Implication); which is that the poet wants to indicate a meaning of meanings, so he does not use the word that indicates that meaning, but a word that indicates a meaning that is a consequence of it and follower to it. If the follower indicates, it indicates the followed. Such is 'Qayd al-Awabid' (Shackle of the wild beasts). That is because he wanted to describe the horse with speed and that he is excellent; if you sent him on the game, he is like the shackle for them and they were like shackled to him; that is because the nearing of his overtaking and the togetherness of his running implies that the wild beasts be like shackled to him. The reality of 'Qayd al-Awabid' is preventer of wild beasts and their confiner. 'Qayd al-Awabid' is more eloquent and better. And 'Al-Manin' was said for the captive, and it was said in describing the horse 'Qayd al-Rihan' (Shackle of bets), and it was said: The eyes are the shackle of thoughts and shackle of eyes; all of that is built on the wording of the horse.

And of metaphors is the saying of Al-A'sha:
'Indeed noble horses will visit you / Praise hung on their rumps.
With him saddle blankets are shaken off in every dwelling / And ends of ropes are tied and untied.'
Ta'abbata Sharran said:
'So he mixed with the plain of the earth; the rock did not scratch / Him a scratch, and death stood looking in shame.'
And of the innovative metaphor is the saying of Al-Hudhali:
'If I had entrusted him to the sun, there would have ascended / To him the deaths, its eye and its messenger.'
And the saying of Ibn Harma, and Ibn Harma did well, all wellness:
'So I said: Either you see me having been betrayed / By a disjointed time, with these people, overturned.
Gray hair has returned its strange camel to my head / So it has no estrangement from the scalp of the head.
My heart has dragged the surplus of its leading rope / And the white, buxom women fear my tear.'
Ibn Al-Riqa' said:
'And a painted woman, the eyes of the people borrow her / Until she returns the gaze to the possessor of fastidiousness.'

Abu al-Tayyib said: "This is all hyperbole and exaggeration and distance from reality. I see you fond of this school of poetry, excluding what its words are sound and its meanings correct upon contemplation. If something of its genus comes to you, even if false, you advance it and cancel others."

I said to him: "This is the saying of one who does not distinguish between metaphor and reality, nor between exaggeration (Ghulu) and emphasis (Mubalagha)."
He said: "Is there a difference between exaggeration and emphasis?"
I said: "All the difference. Antara said describing his horse:
'So he turned away from the fall of spears on his chest / And complained to me with a tear and a neigh.'
He made the complaining of the horse to him, since it was of the animals that speak by neighing and tearing, without speech and expression. So he did not take it out of what belongs to it. Then he revealed the meaning in the last verse and said:
'If he knew what conversation was, he would have complained / And he would have been, if he knew speech, my speaker.'
Bashar bin Burd took this meaning and did well with his saying:
'When the heat turned away and the soil squeezed / The blaze of summer from a star whose flame kindled.
And the sparrows of the anemones flew and [the earth] clothed itself / From the mirage the likes of the galaxy, its canes.
A herd began complaining with its eyes of thirst / To the wild bull, except that it does not speak.'
This is emphasis in description without deviating from reality. Similar to it is the saying of Ibn Harma describing a dog:
'He almost, when he sees the guest approaching / Speaks to him out of his love, while he is mute.'
So he paired this emphasis with 'Yakadu' (almost). So he took it out of the exaggeration that distances from reality.
Look at the saying of Al-Muthaqqib Al-Abdi in this meaning, narrating from his she-camel what is far, all distance, from reality:
'She says when I tightened her saddle girth on her / Is this his religion forever and my religion?
Is all of time settling and departing / Does he not keep me [safe] nor protect me?'
This is the exaggeration distant from reality. He only went to the idea that the she-camel, if she spoke, would have expressed her complaint with the like of this saying. Some of our companions run this and its likes in the chapter of Majaz (figurative language)."

The group present was using their pens to record the beginnings of the verses in which the dispute occurred, observing the locations of my arguments and his arguments, and proving it by symbol and suggestion. All of it was before my eyes, and like a mirror from my memory. When I rose from the gathering—and I did not rise except after I returned beautifully in addressing him, and elaborated in praising him, and in erasing the trace of his punishment, and in softening my side to him—the people followed me, desiring me to organize what happened and gather its dispersed parts, and refer to what was established in their notes of its sum, and seek help from my mind in mentioning it, and compose a treatise in whose folds I alert to his matter.

The day had spent its youth, and its hours turned gray with age, and the sun approached setting and humbled for decline. The rein of the dispute extended, and the matter of the negotiation exacerbated, so the ability did not expand in the moment to organize the treatise. I took what was proven in their pages, and returned to my house. I made the night a mount for three nights in which I did not taste sleep, until the last stars set, the flocks of darkness turned away, and the morning smiled, until the treatise was organized. I led three [nights]... keeping sleep away from my eyes until the dawn tore the shirt of darkness, and its mouth smiled in the gap of the forenoon.

The news spread and the situation became famous, and it was called out in every club. The Vizier Abu Muhammad and the Chief Abu al-Faraj Muhammad bin al-Abbas—and to him I addressed this treatise and his obeyed command in organizing it I complied with—ordered, and they are the two stars of the Kingdom and the two eyes of the State, its explanation, so I explained it. They conveyed the image to Mu'izz al-Dawla, so he was pleased in his happiness, and emphasized the recommendation of caring for me and honoring me severely.

Then the Vizier Abu Muhammad saw fit to gather us in a council, and that his review of speech and his debating him be in his presence. I am presenting that council by council in its form. For Abu Muhammad al-Muhallabi ordered two of his special scribes to record it, and emphasized the instruction to them to guard against a single thing of it escaping; so they collected that a severe collection. Among those who witnessed the situation and showed his face in supporting and alerting to the locations of my excellence in that negotiation and debate was Hibatullah bin Al-Munajjim, who is of literature such that his scene is not exited, and Ali bin Muhammad the poet known as Ibn al-Baqqal, and he has his place in virtue.

I will mention, God willing, what broke out between us, and pair it with what I attached to his work of theft and absurdity, and of hybrid wording and corrupt meaning. I will mention also the beauties of his poetry, and the eyes of his eulogies—for praise was his food and the straying (famous) of his verses—running in all of it with the truth which cannot be transgressed, fair and seeking justice from him, not decreasing his right, nor attributing to him what is not his. I will single out a book for that and exhaust it, and reach the limit that ability reaches in it, by the power of God and His strength, favor, and compassion. The treatise is completed, and praise be to God, and the favor is to God alone, and His blessings be upon our master Muhammad the Prophet and upon his family and companions and peace be upon them completely. The completion of copying it was agreed upon by the hand of the poorest of God's servants and most in need of His pardon and forgiveness, Muhammad bin Abdul Malik bin Asakir Al-Shafi'i Al-Ba'labakki, may God forgive him, on Friday the ninth of Shawwal, the year seven hundred and seventeen, praising and praying.

[The text returns to the narrative of the debate]
Abu al-Tayyib was summoned along with a group of people of knowledge. I attended the council of the Vizier Abu Muhammad al-Muhallabi and planned his discussion. He showed denial, grimness, refusal, and resistance. I softened my side to him, then I hastened him to speak and asked him about his saying:
'Is it single (Uhad) or sixfold (Sudas) in the single / Night of ours, hung on the mutual calling (Tanadi)?'
I said: "What did you intend?"
He said: "I intended: Is it one night or six nights in one night, finding it long and considering its extent far."
I said: "Yes, and I see you looked in it to the saying of the first:
'This night has become long until as if it / Is two connected nights that do not budge.'
And to the saying of the other:
'And a night that refused for the morning to shine, and the darkness / Repeated in it between an end and a beginning.
As if the pitch-black of the night is a shackled blind man / Bewildered in a wilderness of the unknown earth.
As if the darkness when it lowered its curtains / In Najd, is upon a confused, connected night.'
Adi bin Al-Riqa' said in this meaning:
'And as if my night when its sun sets / Is connected to the blackness of another like it.'
Al-Farazdaq went to this school by his saying:
'And a night of a day whose darkness outweighed / Equal to us are its length and its worries.
As if the days and the night in it are a connection / And a black darkness, pitch-black is its beast.'
Bashar did well, all wellness:
'My two friends, what is with the darkness not budging / And what is with the light of morning not becoming clear?
Did the illuminating day lose its way / Or is time all night that does not leave?'

I said: "So all of these ran on one path in lengthening the night, whether exaggerating in it or economizing, except that he did not couple to the beginning of his verse what contradicts its end and negates it, and differs from it all difference and does not imply it, like your deed. For you connected your verse with an end that spoiled it, and was far, all distance, from it; that is that you said 'Is it one night or six nights in a night'. Then you diminished (using diminutive form) according to the schools of the Arabs in diminishing the magnificent in their saying 'Duwayhiya' (Little calamity) and 'Udhayquha al-Murajjab' (Its propped little date-bunch) and 'Judhayluha al-Muhakkak' (Its rubbed little post), and as the first said:
'Above a little mountain (Jubayl), high of head, it was not / To be reached until one tires and works.'
And as the other said:
'O Mayy, may the flashing little lightning (Burayq) water you / And the pouring flowing rains.'"
He said: "To this I went."
I said: "Then you said: 'Al-Manuta bi-Tanadi' (Hung on the mutual calling), so you made it absurd."
He said: "How is that?"
I said: "How is what you imagine to be one night or six in one hung on mutual calling? You only looked in your saying 'Al-Manuta bi-Tanadi' to the saying of the poet:
'I said to my guest when I woke him / In a rainy night:
What is with me, I see the night as a last / As if it was hung (Nita) on the Hereafter (Akhirah).'
So this one made it, in its length, hung on the Hereafter, so he did not couple that with what spoiled it and distorted its meaning, nor made it absurd like your absurding of your verse until you asked the question of a doubter whether it is one night or six in a night. Then you contradicted by informing that it is hung on mutual calling. So what a difference between this questioning of yours and the saying of the other, despite the lateness of his time:
'I do not know, did my night lengthen or not / How would he know that, who is frying (in pain)?
If I were free to measure the length of my night / And to tend the stars, I would be empty (carefree).'
As if you did not hear the saying of Suwayd bin Abi Kahil:
'And when I said my night has passed / The first of it turned and returned.'
Khalid bin Yazid imitated this meaning and said:
'The morning distanced until I do not hope for it / And worry increased so its departure is not hoped for.
And the night is a stop upon us, not leaving us / As if every time of it is a beginning.'
This is better than the saying of the other, even if his time preceded:
'There is no end to the night / From which a lover recovers.
The end of the night is a beginning / No rising sun is seen in it.'
Because he made its end a beginning, and Khalid made every time of its times a beginning. Similar to these two verses is the saying of Al-Hasan bin Ziyad Al-Rusafi:
'O night that lengthened upon a lover / Waiting in the morning for an appointment.
It almost became the Resurrection in its length / When its beginning passed, it returned.'
This is the utmost in its meaning and it has an addition by his saying 'waiting in the morning for an appointment'. Although the saying:
'You slept and did not pity the sleepless / And the night of the lover has no end'
is very innovative, preceding much of what was said about the length of the night. As if this is from the saying of Al-Yaqtini:
'I say to it when its darknesses anchored / I lost you as a night, you have no end.'

It was reported to me afterwards that he changed the verse or some of his faction changed it, so he made it 'Al-Manuta bi-Tanadi' and said its meaning is the people called each other for departure. This is a very weak saying, and a meaning with no benefit.

And you said in this poem of yours:
'As if the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major) in its darkness / Are virgins (Khara'id) unveiled in mourning clothes (Hidad).'
There is no relation for the 'Khara'id' (virgins) among women excluding others with this simile; since the Kharida is the shy one and Kharad is shyness. The stars in the darkness are not more appropriate in resemblance to virgins in black, than to those with shyness among women. You only said 'Khara'id' so the place would be confused and the taking hidden, because Ibn Al-Mu'tazz said:
'As if the stars of the horizon in the coal of darkness / Are the faces of virgins (Adhara) in black sheets.'
He said: "What is the reason for specifying 'Adhara' (virgins) instead of 'Awan' (middle-aged)?"
I said: "Because the virgin is distinguished from the middle-aged by the abundance of the water of the face, its freshness, and the delicacy of its skin; therefore they said 'virgin pearl', not pierced, and 'virgin garden', not sown, and 'virgin wine', not broached. Therefore they named wine 'virgin', if it was not deflowered by mixture or not broached from a jar, as Al-Akhtal said:
'Virgin, the suitors did not unveil its joy / Nor did a Christian unveil it for a Dinar.'
Ibn Al-Mu'tazz said:
'And the two bright stars (Farqadan) gazed at me as if / A blue-eyed woman looking from a black veil.'
He also said:
'And I see the Pleiades in the sky as if / A foot appeared in clothes of mourning.'
So he managed the meaning well and emphasized it, and you did badly in taking it.

And in this rhyme you say:
'May God reward the march to him with good / Even if it left the mounts like water-skins (Mazad).'

He only meant that the march wore out their bodies and betrayed their fatness. You went to liken them to old, dried water-skins, but you could not fulfill the simile, and the material fell short with you, so you limited yourself to mentioning 'Al-Mazad' (water-skins), and not every water-skin is worn out or dried. You only looked to the saying of the Rajaz poet:
'As if she, and the trap is like the dried skins (Shanan) / Sways in a purple suit.'
'Al-Shanan' are the dry water-skins, and this is a correct simile, and your verse which you stole from it is corrupt and sick. If you had brought the description, it would have indicated the described. But to bring the noun which contrasting descriptions take turns on, it does not indicate by mere mention what you intended of its description. Do you not see the saying of Abu al-Najm describing camels:
'Walking from the return the walk of the filled (clouds) / The walk of the water-carrying camels with the heavy water-skins.'
He did not limit himself to mentioning the water-skins until he described with a description of condition that took the simile out of the ugliness of separation.

Then I said: And in these words you say:
'He cheered up before my greeting to him / And threw [money] before the pillow.'
I think the first one followed your trace in this meaning and said:
'Times I approached him, he did not but / Smile laughing and fold the pillow.'

And of your virgin meanings in it is your saying:
'So my thoughts are I praised them of old / And you, by what I praised them, are my intent.'
As if Abu Nuwas heard this and said:
'Even if the words ran with a praise / To other than you, [you are] the human we mean.'
Although Kuthayyir bin Abdul Rahman had said:
'Whenever I say in the end of time a praise / It is only for the son of Layla the Honored.'

Then I said: In this word you say, and lengthen and boast and attack and imagine that the meaning is unsaid:
'As if the heads in the battle are eyes / And your swords were printed from sleep.'
'And you formulated the spearheads from worries / So they do not cross except in a heart.'
Glory be to Him who humiliated the necks of speech for you, and smoothed its shoulders and gathered its dispersed parts, and led meanings to you by their reins, until you invented from them what the thoughts of those who preceded you of the knights of poetry and princes of verse and prose fell short of. These two verses are from the saying of some Syrians:
'He imagined the heads as pupils, his sharp swords / Between their eyelids were crafted from slumber.
They top working (spears) that were aimed out of fear / They travel by stabbing from him the path of the clever.'
Some of those present said, and I think it was Abu Ali Al-Hussein bin Muhammad Al-Anbari, and his inclination was with him: "These two verses are fabricated, artificial, their sayer is not known."
I said: "Then you make the likes of them and let them be." He took the first verse of his two verses from the saying of Mansur Al-Namari:
'The bloods reminded with its luster, as if / It tops the men with bright clusters (of dates).
And as if the numbness of the sharp sword in his head / Is the numbness of death or the drowsiness of the sleeper.'
As for his saying: 'And you formulated the spearheads' to the end, it is from the saying of Al-Buhturi describing a wolf, and it is of the best that was said:
'And a dust-colored one filling the eye, dividing his chest / And his ribs from his two sides is a high roasting (hunger).
Hunger folded him until his rope became bitter / There is nothing in him but bone, spirit, and skin.
He rose to me, and in me from the intensity of hunger is what is in him / In a desert where no comfortable life is felt.
So I fed him a clumsy (arrow/spear) considering its feathers / On a shooting star and the night is black.
And I followed it with another, so I delivered its blade / Where the core (heart) and terror and hatred are.'
Al-Buhturi took this from the saying of Abu Tammam:
'From every blue (spear), looking without a look / To the killing spots, there is no crookedness in its wood.
As if it was the dust (peer) of love for a time / So no heart nor liver incapacitates it.'
He took it from the saying of Amr bin Ma'adi Karib:
'And the strikers with every white sharp sword / And the stabbers of the gathering places of grudges (hearts).'

Abu al-Tayyib said: "Who are Abu Tammam and Al-Buhturi? I do not know that I heard their mention except from this presence."
I said: "Abu Tammam and Al-Buhturi whose words you snatched, and whose meanings you annexed, and you fell short of them the falling of the arrow falling short of its target."

Then I said: "And you erred in your saying:
'She got angry for him when I saw his descriptions / Without a describer, and poetry, its non-Arabs (Tamatim) rave.'
Because raving (Hadhayan) is the speech of the senile and the sick, and one possessed by a specter of madness. The raver and the rave are of the blamed descriptions as the first said:
'Raver, rave, much raving / Prone to slip, possessor of a scattered mind.'

And 'Al-Tamtama' is the speech of the foreigner which is not understood. It is said: A Tumtum foreigner and Tumtumani, if his speech is not understood. Antara said:
'The young camels of Al-Nu'man shelter to him as sheltered / Groups of Yemeni (camels) to a stammering foreigner.'
So you made your poetry and its struggling in your chest and its creeping on your tongue and what its instinct granted you, in the status of the speech of the raver and the stammering foreigner whose speech is not understood. There is no good in what is of this way. The face of speech was that you say: And poetry, its current heaves, its deep water boils, its sea rages, and its rhymes envy each other in his praise. This speech is as Abu Tammam said:
'Poetry envied each other regarding him when I stayed up for him / Until I thought his rhymes would fight.'
But the rhyme forced you to what disgraced the speech and corrupted its meaning and turned it from correctness.

He turned to me and said: "Be fair, for the fair one is he who distinguishes. And look closely, the looking of one whose foot has advanced in knowledge, and to whose virtue pointing has occurred. And do not let passion rule over opinion."
I said: "Speak."
He said: "I only run on the path of the prominent poets in excellence and invention of meanings. So if the paths of creativity are obscure, I run on the manner of those who preceded me in tracking the trace and observation and looking. I do not absolve my mind, even if correctness acts by it on its path, from a slip that passes me and a stumble I intend."

I said to him: "Is it from your inventions, your saying describing your sandal:
'Neither does my she-camel carry the pillion rider nor / With the whip on the day of the bet do I exhaust her.
Her strap is her saddle and her lip (Mashfar - camel lip) / Is her rein and the thong is her leading rope.'
He said: "Is this not invented?"
I said: "Yes, and it is invented for Abu Nuwas in his saying:
'To you, O Abu al-Abbas, whoever walked / Upon them, we rode the tongued Hadrami (sandals).
Young camels that did not carry a yearning pillion / Nor did they know the knocking of the stallion nor the tar.'
Your saying 'Naqati' (My she-camel) is from the saying of Abu Nuwas 'Qala'is' (Young she-camels). You increased the meaning and saturated it in the second verse and left from the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'Young camels that did not carry a yearning pillion / Nor did they know the knocking of the stallion nor the tar.'
And you added that you do not exhaust it with the whip, and that her strap is her saddle, and her rein is her lip, and the thong is her leading rope.

And from your invented meanings is your saying:
'Sharp of heart, prudence shows him tomorrow / With his heart what his eyes see after tomorrow.'
This is from the saying of Duraid bin Al-Simma, meaning and wording:
'He sees the consequences of opinion and the matter is approaching / As if he has in today an eye on tomorrow.'
The other said:
'He becomes with the consequences of matters as if / The consequences of every matter speak to him.'
Al-Mutanabbi repeated this meaning in another place and did not express it well, saying:
'Deriving from his knowledge what is in tomorrow / And as if what will be in it is recorded.'
And the first of this meaning is the saying of Aws bin Hajar:
'The brilliant one who thinks the thought of you / As if he has seen and has heard.'

And in the word Al-Mutanabbi says:
'When you returned from the coasts towards us / Loneliness returned to them from us.'
He only took it from the saying of Al-Buhturi:
'Prince Muhammad departed, so departed / From us the juice of this bliss.'

And similar to this, your inventions, is your saying:
'Whenever I increased after the limit / My decrease fell (occurred) as an increase.'
This is transferred from the saying of Mahmud:
'Fast in the decrease of a man is his completion / His days turn back in his advancing.'
Ibn Al-Rumi expressed this meaning well and said:
'Times snatch him while they are his growth / And foods assassinate him while they are a bait for him.
If you see a thing whose age wears it out / And corrupts that it remains, then in its disease is sterility.'
This meaning looks a look at the saying of Hamid bin Thaur Al-Hilali:
'I see my sight has disturbed me after health / And it is enough of a disease for you that you are healthy and safe.'
And Hamid in it has a look at the saying of Al-Namir:
'The youth desires length of safety striving / So how do you see the length of safety doing?'

If you wished, you would have refrained from exposing yourself to what is this way, especially since you are a target for every accidental arrow, an opportunity for every opportunist. What do you do with your saying:
'I saw the horn of the sun in the moon of darkness / Swaying, a branch in him sways.'
With the saying of Muslim:
'Slender-waisted, in her hair is a night, over a moon / On a rod, on a dune of the sandy hill, reddish.
As if my heart is her two sashes when she strutted / And her heart is her heart in silence and dumbness.'

'Her love runs in the heart of her lover / The running of safety (health) in the limbs of a relapsing one.'

I said: "And among what you stole and corrupted is your saying:
'Ha! So look or think of me, you will see burnings / Whoever did not taste a tip of them has surely failed.'
'Perhaps the Prince sees my humiliation so he intercedes for me / To her who left me in passion a proverb.'
That is because you exposed the Praised One to pimping, by your hoping for him to be an intercessor for you to the one you love. This is of the ugliest exit and silliest meaning a poet undertook in addressing a praised one. You only imitated in it the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'If my Lord willed, He would afflict them with what He afflicted us with / So they would be neither against us nor for us.
I will complain to Al-Fadl bin Yahya bin Khalid / Your love, perhaps Al-Fadl will unite us.'
Abu Nuwas only went in directing this to seeking the giving of the Praised One and his aid, or marrying her if she was free. His saying in the last verse indicated that:
'A prince, I saw wealth in his moods / Humiliated, insulted of soul by oppression, submissive.
If the Lord of Wealth is stingy, his generosity calls / Come to the wealth of the Prince, and makes the call to prayer.'
This is further clarified by his saying in this word, mentioning a man he pointed to regarding the debt as a loan and the buying of this slave girl:
'He sees Al-Fadl has sworn to plunder his money / And the idiot asks me to be a scout.
O Fadl, perceive my youthful love with its dust / For there is no good in my love if it commits adultery.'
This is a clear proof."

Abu al-Tayyib said: "So I imitated a meaning and two meanings and three of Abu Nuwas, and he is the Imam of the moderns, so what of it?"
I said: "And of your leaning on him and falling short of him is his saying:
'Indeed kings saw your father with eyes / Kohled for them with the kohl-sticks of aggrandizement.'
So you said:
'You know in his eye his truths / As if he is kohled with intelligence.'
And from this is the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'He understood the suggestion and the whistling / And the revealing, whether you gesture or signal.'
So you transferred it and said:
'And her discipline is the length of the chase, so his glance / Signals to her from afar and she understands.'
And Abu Nuwas said:
'To a youth whose mother's walker forever / Strives with a pocket torn among people.'
So you said and did well:
'A king, if his treasuries become full one day / He makes them taste the taste of the mother's bereavement of the child.'
And Abu Nuwas said:
'And if the mounts reach Muhammad with us / Their backs are forbidden to men.'
So you said, and did not observe the looting of meaning and wording:
'And the excuse of the free men, her back became / Except to you, upon me a forbidden vulva.'
He said: The first who realized this meaning was Al-Farazdaq by his saying:
'I say to my she-camel when she reached me / You have become to me by oath
Forbidden to the nose-reins and the saddle-pads / And the straps of the saddle and the girth.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'He weeps and sheds tears from his eye / And slaps the rose with jujube.'
So you took it and said:
'She looks at you with the eye of a gazelle, ready to cry / And wipes the dew over the rose with the Anam (fingertips/red tree).' 
The first who looked at this meaning was Al-Muraqqish, for he said:
'The scent is musk and the faces are Dinars / And the tips of the palms are Anam.'
Omar bin Abi Rabi'a said, and did well:
'Coming from the bottom of the winding valley with Yemeni / Sheets, lifting the tail of the clouds.
With palms as if they are pieces of snow / Their tips are of jujube.'
Some moderns said:
'From the palm of a girl as if her fingertips / Are of silver tipped with jujube.
As if her right hand, when she clicks with it / Casts a calculation upon her left hand.'
Abu Tammam said:
'They said "Departure", so she stuck her nails / In her cheek while they had caught dye.
So it turned green under her fingertips, so as if she / Planted jujube in a land of violet.'
Al-Mu'alla Al-Tai did well, all wellness, by his saying:
'She gifted a peace to my heart, stealing / From the eye of the watcher with soft fingertips like Anam.
As if she orally told me in her signal / To me: A jujube topped a pen.'
The poet from Jabal al-Summaq said:
'They said: Departure is tomorrow forenoon or after it / So they slapped with jujube and pens.'
Al-Buhturi said, and changed the expression:
'She revealed her fingertips so she showed us / Gold of her dye in silver.'
Al-Nashi' the Mutakallim said, and did well, all wellness:

'Embracing, concealing their passion / Blame slept between them so it became good.
Exchanging the glance from their eyelids / As if they are studying a book.
When the eye of the watcher was inadvertent, their palms / Snatched the snatch of peace, robbing.
With fingertips from him appearing like oil-pots / And fingertips from her clothed in dye.
As if she picks for him from his palm / Grapes, and he picks for her jujube.
