She feared the eyes of the slanderers so she turned away / Biting the jujube with hail (teeth) out of anger.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'They said: You have done well. So I said: I / Found speech enabled me, so it was good.'
So you said:
'I am not alone who said this whole poetry / But my poetry has poetry from itself.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'You see its light from the outside of the cup appearing / Upon you even if you covered it with a cover.'
So you took it a curious taking and transferred it to praise, so you said:
'When he appeared, his awe veiled your eye / And nothing veils him if he veils himself.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'So reveal the name of whom you love and leave me nicknames / There is no good in pleasures which have a curtain before them.'
So you said:
'Love is what prevented speech the tongues / And the sweetest complaint of a lover is what he declared.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'Indeed I am a rebuker of the glance of the eye with the eye / For almost no conscience is hidden from me.'
So you said:
'More seeing than Zarqa (of Yamama) is the atmosphere of my familiarity / When my eyes look, my knowledge willed both.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'If the Lord of Wealth is stingy, the dress of his generosity / Calls: Come to the money of the Prince, and makes the call to prayer.'
So you said:
'And Dew called to the sleepers away from Dew / So he made them hear: Stinginess has perished.'

And Abu Nuwas said:
'So it left me no flesh and left me no blood.'
So you said:
'And a phantom of a body, passion did not leave for it / Flesh so sickness dissolves it, nor blood.'

Then I said to him: "Does this satisfy you from Abu Nuwas and in him, or shall I increase you?"
He said: "Increase if you wish or decrease. Does not your Abu Nuwas, whom you announce my theft from, have an example in others? He is the one saying:
'And her love enters every heart / Entrances that wine does not penetrate.'
He only took it from the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'Two eyes, God said: Be, so they were / Doing in the minds what wine does.'
And he is the one who says:
'And a tent of a guard on a high peak / The hands of whoever sought it intended slipping.
As if we are at it between the sides of an ostrich / Its chest shunned a dwelling and a resting place.'
He only imitated the saying of Jarir:
'We shaded in the garden of Arak as if / At a horse facing the wind, fasting.
Whiter (blazed) than the piebald horses, hurt by / The harm of mosquitos except what he protected with the legs.'

I said to him: "Jarir only intended that the fluttering of the wind in the hem resembles a horse kicking with his leg when the mosquito bites him, and he mentioned a tent made of clothes of different colors, therefore he likened it to the piebald horse. The verse of Abu Nuwas is not of this nor resembling it."

He said: "And Al-A'sha said:
'With a brave one, taking judgment over time / So from whatever time brings he is fearful (cautious).'
Abu Nuwas took this:
'It circulated among youths to whom time submitted / So nothing befalls them except what they willed.'"
I said to him: "If he took it from Al-A'sha, he surely did well in it. If fairness occurs, you know that the verse of Abu Nuwas is more noble in wording, sweeter in expression, more revealing in meaning, and has an addition by his saying: 'Time submitted to them'."

He said: "Al-A'sha has said:
'And you think them dead when / The spirit, the wine, walks in them.'
Abu Nuwas took it and said:
'If the Pole (star) does not drag them, we died / And in their rotations is resurrection for us.'
He said: In the verse of Abu Nuwas is an addition, which is his saying: 'And in their rotations is resurrection for us'. This is more appropriate to the saying of Al-Akhtal, which is:
'We stayed in it being given the extract of coffee / Our joints die from it then resurrect.'"

He said: "He is the sayer:
'Ask the two coming from Hakaman / How they left Abu Uthman.
They say to me: Jinan, as pleased you / In her state; so ask about Jinan.'
This is taken from the saying of the first:
'And asking about the riders, all of them / So Hassan bin Zaid hears her question.'"

Then he said: "Likewise his saying:

'The rose reminded me of the scent of a human / Whom I remember at every basil.
If it diffuses, I do not control weeping, and when / It appears, the drinking companion almost announces my death.'
This is taken from the saying of Malik bin Asma:
'Indeed I have at every breath of a garden / Of roses or of jasmine.
A look and a turning, I hope / That you have settled in what follows us.'"

Then he said: "Shall I increase you or is it enough?"
Abu Muhammad, may God have mercy on him, said: "Rather, it is enough. In some of what you negotiated there is sufficiency from others. And your place, O Abu al-Tayyib, is not unknown."

He rose from his seat and Abu al-Tayyib rose to leave. We tarried at the Vizier's house, so he called for drink and we were called, and he prevented the presence of music. He began reviewing what happened, repeating his glance on it, and reviewing me about it. Among his care in the moment for me, and his honoring of me, was his gift, as his generous habit never ceased to run.

The Chief has known the condition of Abu Ali Al-Hussein bin Muhammad Al-Anbari in his deputizing for Al-Muhallabi in the ministry, his relation by marriage to him through his daughter, and the kindness of his position with him, what I have no need to elaborate on mentioning, because it is news that traveled further and remained as a landmark and trace. Al-Muhallabi, with that, showed him without his mirror (showed him falsely) an aggrandizement of his worth, and a magnifying of his affair, and an estimation that there is literature and virtue by which he is distinguished from others of his peers. He was not researching his plagiarism, but they are verses he presents, and words he deceives with, preserving them harvested from scrolls and picked from the backs of books. I did not let him swallow his spit (did not give him respite), rejecting much of what he presented, and deviating from the face he sought and intended. That angered him, and affected his soul an effect his left hand ceased not to speak of.

When the meeting with Abu al-Tayyib occurred after his departure, he chose verses from his poetry whose meanings he was unique in and was the first to invent. He (Al-Anbari) conspired with him to aid against me, and promised him to schedule a meeting with me and surprise me with those verses, forcing me to submit to them and admit his precedence to them, a promise he saved for an appointed day. He suggested to Abu Muhammad the summoning of Abu al-Tayyib, so he summoned him. I was accompanying the presence of Abu Muhammad in the assemblies of his gathering and his privacy, and specialized with him every specialization.

Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi, Ali bin Isa al-Rummani, Abu al-Fath, Abu al-Hasan al-Ansari the theologian, and others of the notables of the people of knowledge and those pointed to in literature were corresponded with. So a group attended, among whom was Ali bin Harun, turning to Abu al-Tayyib saying:
"Are you not the sayer:
'I prepared for the treacherous ones swords / That cut (Tajda'u) from them necks (Tulan) and noses (Anafa).'
Who are these 'treacherous ones' for whom you prepared these swords? And what is the meaning of your saying: 'That cut (Tajda'u) from them necks and noses'? Necks are for swords, and noses are cut (Ijtida') with razors." He began repeating this saying while Abu al-Tayyib turned away from him.

Al-Muhallabi turned to Abu Sa'id and said: "What do you say about that? Is it permissible, palatable, eloquent from the speech of the Arabs? Our companions have recited verses like it."
He turned to Ali bin Isa al-Rummani, who said: "The matter is as he said, and the estimation is: Cut noses and sever necks."
He turned to me, so I said: "Like the saying of the first:
'You see him as if God cuts his nose / And his two eyes if his master returns to him abundance.'
He meant cuts his nose and gouges his eyes. And like it:
'I fed her straw and gave her cold water to drink.'
Similar to it is the saying of Tarfa:
'And she smiled revealing a dark-lipped mouth as if camomiles / Interspersed the heat of the sand, a dune with dew.
And a face as if the sun cast its veil / Upon it, pure of color, not hardened.'
He meant: She reveals a face. Except that Abu al-Tayyib [mentioned] the cutting (Jad') for necks then followed it with noses. Had he put noses first then followed it with necks, it would have been carried on the like of what we mentioned."

Al-Muhallabi turned to Abu al-Tayyib as if seeking his speech. Abu al-Tayyib said, and did not add a witness to this:
"This is like the saying of the other:
'Drinker of milk and ghee and dried curd.'"
I said: "This is as we mentioned just now: drinker of milk and eater of ghee and dried curd; and the objection stands as is, unless you carry the cutting (Jad') for necks on metaphor for it."

Abu Sa'id said: "Carrying speech on advancement and delay is common as God Almighty said: 'O Mary, be devout to your Lord and prostrate and bow with those who bow.' He means, and God knows best, bow and prostrate, so He began with prostration by advancement and delay."

Then Ali bin Harun turned to him and said: "Tell me, are you a Muslim when you say:
'The best signs of the Tihami (Prophet) is that / He is your father, and one of what he has of virtues.'
And when you say:
'And all that God has created / And what He has not created.
Is despised in my ambition / Like a hair of my parting.'
And when you say:

'They sip from my mouth sips / Which are sweeter in it than Tawhid (Monotheism).'
Then he whispered to me and said: "Inform me, by God, tell me that the gums of his teeth are rotten and his breath smells bad," making me laugh. Abu al-Tayyib did not mention an answer to this, so I wanted to calm his apprehension and said: "How beautiful is what Al-Majnun said:
'And I, when I pray, turn towards her / With my face, even if the prayer-place is behind me.'
Then he corrected this saying:
'I have no polytheism, but her love / Is like the bone of choking, wearying the treating doctor.
I pray, so I do not know when I remembered her / Did I pray two for Duha or eight?'"
Abu al-Tayyib said: "In this is a subtle meaning." I said: "He used not to count what he prayed due to preoccupation with her love, so he counted the Rak'ahs; if he counted two, his two fingers extended, so he imagined them eight." Al-Muhallabi found this answer witty and the attendees appreciated it, and Abu al-Tayyib smiled at me.

Abu Ali Al-Anbari called for a scroll from his inkwell holder and said: "Speak on these meanings, and contemplate the excellence of this man in them and his precedence to them." He turned to me, the scroll in his hand, and said: "You are the one pointed to in memory, so mention what you have, and let the group mention what occurs to it, or let us surrender the goal of precedence to Abu al-Tayyib."
I said: "I speak on the condition that no one else interrupts my speech, for the crowding of speech is a misleader of understanding. Or let someone else speak on the condition of surrendering to me the prime of speech and its heels."

The group sought rest in me, and Abu Ali Al-Anbari began saying: "What do you have regarding his saying:
'And a waist the sights fix in / As if upon it is a belt of pupils.'"
The group began to appreciate it. He turned to me and said: "Speak." I said: "Good." He said: "Is it not a virgin (original)?" I said: "No! How can it be virgin when Bashar bin [Burd] says:
'Crowned with eyes / They knocked on us and left whispering.
So they hit from the novelty of conversation / A pleasure and returned smooth.
Houris who shine when they adorn / And when unadorned, they fear an evil eye (Nafsan).'
His saying: 'Crowned with eyes' is the verse, and that is the meaning. He says: If they appear, onlookers turn their eyes to them for their beauty, so as if they are crowned with eyes. 'And returned smooth', meaning they did not commit a suspicious act. And his saying: 'If they adorn', i.e., wear jewelry, they do not wear it for their beauty, but wear it as a charm, because they are dispensed of decoration by their beauty. Likewise his saying: 'And if they are unadorned, they fear an evil eye', he says: They fear the eye, so they repel the eye with jewelry. Ibn al-Rumi stole this meaning:
'She wears jewelry made for her as a charm / Not decoration, but in her is sufficiency from that.'
Abu Ja'far... Al-Masri said in the first meaning mentioning eyes insisting on looking at a person:
'Nailed upon him, not uprooting.'"

Ibn Al-Anbari said: "What do you say about his saying:
'Favors resided in necks for him / They are the collars and the people are the pigeons.'
Is this not invented?" I said: "No, rather it is from the saying of Ibn al-Rumi:
'If they are praised, they are not attributed the virtue of others / And are collars attributed to the ash-colored pigeons?'
Ibn al-Rumi imitated in it the saying of Muhammad bin Hazim Al-Bahili:
'It refused for me to prolong poetry, my sufficiency / To the meaning and my knowledge of correctness.
So I send them four and six / In refined, sweet words.
And they, if I brand a people with them / Are like the collars of pigeons on necks.
And they, even if I stay, are traveling / Narrators exchange them with the riders.'
Ibn Hazim imitated in it the saying of Al-Farazdaq:
'Whoever is fearful of the harm of my poetry / Banu Haram have been safe from satire.
They led their fool and feared / Necklaces like the collars of pigeons.'
The origin in this is the saying of Hassan bin Thabit, and a man quarreled with him, so he said: Go away, otherwise I will collar you with the collar of the pigeon."

Abu Muhammad said: "What do you say about his saying:
'Suffice it for my body as emaciation that I am a man / Were it not for my addressing you, you would not see me.'
Is it invented?" I said: "No, this is from two verses Muhammad [bin] Yahya recited to us:
'When I wore out from passion / I feared eyes lest they see me.
Were it not for my speech, the eye of the sitter / Would not have been guided to my place.'
This meaning looks to Abu Nuwas:
'Poetry of a living one came to you from the utterance of a dead one / He became a pause between life and death.
The accidents of time pared him until / He almost hid from the eyes of accidents.
If you contemplated me to verify my face / You would not clarify a letter from the book of my face.
And you would have returned the glance of your eye in a body / Which repulsion pared until it was effaced.'

Al-Muhallabi said: "I do not think anything better than this was said about emaciation." I said: "Yes, Al-Majnun:
'If what you left of me were hung / On a stick of Thumam, its stick would not bend.'
And Kuthayyir did not do badly in his saying:
'I carried on her what, if a pigeon / Carried it, she would fly with it in the winds.
Straps and thongs and the bones of an emaciated one / Whom the length of passion and autumns harmed.'
I said: "And the saying of Omar bin Abi Rabi'a preceded people:
'Little on the back of the mount is his shade / Except what the embroidered cloak denied from him.'
And the saying of Ibn al-Dumayna is appreciated:
'Bones which longing pared until as if they are / Curved sticks of Nab' tree having no bowstring.
They are not dead, nor do they rise with me / Nor does a bird fill itself from what is on them.'
Bashar said:
'Between my clothes is an emaciated body / If the wind blew it, it would fall.'
He also said:
'Indeed in my two garments is an emaciated body / If you leaned on it, it would collapse.'
This pleased Abu Muhammad a severe pleasing, and he said: "I did not think anyone preceded Abu al-Tayyib to a meaning evidenced by the advanced. What do you do with his verse, driven as I informed the Vizier of it, and each one of these has in this a meaning in which no one shared with him."

Al-Anbari said: "If he was preceded to meanings in what we mentioned, he was not preceded to his saying:
'And a visitor (fever), as if she has modesty / She does not visit except in sleep.
I offered her the velvet and mattresses / She loathed them and spent the night in my bones.
When she separates from me, she washes me (sweat) / As if we are secluded on a forbidden thing (sin).'

I said to him: "His state in this is worse than in what preceded, for he relied on the saying of Ibn al-Qa'qa':
'And a visitor without appointment came to me / And intervened between my body and the heart.
A spearhead for deaths, if she appeared / My soul and deaths are in a chase.
As if my limbs, when she separated from me / Are springs drawing from the morning clouds.'
I said: "And you made an absurdity in your saying:
'When she separated from me, she washed me / As if we are secluded on a forbidden thing.'
While the Halal (lawful) is more worthy of washing and more specific than the Haram (unlawful). So how did you specify the Haram with a description in which others share, and it has a specificity above its specificity?"
Abu al-Tayyib said: "I brought one of them, so it indicated the other even if I did not mention it. In the Quran: 'Garments protecting you from the heat', and they protect from the cold. The poet said:
'So do not count lying promises / The winds of summer blew with them without me.'
He means and the winds of winter."

When he cracked with the argument, the morning cracked the cloak of darkness. I feared he might delude the Vizier Abu Muhammad that I had no knowledge of what he mentioned. I said: "Yes, but your saying is somewhat far from this, even if you follow its path. Because the Halal is more strictly specific to washing than the Haram, and garments are not more specific in protecting from heat than in protecting from cold, nor are the winds of winter more specific in their blowing without promises than the winds of summer. Although some of our companions mentioned that he specified the winds of summer because they are more effacing." Al-Muhallabi liked this objection.

I said: And like the verse is the saying of the other:
'I do not know, when I intended a direction / Wanting good, which of them follows me.'
He said: "Which of them", he only mentioned one, because he indicated the second, then followed that by saying:
'Is it the good which I seek / Or the evil which seeks me?'
People of meanings (rhetoric) discussed the saying of Aws bin Hajar:
'And changed her from our connection, gray hair, indeed it / Is an intercessor to the white beautiful women, tested.'
Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Yahya Tha'lab said: The Ha in 'Innahu' refers to youth, and that is permissible even if he did not mention it, because gray hair indicates it. This is the saying of Ibn al-A'rabi. Al-Asma'i said: He means that he grew old so she became familiar with him.

Abu al-Tayyib said: "To God belongs your goodness, for the best speech is what your tongue uttered."
Al-Anbari said: "He has said:
'I see that nearness became turning away / And the long greeting became brevity.
You left me today in confusion / I die times and live times.
If people were from their time / They would be the darkness and I the day.'
And he said:
'I march to his cutting (iqta') in his clothes / At the edge of it from his house with his sword.'
And he said:
'Until when the greed of the blamer / And there is no opinion in love for the wise.
It is wanted from the heart to forget you / And nature refuses against the mover.'
He recited verses among which was:

'If what passed pleases you / Then a return to Homs in the coming (year).
For the polished sword with which / You killed is in the hand of the killer.'

Abu al-Tayyib said: "Is my excellence in these verses out of badness, if there was any, in others?"
I said: "I do not know excellence for you, nor do I admit invention for you, if these verses which you imagine you are the forerunner to their meanings and the lord of excellence in them are stolen, pasted. In what preceded of their composition and what their authors initiated of their meanings is a distraction from repeating them and changing their words. It has been said:
'But she wept before me, so weeping excited / For me her weeping, so I said the merit is to the precedent.'

As for your saying:
'I see that nearness became turning away'
It is from the saying of some moderns:
'She approached then turned away for a sin / My father is ransom for one whose nearness returned as distance.'

As for your saying:
'I die times and live times'
It is from the saying of Al-Abbas bin Al-Ahnaf:
'By my life, the slanderers have made / Between me and you a kindling fire.
And my soul, hung on hope / Dies times and lives times.'

And your saying:
'They would be the darkness and I the day'
It is from the saying of the other:
'White, in her cheek is redness / Her neighbors, the short ones, fault her.
They are the nights and she is the day.'

And your saying:
'I march to his cutting (iqta') in his clothes...'
Is from the saying of Ahmad bin Abi Tahir:
'If I were of the children of Yahya I would not / Have increased, even if his father were my father.
From his wealth is my wealth, and from his status / Is my status, and from his mount is my mount.'
And Ahmad bin Abi Tahir took it from an old poet:
'My flesh and what was mixed with flesh of my blood / And my status and value are from your wealth and money.
If my utterance did not undertake thanks / My right hand would inform of what you gave me and my left.
And my skin and bone and joints told of it / And my slave and my palfrey and the freshness of my state.'
You also took his saying 'And my skin told of it' so you said:
'My skin admitted them against me, so I / Cannot, until death, deny them.'
The origin in that meaning is the saying of Al-Nabigha Al-Dhubyani:
'Indeed my old property, if I look, and my weapons / And my colt and what the fingers close on.
Are your gift, and the white camels as if / The white oryx, the saddles rush upon them.'

And your saying:
'If he does not seek refuge for his glory with defects'
Is from the saying of Kushajim:
'People stared at your beauty, so seek refuge / From the evil of their eyes with one defect.'

And your saying:
'With splitting of hearts not splitting of pockets (clothes)'
Is from the saying of a Bedouin:
'And short of what I meet of the pain of passion / Hearts are split, nay pockets are split.
When we looked at the watcher and his glance / And the lucky one over the glance of the watcher is a watcher.'

And your saying:
'And there is no opinion in love for the wise'
Is from the saying of the first:
'There is no youth among people whose affair is praised / Found but that he is in love a fool.'

And your saying:
'And nature refuses against the mover'
Is from the saying of the first:
'And how can I leave, O son of the mother of natures.'
And the other said:
'Affectation falls short of nature.'

And your saying:
'For the polished sword with which / You killed is in the hand of the killer.'
Is from the saying of Amr bin Al-Ahtam:
'For the Rudayni (spear) solid of knots / If you return in the darkness of the friend, returns.'

What I cited dazzled him and restricted his speech. Al-Muhallabi admired that all admiration. Al-Anbari said: "To God belongs Abu al-Tayyib in his saying:
'Thus the days decreed among their people / Calamities of a people are benefits to a people.'
I said: "Rather to God belongs the goodness of Abu al-Atahiya in his saying:
'The death of some people in the earth / Is upon others victories (openings).'
Except that Abu al-Tayyib is more noble in wording. The first who uttered this meaning was Amr bin Hilliza, brother of Al-Harith, in his poem the first of which is:
'It was only what was to be / And the calamities of people in time are types.'
Then he said following this:
'Perhaps eyes were cooled by a grief / Painful, from which eyes became hot.'
This is his saying: 'Calamities of a people are benefits to a people.'

Al-Anbari said: "And among his virgin meanings is his saying:
'And of the misery of the world on the free man is that he sees / An enemy for him whose friendship is unavoidable.'
I said: "The wonder is the saying of Al-Nazzam the Miserable:
'And of the misery of the world on the free man is that he sees / An enemy whom he loves to be called a friend.'
To this meaning Ibn Al-Mubarak went by his saying:
'Who is my guide to the path of my rectitude / Who is my helper, who seeks a path for me?
The calamities of time ceased not with me until / They left me to him whom I oppose, a friend.'
Although Al-Qasim bin Yahya Al-Maryami, and it is likely you relied on him, has said in a poem beginning 'If your opinion in your affairs is piercing / Then be patient and do not be an overcomer of fate':
'My soul is your ransom, harming or benefiting / Or ascetic in his slave or desiring.
I would have struck what suppressed the enemy and was for me / A joy, and was upon the enemy calamities.'

And Ibn al-Rumi has said:
'Your enemy is gained from your friend / So do not increase in companions.
For the disease, most of what you see / Is from food or drink.'
You took the last verse of these two entirely, so you said:
'The doctor says to me: You ate something / And your disease is in your drink and food.'
This meaning looks to the saying of Abu Nuwas, and its beginning was:
'If a wise man tested the world, it revealed / To him an enemy in the clothes of a friend.'
Abu Nuwas imitated in this saying Jarir:
'They called passion until our hearts were shot / With arrows of enemies while they are a friend.'

Al-Anbari said: "Do you know for anyone this meaning:
'Banu Ka'b, no hand made an impact in them / That the bracelet did not bloody.'
I said to him: "Not every meaning he stole is present with me, but I know for him in this poem:
'They passed racing in limbs in it / For their heads by their legs is a stumbling.'
'If he travels Al-Samawa without a guide / Their slain are for his eyes a lighthouse.'
As for his saying: 'For their heads by their legs is a stumbling', it is from the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
'They made their skulls / In the dust legs.'
And as for his saying: 'Their slain are for his eyes a lighthouse', it is from the saying of Dhu al-Rumma:
'And a wasteland, empty, the sandgrouse is confused in it / The guides of its riders are the daughters of the she-camels.
The sturdy one who is decisive protects with it / With the strike of his palms the desert, riding.
I cut it with ravines like arrowheads, so they became / With the family, happy in the backs of the deserts.'

Then I said: "This piece is of the verses of meanings." I turned to Abu al-Tayyib and said: "Do you have anything to say about it?" He turned away from my answer, and Al-Muhallabi looked up at him. So I said: "He meant by his saying 'The sandgrouse is confused in it' due to its vastness and ambiguity, and he specified the sandgrouse, the most guided of birds. His saying: 'The guides of its riders are the daughters of the she-camels' is the saying of Abu al-Tayyib: 'Their slain are for his eyes a lighthouse'. The daughters of the she-camels are their foals they drop on the road from the fatigue of walking, they guide themselves by them. His saying 'Yuhayi' is from 'Hayat' (life), i.e., he keeps alive with it. His saying 'By the strike of his palms the desert' means he performs Tayammum with dirt and seeks water to give his companion to drink and does not perform ablution with it. 'Al-Nisal': Arrowheads, he likened the riders to them in their leanness and pallor. His saying 'So they became with the family' means they slumbered and slept, so they dreamed of their family in their sleep."

Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi said: "This is like the saying of the other:
'Our youths impregnated the saddles / They did not leave of them a barren curve.'
He means they had wet dreams on the saddles."
Ali bin Isa al-Rummani said: "This is like the saying of Di'bil:
'I have not seen a knocked upon (host) settling with his guest / Nor a knocker (guest) giving wishes and graying.'"
Al-Muhallabi appreciated that. I said: "And like it is the saying of Al-Ra'i:
'The knowledge of drowsiness sufficed me, and I sufficed him / Watching the stars while slumber embraced him.
So he spent the night showing him his wife and daughters / And I spent the night showing the star where its setting places are.'"

I said: "Like the saying of Dhu al-Rumma: 'The guides of its riders are the daughters of the she-camels' is the saying of the other:
'A trackless desert, its guide smells the dirt / And there is nothing in it but the Yemeni, failing.
I crossed it alone and did not fear death / My guide a star or a left-behind young camel.'
He says: The camels aborted from the intensity of marching in it, so they cast their fetuses, so they became like a lighthouse for its inhabitant to guide and lead by."

Al-Muhallabi turned to Abu Sa'id and Abu al-Hasan al-Rummani asking them to explain and seeking more from them. They said: "The matter is as he said, and thus Al-Asma'i mentioned." It pleased him.

Then I said: "And I know from that poem the saying of Abu al-Tayyib:

book_title: The Clarifying Treatise on Mentioning the Plagiarisms of Al-Mutanabbi and His Substandard Poetry
text: And among the misery of the world upon a free man is that he sees... an enemy whom he desires... whom he desires to be called a friend. Ibn al-Mubarak went towards this specific wish in his saying: 'Who is my guide to the path of my righteousness... who is my helper? Who will seek a path for me? / The calamities of time did not cease with me until... they left me as a friend to the one I treat as an enemy.' However, Al-Qasim bin Yahya al-Maryami is worthy and likely to be the one you relied upon, for he said in a poem beginning with: 'If your opinion in your affairs is piercing... then be patient and do not be one who tries to defeat destiny.' He said within it: 'My soul is your ransom, whether harming or benefiting... or abstaining from his slave or desiring him / You have achieved what repressed the enemy, and it was for me... a joy, while it was a calamity upon the enemy.' And Ibn al-Rumi has said: 'Your enemy is gained from your friend... so do not acquire too many companions / For the disease, the most you see of it... comes from food or drink.' You [Al-Mutanabbi] took the last verse of these two entirely and said: (The doctor says to me, 'You ate something'... and your disease is in your drink and the food). Looking at this meaning is the saying of Abu Nuwas, the beginning of which was: 'If the world tests a wise man, it reveals to him... an enemy in the clothes of a friend.' And Abu Nuwas imitated Jarir in this saying: 'They invited passion until our hearts were struck... by the arrows of enemies while they were friends.' Al-Anbari said: 'Do you know this meaning for anyone: (The Banu Ka'b, and nothing left a mark on them... a hand not muddied except by bracelets)?' I said to him: 'Not every meaning he plagiarized is present in my mind, but I know regarding this word of his: (They passed, their limbs racing within it... their heads stumbling over their legs) [and] (If one travels the Samawah without a guide... their dead bodies are landmarks for his eyes).' As for his saying: (Their heads stumbling over their legs), it is from the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz: 'They turned their heads... in the dust into legs [feet].' And as for his saying: (Their dead bodies are landmarks for his eyes), it is from the saying of Dhu al-Rummah: 'And a desolate desert where the sandgrouse is confused... the guides for its riders are the daughters of the she-camels / The enduring man who is prudent vies with it... with the strike of his palms upon the open land, a rider / I crossed it with mountain paths like arrowheads, so they became... with family, joyful in the backs of the deserts.' Then I said: 'This piece belongs to the verses of deep meanings.' I turned to Abu al-Tayyib [Al-Mutanabbi] and said: 'Do you have a remark regarding this?' He turned away from my reply, and Al-Muhallabi looked towards him expectantly. So I said: '[Dhu al-Rummah] intended by his saying "the sandgrouse is confused in it" to indicate its vastness and similarity [of terrain], and he singled out the sandgrouse as it is the most guided of birds. His saying: "the guides for its riders are the daughters of the she-camels" is the [source of] Abu al-Tayyib's saying: (Their dead bodies are landmarks for his eyes). For the "daughters of the she-camels" are their offspring that they drop on the road due to the exhaustion of the journey, so they use them as guides. His saying "yuhayi" is from life, meaning he keeps himself alive with it (or shies away/vies). And his saying "with the strike of his palms upon the open land" means that he performs dry ablution (Tayammum) with dust and saves the water for his companion to drink, not using it for ablution. "Al-Nisal" are the arrowheads; he likened the riders to them in their leanness and pallor. And his saying: "so they became with family" means they rested and slept, so they were carried to their families in their sleep.' Abu Said al-Sirafi said: 'This is like the saying of the other: (I have impregnated our young men with the saddlebags... they did not leave a curved rib of them barren).' He means they dreamt while on the saddles. Ali bin Isa al-Rummani said this is like the saying of Di'bil: 'I have not seen a visited one settling with his guest... nor a night-visitor giving desires and graying.' Al-Muhallabi admired that. I said: 'And similar to it is the saying of Al-Ra'i: (The knowledge of drowsiness sufficed me, and I sufficed it... guarding the stars while slumber embraced him / So it [slumber] began showing him his wife and daughters... and I began showing the star where its setting place was).' And I said: 'Similar to Dhu al-Rummah's saying: "the guides for its riders are the daughters of the she-camels" is the saying of the other: (A trackless desert, its guide sniffs the dust... and there is nothing in it but the Yemeni camel failing / I crossed it alone and did not fear death... my guide was a star or a left-behind camel foal).' He says: The camels aborted due to the intensity of the travel in it, casting their fetuses, so they became like landmarks for its inhabitants to use as guides.' Al-Muhallabi turned to Abu Said and Abu al-Hasan al-Rummani asking them for understanding and more details. They said: 'The matter is as he said, and strictly so did Al-Asma'i mention.' He was pleased by that. Then I said: 'And I know from that poem the saying of Abu al-Tayyib...'

'So you were the sword, its hilt to them / And in the enemies are your edge and the blade.'
This is from the saying of the first:
'Our swords divide us a division / Among us are their sheaths (coverings) and among them are their chests (blades).'
Ali bin Isa said: "This is as the other said, recited to us by Muhammad bin al-Hasan Ibn Duraid:
'Abd Amr disputes my cloak with me / Slowly, O brother of Sa'd bin Bakr.
Mine is the half which my right hand possessed / So take and wrap yourself with a half.'"

I said: "And I know in it:
'As if the ray of the sun's eye is in him / So in our eyes from him is a refraction.'
This is the saying of the other:
'If she sees me, she turns away from me / As if the sun turns from my direction.'
And I know from it his saying:
'The cold of the white swords replaced them from them / And their heads belong to him, with them borrowed.'
This is as if it is from the speech of the Sufis."

Al-Anbari said: "Do you know for anyone the like of his saying:
'I hoped the night they traveled would reveal her wrist / So the tribe would stay without marching, bewildered.'"
I said: "Yes, the saying of Mahmud Al-Warraq, and from him he took the meaning:
'I said: Lift the curtain, let us enjoy our gathering / For the sun has not set from your face, the tired one.'"
Al-Anbari said: "Where is this from that?" I said: "It is it, if you look closely."

Abu al-Tayyib said: "And in this word I say:
'As for clothes, they become naked; and of her beauties / When she strips them, beauty is clothed naked.'"
I hastened him by saying: "This is what you adhered to in his saying:
'The adornment of clothes, even if her clothes were stripped / On the mattress from her, the stripping adorned her.'"

He said: "And in it I say:
'As if they arrive at death out of thirst / Or smell from the spear a basil.'"
I said: "You stole it from Al-Buhturi:
'They crowd for fighting at the battle / Like the crowding of thirsty camels for a watering place.'"

He said: "And in it I say:
'I do not ask for more upon what is in you of generosity / I am the youth who slept, if alerted, awake.'"
I said: "This is stolen from the saying of Abu Tammam:
'The blessing of God in you, I do not ask God / Other than it as a blessing, except that it lasts.
If I did, I would be like one who / Asks him, while he is standing, to stand.'
Jarir has said:
'Indeed I and your love, if you wanted an increase / In love with me, you would not find an increase.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "And in it I say:
'Upon you from yourself, if you are alone, is a watcher / You did not do in secret what you did not do openly.'
I said: "This is stolen from the saying of the other:
'For whom do I not see, I turned away from everyone I see / And became upon my heart a watcher for its killer.'
Al-Abbas has said:
'I lower my eyes if I look at other than you / As if you have a watcher over my heart.'"
That angered him, and Al-Muhallabi ordered patience with him, and signaled to me.

Abu Al-Ala Sa'id bin Thabit, who was at the time replacing Al-Muhallabi, said: "I appreciate the saying of Abu al-Tayyib about Sayf al-Dawla:
'The noble walk on the traces of others / And you create what you come to and innovate.'
'Whoever's position is above the place of the sun / Nothing raises him nor lowers him.'"
Al-Muhallabi said: "This is a virgin (original), no one said it." Then he turned to the group and said: "Do you know this for anyone?"
Abu al-Hasan al-Ansari, who was clinging to the tails of literature, said: "Refer to Tawwab who extracts the theft," meaning me. He said: "What do you have?"
I said: "The first is stolen from the saying of Al-Sanawbari:
'Was it not enough for you that you were found following / In generosity, until you were found inventing?'
As for the second, it is stolen from the saying of Bani Dulamah, and some of our companions narrate it for Mani:
'If a people were to sit above the sun out of generosity / It would be said: Sit, O family of Abbas.
Then ascend in the ray of the sun, all of you / To the sky, for you are the masters of people.'
The first who spoke this meaning was Zuhair in his saying:
'If a people were to sit above the sun out of generosity / By their firsts or their glory, they would have sat.'

When the wave of this speech covered Abu al-Tayyib, he said: "Slowly! As for what you criticized me of theft, what makes you know that I intended it? The speech of the Arabs takes some by the necks of some, and takes from some. Meanings struggle in the chests, so they occur to the predecessor at times and to the later one at other times, and words are shared, permissible. This is Amr ibn al-Ala who was asked about two poets agreeing in wording and meaning despite the difference between them and the distance between their lands, so he said: Those are minds of men that coincided on their tongues. Furthermore, who is this who is stripped of following, and singled out with invention and innovation? I do not know a Pre-Islamic nor Islamic poet except he has imitated and followed, and attracted and imported.

This is Imru' al-Qais saying:
'A chest gathered, as if its construction / Is raised on the head of a trimmed palm trunk.'
He only relied in it on Abu Duwad:
'And a neck advanced, no defect in it / Like the trunk cleared of the leaf bases.'
He also said:
'As if the whistling birds of the valley in the morning / Were given a drink of spiced pure wine.'
He only relied in it on Abu Duwad al-Iyadi:
'You think its whistling birds in the forenoon / Amidst the deserts are drunken drinkers.'
Imru' al-Qais said describing a horse:
'As if my boy when he topped the condition of his back / Was on the back of a hawk in the sky, soaring.'
Which is from the saying of Abu Duwad:
'If his rider wishes, he embraces him / As a hawk embraces the wing to itself.'
Imru' al-Qais said:
'Attacking, fleeing, advancing, retreating together / Like a boulder of rock the torrent brought down from above.'
He only relied in it on Abu Duwad in his saying:
'Puffing, throwing, helping, artful / Mixing, separating, recalcitrant, exiting.'
Imru' al-Qais said describing lightning:
'And its brightness calms at times, and at times / It rises as the broken-winged bird rises.'
He relied in it on Abu Duwad also in his saying:
'And it expanded rising the rise of the broken / The water pushed it until it flowed.'
Adi bin Zaid took it from both of them saying:
'And my love after the calm, winds drive it / As the broken is driven.'
This is the Prince of Poets. And after him Al-Nabigha, and a group has prioritized him over him, said:
'And you think her in the house when you surprised her / A lit lamp that was hidden.'
He only relied in it on the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'She lights up the darkness in the evening as if she is / The lamp of the night of a devoted monk.'
Zuhair said:
'He stabs them, they did not shoot, until if they stabbed / He struck, until if they struck, he embraced.'
He only relied in it on the saying of Muhalhil:
'They pulled the strings of the bows and flashed / As stallions threaten stallions.'
Al-A'sha said describing the phantom:
'My debt twists me in the morning and I demand / And my debt if drowsiness struck the sleepers.'
He only took it from the saying of Amr bin Qami'a:
'Umama distanced except for a question / And except for a phantom meeting a phantom.
It meets with the night, her appointment / And refuses with the morning except departure.'

I said to him: "From here Qais bin Al-Khatim took:
'How did you travel un-traveling / And dreams bring near a non-near one?
You did not prevent my wakefulness, so you may give it / In sleep, not restricted nor calculated.'
Al-Buhturi took this and said:
'My soul is ransom for one who distances, and her remembrance nears / And her phantom gives and she refuses.'"

He said: "And Al-A'sha took his saying:
'You spend the night in the winter full, your bellies / And your female neighbors are hungry, spending the night empty.'
From the saying of Al-Ash'ar:
'It is not right for neighbors to neighbor / This one a brother of satiety and that folding the intestines.'
This is Ubayd bin Al-Abras who took his saying:
'And people blame the misguided if they / Missed correctness, and the guided is not blamed.'
From the saying of Al-Muraqqish the Elder:
'Whoever meets good, people praise his affair / And whoever is seduced fails to find a blamer for error.'
Al-Akhtal said:
'As for the back, it is of a white brocade / And on the legs like tattooing with tar.'
He only took it from the saying of Al-Musayyab bin Alas in his saying:
'As if on the back is brocade / And the black of legs think it tar.'
This is Jarir who took his saying:
'I am chaste in poverty, sharing in richness / Swift to move if I am not pleased with my house.'
From Al-Munakhkhal Al-Sa'di in his saying:
'Indeed calamities afflict me in richness / And I am chaste at the scarcity of poverty.'

And for Jarir in satirizing Al-Farazdaq:
'The branches of disgraces flow upon them / And they were for its evils a settling place.'
And for Al-Farazdaq in satirizing Jarir:
'You are the settling place of every mine of evil / And for every flowing thing that flows, a settling place.'
They both took it from A'sha Bahila in satirizing Al-Raqqad bin Amr Al-Ja'di:
'Banu Hisn are the settling place of all meanness / Likewise for every flowing thing a settling place.'
And Al-Farazdaq took his saying:
'Short-haired, led, and in the chase as if they are / Eagles of a cloudy day and light rain.'
And took his saying:
'And possessor of a husband, our spears married her / Lawful to who builds (consummates) with her, she was not divorced.'
From Sulayk bin Al-Sulaka in his saying:
'And how many a widow our spears married / And another over an uncle and maternal uncle grieving.'

Then he said: "This is a small portion of a lot that gathering and exhaustion cannot cover, let alone what the instinct helps with and memory dictates for discussion."

The Vizier looked up at his speech, and the group listened to his saying, and showed appreciation which what he brought did not deserve.
I said to him: "As for your saying that the meaning struggles in the chest so it occurs to the predecessor at times and to the later one at others, and that words are shared, the matter is not as you imagined, nor is all speech shared, nor is the first not more entitled to it than the last. If it were so, the virtue of the forerunner would fall, and the precedence of the advanced would be void, and the Pre-Islamic poets would not have been prioritized over the Islamic poets, nor the first generation of Islamists over the first generation of moderns. They were only judged with preference, and precedence surrendered to them because of what they innovated of meanings, preceded to of metaphors, invented of valid similes and wandering proverbs, and smoothed of the rugged paths of poetry; and because they did not envy each other by theft, importing, transfer, and attraction.

Do you not see the saying of Qurad bin Hanash Al-Murri satirizing Banu Auf:
'When they gather in their clubs, they squat / The sitting of the tribe's maids around the slaughterhouses.
If they speak, they say what was said before them / And if they arrive [at water], they circle through the returning ones.'
Jarir taunted Al-Farazdaq for his importing, so he said:
'You will know who his father is a blacksmith / And whose poems are known as importation.'
When Ka'b said:
'So who is for the rhymes, checking them, who weaves them / If Ka'b passes and the success of Jarwal?'
Muzarrid bin Dirar, brother of Al-Shammakh, objected to him and said:
'I passed by Ka'b and imagined my wild beasts (verses) / Wild beasts rising above Ka'b and Jarwal.
Did you wade a sea people fell short of / Of poetry, or did you say what was not said?'
Ibn Harma said mentioning people who stole his poetry and borrowed his meanings:
'I feed an inheritance of poems, I fix them / The fixing of the decisive one for needs and order.
I prepare poems for the narrators, remaining / As if they are among them embroidered suits.
Either erotic poetry, or praise of possessor of pride / Remaining, or storing from those of error.
Until when their ears were filled with wonder / And they stopped in the hearts of people like honey.
They dropped to them to dive in their pastures / They did not knock the mothers of the Shul (camels) for pregnancy.
They explored a mind they do not reason with / And placed the sitting of the gathered among the neglected.
I do not share with them the paths of their stallion / Nor in a plain do I graze with them nor a mountain.
I cease not to see my brand and recognize it / In another herd branded on a front.
I did not brand young camels while they were grazing / Until they came despite the fetters and shackles.'

What is your saying: Who is this who is stripped of following and imitation, and walking the path to which others preceded him of poets? By my life, the matter is as you mentioned, except that speech is not praised if it is forest-like (dense/confused), nor meanings if repeated. So the poet should not permit the bulk of his poetry, upon examination, to be stolen pasted, and collected fabricated, nor to increase reliance in his poetry, and theft to support his speech. The path of the imitator is to take the meaning without the wording, then to fold it if it is exposed, and reveal it if it is hidden, and improve the expression of it, and choose the sweet meter for it, so that it becomes fragrant to the ears and attached to hearts. Do you not see the saying of Al-A'sha:
'Leave us and a people if they intended for us / Abu Thabit, and sit for you are fed.'
Al-Hutay'ah took it, improved the expression of it, and fulfilled the meaning in it, so he became more entitled to it than its inventor by his saying:

'Leave noble deeds, do not travel to seek them / And sit, for you are the fed, the clothed.'
And just as Imru' al-Qais said:
'And no like of a day in Qudharan I shaded it / As if I and my companions were on the horn of a gazelle.'
Al-Murrar took it and revealed it and said:
'As if the hearts of their guides / Are hung on the horns of gazelles.'
And just as Al-Muraqqish said about two lion cubs:
'No day passed but they have / The meat of men or they lap blood.'
Imru' al-Qais looked a look and said:
'As if the hearts of birds, wet and dry / At her nest are jujube and worn-out dates.'
That is because Imru' al-Qais went to the idea that the eagle is provided for and that the game is with her; to this Al-Muraqqish went in describing the lioness, that she is provided for and that prey is abundant with her.

If you contemplate the verses you argued with, you will find much of the taken in them surpassing the taken from, advancing in the field of clarity, judged in it for the taker with excellence, or equal to him all equality.
Of equality is the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'If it were a soul dying together (at once) / But it is a soul falling as souls (pieces).'
Abd bin al-Tayyib took it, revealed it, sharpened it, and equaled in it who preceded him, saying:
'The perishing of Qais was not the perishing of one / But it is the building of a people that collapsed.'
Similar to this is the saying of Al-Nabigha Al-Dhubyani:
'The headscarf fell and she did not intend its falling / So she picked it up and guarded herself from us with the hand.'
Abu Hayya Al-Numayri took the meaning and did well, all wellness, for a subtle addition he added in his saying:
'So she cast a veil, other than it is the sun (like the sun), and guarded herself / With the best two connected things: a palm and a wrist.'
Equality became obligatory for him by this addition, but preference was not given over Al-Nabigha because of Al-Nabigha's precedence in inventing this meaning. The addition is his saying: "Other than it is the sun", meaning like the sun, and his saying: "With the best two connected things".

But for the poet to import a meaning and fall short of fulfilling it as you fell short, and do badly in expressing it as you did, and fall forever below the first, then there is no bearing with him, nor permissiveness in it, nor judgment of excellence in any of it. Do you not see the saying of Tarfa:
'By your life, indeed death, what mistakes the youth / Is like the loosened long rope whose two ends are in the hand.'
Al-Ra'i took it and fell short, all shortness, in it by his saying:
'And I know that death, O Umm Amir / Is a companion whose rope surrounds me from behind me.'
Look at the disparity between the two speeches despite the precedence of the advanced one to the meaning.
And Tarfa said:
'So if I am to be eaten, be you my eater / For some deaths of people are more honorable than others.'
Abdullah bin Al-Hajjaj Al-Tha'labi took it and said:
'So if I am to be eaten, be you my eater / And if I am to be slaughtered, be you the slaughterer.'
He did badly, all badness, and exchanged for us that proverb and eloquent wording with what demonstrated the dullness of his edge and the stinginess of his flint.
Al-Murrar said mentioning the male ostrich:
'Possessor of a cloak that was empty on his chest / Black, rough from spinning.
And a white piece (shaqiqa), not long / From his knees, little of surplus.'
His saying: "Rough from spinning" is because of the variegation of his feathers. He likened the blackness of his upper parts and chest to a black cloak that was empty on him. And he likened the whiteness of his lower parts to his knees to a white piece (shaqiqa), which is what is split in two, because if it reaches his knees it is cut off. Al-Tirimmah took this, shortened his wording, and improved the expression of it by his saying:
'Wearing a cloak of striped cloth for his back / As a loincloth, and what is other than it, the striped cloth surrendered.'
He says: His back is striped.

Al-Nabigha said describing a wild bull, and it is of his meanings which he was not preceded to:
'From the wild beasts of Wajra, his legs are marked / Folding the intestines (lean) like the sword of the polisher, the solitary.'
Al-Tirimmah took it and added the best addition, and became because of it more entitled to the meaning by his saying:
'He appears and the lands hide him as if he is / A sword on a height being drawn and sheathed.'
He likened him in the two states of his appearance and hiding to the sword in the two states of its drawing and sheathing.

Some Arabs said:
'She was proud against me that her beauties were complete / A tender girl in whose sides temptations speak.
She intended coming to us until when she looked / In the mirror, her beautiful face forbade her.'
Abu Nuwas pointed to this meaning a hidden pointing and added a subtle addition, saying:
'She looks in the mirror and says: Here now / I am the sun about which there is no doubt.'

'I, by God, am fit for sins / If the people of sins commit them.'
Look at his subtlety in taking, and his good approach to following and imitating."

Then I said: "I have not found them praising the poet's increasing of following, and his increasing of taking and stealing, for that from him indicates the narrowness of scope, poverty and imbalance, and the shortness of mind, dullness of thought, and cowardice of instinct."

Al-Muhallabi admired what I brought, and emphasized the instruction to whomever he had appointed of his scribes to record what happened, control it, collect it, and fulfill it. He said: "We only come to you once in a while, so if we come to you, improve the hospitality." He rose angrily, so Al-Muhallabi ordered him to be returned, so he was returned compelled, but he did not prolong the sitting and rose. When he departed, Al-Muhallabi turned to me and said: "I want you to negotiate speech with him regarding the poetry of Abu Tammam and Al-Buhturi, and test what he has regarding them."

A week passed and he did not summon him, nor did he attend initiating, then he attended and apologized for his delay. Abu Ali Al-Anbari had dragged the ropes of greed for him, and promised him from Al-Muhallabi what was far from reaching him, due to Al-Muhallabi's bad opinion of him. He signaled to me to run with him what I had marked for you of running.

I asked him to recite his word whose beginning is:
'O burning of his heart for one whose heart is cold / And who has, regarding my state and body, a sickness.'
He hesitated a little, then began and recited it until he reached his saying:
'And the horses, and the night, and the desert know me / And the war, and the strike, and the paper, and the pen.'
The group appreciated this verse an appreciation in which they exceeded.
I said: "He only took it from his two Imams."
He said: "And who are my two Imams whose poetry you annexed, whose sanctity you tore, whom you attacked, and whose knowledge you denied?"
I said: "Abu Tammam and Al-Buhturi. As for Al-Buhturi, he said:
'O my two friends at Al-Sawajir from Udn / Bin Ma'n and Buhtur bin Atud.
Seek a third other than me, for I am / The fourth of the white camels, the darkness, and the deserts.'
As for Abu Tammam, he said, and upon him Al-Buhturi relied:
'The white camels, and worry, and the complete night together / Are three forever joined in a horn (rope).'
Abu Tammam imitated in it the saying of Al-Shanfara:
'And I have besides you a family: A wolf, swift / And a leopard, smooth, and a hyena with mane.
Three companions, a brave heart / And a drawn white sword and a long yellow bow.'
To these two verses Dhu al-Rumma looked in his saying:
'And a night like the cloak of the bride, I wore it / With four, while the person in the eye is one.
A deaf Hilafi sword, and a sharp white one / And a reddish-white Mahri camel, and a noble terrified one.'"
One of those present, and I think it was Al-Anbari, said: "What does the night resemble of the bride's cloak?" So I held back.
Al-Muhallabi said: "What do you say?"
I said to him: "The night does not resemble anything of the bride's cloak except its length and ampleness."
Al-Muhallabi said: "Then what does he intend by his saying:
'With four, while the person in the eye is one'?"
I said: "He intends that he looked at this group gathered in the darkness of the night, so he imagined them as one person."

His hearing was struck by my speech with what awakened his zeal, shook his determination for riot, and moved his outburst. He exemplified with the saying of the poet:
'And things may be remembered by the thing after them / And the distinct enemy returns to affection.'
And he said: "As for your Abu Tammam who says:
'He gulps sorrow, the singular swallowing has become empty / And leave the sip (Hisy) of an eye whose water ecstasy milks.'
He made the ugliest absurdity, and borrowed the furthest metaphor, by his making the eye a Hisy (water hole in sand), while Ahsa (plural of Hisy) are described by little water, and it is the nature of tears to be described by abundance by those of ecstasy and passion." The group was as if it listened to this saying.

I said: "The matter is not as you imagine, because Al-Hisy is the sand under which is a solid rock that returns the water, so the sand drinks the water until it reaches that rock. If they need water, they dig and extract thing after thing. This is the saying of the author of 'Al-Ain' and a group of people of knowledge. Abu Tammam borrowed 'Hisy' for the eye, because tears come out thing after thing, and this is a real metaphor not a metaphor of exaggeration."

He held back for a little while then said: "Abu Tammam the sayer in this rhyme:
'Thin of the edges of forbearance; if his forbearance / Were in your palms, you would not doubt that it is a Burdah (garment).'
Did anyone before him praise anyone for thinness of forbearance? Describing it with gravity and thickness is more appropriate. Do you not see the saying of Adi bin Al-Riqa':
'You have good situations / And forbearances (dreams) for you that weigh the mountains.'"

He said: "Then he likened forbearance in its thinness to the Burdah, and the thinness of the Burdah is indicative of the looseness of its weaving, and that is not of its descriptions nor praiseworthy qualities."
He said: "And in this poem he says:
'Do not think Hind has treachery alone / It is the nature of a soul; every beautiful woman is Hind.'
He only took it from the saying of Al-Adbat bin Qurai' Al-Sa'di. He was their master, then he saw envy from them, so he departed from them and settled among others, but saw them in the same condition, so he said: 'Wherever I go I meet Sa'd', i.e., people are like my people in their envy of their masters."
I said to him: "There is no clearer proof of Abu Tammam's virtue than his taking this speech and organizing it in that easy, sturdy, far, near expression."

He said: "And Abu Tammam the sayer:
'I say to a Qurhan (un-ulcerated/inexperienced) of separation who did not host / The creeping of passion between the entrails and the chest bones.'
What is 'Qurhan al-Bayn' (un-ulcerated of separation), may God silence his tongue?"
I said to him: "He means a man whom his loved ones did not cut off, nor did his mates separate from him, nor did passion visit him, nor did ecstasy enslave his patience. The origin in this word is that the Qurhan is the one who did not have smallpox. Jarir said:
'And I was, regarding the sighs of love, a Qurhan (free/inexperienced).'

In this word Abu Tammam says:
'And riders driving the mounts, a glass / Of marching (Sira) which the palm of a gatherer did not intend.
They ate the humps from them by night travel / So their figures became like the humps.'"
Abu al-Tayyib said: "As for the first verse, it is from the saying of Abu Nuwas, until you contemplate the second verse:
'A people who passed around on the saddles among them / The cup of night travel, so the given drink and the cupbearer became intoxicated.
As if their heads, while drunkenness lowers them / On the shoulders, were not inserted in necks.'
Abu Nuwas took it from the saying of Abu Dahbal:
'I say while the riders, their turbans have tilted / And sleeplessness has given the people the cup of drowsiness to drink.'"

I said: "And in this poem Abu Tammam says:
'He sees the ugliest of things is the return of a hoper / Whom the hand of the hoped-for clothed in the suit of a loser.
And better than a blossom which dew opens / Is the whiteness of gifts in the blackness of demands.'"
He said: "As for the first verse, it is taken as a raid from the saying of Al-Akhtal:
'They saw whiteness in blackness as if it is / The whiteness of gifts in the demands.'"
I said to him: "This verse is from the fabrications of Ahmad bin Abi Tahir out of prejudice against Abu Tammam. Otherwise, who is this who narrates poetry, and in which poem is it, and in which copy of Al-Akhtal's Diwan is it found?"
He said: "And what motivated Ahmad bin Abi Tahir to this, and what cause necessitated it from him?"
I said: "Is he not the sayer:
'Al-Buhturi, if you searched his lineage / In Buhtur, in Banu Thu'al.
Both of them suspect regarding his lineage / And his heart from his suspicion is in fear.'"

Then I said: "And in this poem Abu Tammam says:
'And Al-Afshin knew, and he is the one by whom / The cloak of the kingdom is protected from every puller.
That you, when the matter rubbed you and clothed itself / In hides blown in the faces of calamities.'"
I said: "This is the lacking, the miraculous, the greed-inducing, the impossible, the near, the far, the easiest rugged." And I recited to him from it:
'If poetry were to perish, it would have been perished by what settled / Your basins of it in the passing ages.
But it is the downpour of minds; when / Clouds of it clear, they are followed by clouds.'"
Abu al-Tayyib said: "As for the second verse, it is from the saying of Aws bin Hajar:
'I speak by what my cloud poured upon them / And my effort in the rope of the clan is a wood-gatherer.'"
I said: "By God, if he took as you claim, he surely folded the taking, and added to the inventor in meaning a subtle addition by his saying: 'But it is the overflow of minds'."

Abu al-Tayyib said: "How can Abu Tammam be doing well in taking while he is the sayer:
'Leading their forelocks is a Judhayl (rubbing post) of easts / When a worry returns to him, he is an Udhayq (date bunch) of wests.'
He took it from the sturdiest wording and clearest of some of the ancients:
'And riders who, with the eyes of the stars, saw / The straying of the Mahara camels, so they were guided by the stars.
They are the sunrise of the easts once / And another time, when they disappear, the sunset of the wests.'"

Then he said: "He is the one who says:
'By my life, I would have freed the day I met him / If only fate alone did not chill.'"
I said to him: "He is the beginner of this poem with his saying:
'She began seeking refuge for the tear from fear of tomorrow's distance / And every sleeping place became tragacanth (thorns) to her.
And what saved her from the flood of death was that it is / A repulsion of separation, not a repulsion of intentional hate.
So pity made flow for her a rosy tear / Of blood running over a rosy cheek.
She is the full moon, the affection of her face brings her near / To everyone she met, even if she did not show affection.'
And in it he says:
'But I did not contain gathered wealth / And won it except with a scattered reunion.
Nor did days give me a tranquil sleep / I enjoy, except with a displaced sleep.
The length of a man's stay in the tribe wears out / His two brocades, so go abroad, you will be renewed.
For I saw the sun increased in love / Because it is not permanent over them.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "As for his saying 'So go abroad, you will be renewed', it is from the saying of Laqit bin Zurara:
'And whoever is addicted to the roast meat in the tribe wears out.'
He said: His saying 'For I saw the sun' is from the saying of Kuthayyir:
'And if the sun of the day did not set, it would be boring.'"
I said to him: "And who is there for you who utters the like of this and is capable of it, or takes a meaning and clothes it in an elegant exhibition, and casts it so its drinking place is sweet, and its intent is obscure to minds?"

I said: "And in it he says:
'And the spears had seen his heart / So the curtain of extended fate gave them ophthalmia.
And I hope that He necklaces his neck / With the necklace of a polished, Indian sharp sword.
Strung with death, its wearer attains its ornament / Its wearer among people without the necklace.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "He is the sayer:
'So you struck the winter in its two jugular veins / A strike that left it an old riding camel.'"
I said to him: "He is the sayer beginning this word:
'It is of the characters of height (length/tallness) not to answer / So it is correct for an eye to pour.'
This is of the best beginning. And in its erotic introduction he says:
'Most of the earth visiting and visited / And ascending from passion and descending.
And a buxom girl, as if / The heedlessness of youth clothed her in a new garment.
The separation showed her loss; rarely does she know / The loss of the sun until it sets.'
And in its praise he says:
'He preceded time with the old property and did not wait / For the calamities until they befall.
And whenever the circumstances exempted him, his / Palms were accidents and circumstances.'"

He said: "Is he not the sayer:
'Submissive to God, ruler of a nation / To those of arrogance (Tajahhum) in it, he has submission.'
If he had vomited his liver it would have been better than his saying 'Tajahhumha'."
I said to him: "The narration in this verse is 'Li dhawi takabburiha' (To those of arrogance in it). And 'Tajahhum' is taking the thing by oppression; therefore the lion was named Jahdam. In this poem he says:
'Did the tears of your eye descend because / A pigeon cooed when the darkness cleared?
Do not sob for her, for her weeping / Is laughter, and your weeping is infatuation.
They are the pigeons (Hamam); if you break in augury / From their Ha, then they are death (Himam).'
This is by everything a modern said (equal to all). And in it he says:
'With the large-mouthed, noble (camels) as if / Their figures between the hills are hills.
You kindled the flint of determinations under the darkness / They lit your thought while the lands were dark.
So you rose dragging the tail of an army drove by / The goodness of certainty and led by advancing.
Clamorous, noisy, you see its vanguard / And they have in the pierced space a crowding.
It filled the desert in groups and almost seemed / To have no rear in it and no front.
With sweating, lean-flanked, slender ones / Their hanging is the saddling and the bridling.
Unleashed towards deaths as if / Between deaths and them are wombs (kinship).
Lions of a thicket, hidden, they have no / Thickets except the sharp swords and spears.
And the strike ties the chief of a battalion / Fierce of nature, while deaths are standing.
So you broke the handle of their gathering in it, and / The heads began to separate from their handles.'
Then he said in it:
'Treading on your heels in seeking heights / And the goal, then the feet become equal.'
Al-Buhturi took this and said:
'You possessed the goal by precedence, and he prayed second / Then the feet became equal after him.'
And from here you took, O Abu al-Tayyib, your saying:
'I saw Ali and his son, his people / And they are the best people, and the free and the slave became equal.'
And you said in another place:
'The served and the servants resemble each other.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "He erred in his saying 'Kada bi-an yura' (Almost seemed) because what is heard from the speech of the Arabs is: 'Kada yaf'alu' (Almost did - without 'an')."
I said: "It has come for some poets in describing a road:
'It almost, from the length of wear, is erased (An yamsaha).'

If you make 'Kada' mean 'Arada' (wanted), the entry of 'An' becomes good, as he said:
'She almost (Kadat) and I almost (Kidtu), and that is the best will / If what passed of the connection of the beloved returned.'
He said: "He took his saying: 'Their hanging is the saddling and the bridling' from the saying of the first:
'She is wanted at the dirt of the watering places; if she refuses / Then the pasture is a journey, so riding.'"
I said to him: "This, even if it is taking as you mentioned, is better than the taken from and more revealing of the meaning."
He said: "But Al-A'sha has said:
'And a desert as if it is the back of a shield / There is nothing but the return (cud/excrement) in it as a hanging.'"
I said to him: "This is also not revealed all revelation, and saddling and bridling is more eloquent and clearer."

He said: "Abu Tammam who says:
'He turned away and did not oppress; and does a man oppress / Who urged the escape while behind him is the dragon?'
Have you seen a human likened to a dragon? He only intended the saying of Kuthayyir:
'He turns the two eyes of a snake in a shell.'
Or the saying of Al-Akhtal:
'Frogs in the darkness of a night responded to each other / So their sound indicated the sea snake.'
This is a school in praise which the Kings of Banu Umayya ceased not to be attached to in their poets, and announcing it in their praisers."

I said to him: "He is permitted that for his saying:
'Poured upon it from the skulls of its people / Rains whose signs are necks and tear ducts.
A sea of war, blowing; it has no / Ships except the skulls and the ribs.
A king, the noble deeds light up if appears / For the kingdom from him a blaze and a forehead.
His shaking softened so he became mighty; and only / The back of the spear hardens when it softens.
So you left Arshaq, and she is called by her name / Deaf rocks, so springs soften from it.
Babak met you roaring so he praised / And his roaring returned while it was a whine.
And he hoped for the lands of the Romans, so became difficult with him / A term, deaf to safety, stubborn.'"

He said: "He is the one who says:
'They were the cloak of their time, so they cracked / So as if Time wore wool.'"
I said: "He is the one who says in this poem:
'O dwelling that gave accidents their rule / No delay in a promise and no procrastination.
Dew anchored in your club, and winds breathed / A breath in your courtyard, weak.
The cloud was fond of your courtyards, and perhaps / Your hills quenched the wandering fond one.'
In it he says:
'Days when no calamity attacks your people / Except it retreats turned away.
And if accidents shot you with a glance / Your blades returned its glance blinded.'
In it he says:
'If the water of the cloud sinks, you overflowed... / The liver of time, you were kind to me.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "He is the one who says:
'Ninety thousand like the lions of Shara, their skins / Ripened before the ripening of figs and grapes.'"
I said to him: "For this verse is a news that necessitated its saying; if you investigated it, you would not permit attacking its sayer. If a sayer wished to say: No poem was opened with more concise nor shorter than his saying:
'The sword is more truthful in news than books / In its edge is the limit between seriousness and play.'
He would not be blamed."
He said: "Is this not from the saying of the first:
'So do not increase the clamor regarding him, for / The sword erased what Ibn Dara said, all of it.'"
I said: "The matter is as you mentioned. And you have imitated this meaning from Abu Tammam, so you said:
'And do letters avail against an enemy / If the sword is not a calligrapher?'"

I said: "In this poem Abu Tammam says:
'A virgin (city), the hand of an accident did not deflower it / Nor did the ambition of calamities ascend to it.
God threw its two towers with you so He destroyed it / And if other than God threw with you, he would not have hit.'"
He said: "Is this in your Book?" He disbelieved, may God curse him. "'And you did not throw when you threw, but God threw.'"
I said: "In it he says:
'A victory the gates of the sky open for / And the earth appears in its new clothes.
He did not raid a day nor rise to a land / Except an army of terror preceded him.
When he saw love with the eye's view, he became bankrupt / And war is derived in meaning from plunder (Harb/Harab).'"
He said: "Is this not from the saying of Al-Nabigha Al-Ja'di:
'And we plunder the dark horses, their owner was / Stingy with them, and war is plundering in it.'"

I said: "In it he says:
'You saw the great rest, so you did not see it / Attained except on a bridge of fatigue.'

And you took this verse according to your custom, so you said:
'And if souls are great / Bodies get tired in their desire.'"

He said: "And Abu [Tammam] is the sayer initiating:
'What is with the dune of the sanctuary to a knot.'"
I said: "Yes, this is the poem from which you took:
'Like the branch in figure, and the gazelle in / Splendor, and the fawn of the gazelle in softness.'
Then he corrected this and said:
'And he did not resemble it, and he has no softness / In his neck, rather he resembled it in a long neck.'
So I said taking the first verse:
'She appeared as a moon and swayed as a Ban branch / And smelled as ambergris and gazed as a gazelle.'
So what did you deny of this beginning and criticize him for? Did you not criticize his saying:
'The announcer deafened you even if he made hear.'
And no more wandering nor more concise than this was said in the beginning of an elegy after the saying of Aws bin Hajar. For the scholars of poetry entirely point to the saying of Aws:
'O soul, be beautiful in anxiety.'
And the saying of Abu Tammam, if you do not deny, is more fulfilling than it."
He said: "It is taken from the first:
'He announced Abu Al-Miqdam to me, so my view blackened / From the earth, and the hearing was blocked against me.'"
I said: "It is from it, but what a difference between them in nearness, subtlety, and brevity. If there were nothing but the virtue of brevity, I would judge with excellence and give him precedence.
And his saying:
'The strangeness of distance was happy with Su'ad.'
And his saying:
'O Rama, you were the familiar place of every white antelope.'"
He said: "This is from the saying of Zuhair."
And his saying in the beginning of another:
'It has become easy for us to say and to do.'
And the beginning of another:
'Yes, O quarter whose people... / Distance has attained in you what it seeks.'
And his saying:
'We did not know the weeping of the yearning one like this.'
And his saying:
'O lightning, spend the night at the top of Al-Buraq / And go early in it with a pouring rain.
And know that there is no / Share for your stars if they do not quench it.
Traces upon which the tears of the cloud met / For long, and the tears of lovers.'
This is of the best beginning. Likewise his saying:
'Take the tears of your eye from my determination / And preserve what the veil humiliated.
O familiar with weeping, how many a separation / Cast a shadow, so it was a caller to a meeting.
And the joy of returns is only / For one stopped at the grief of farewell.'

Then I said: "He is the one who says in the D-rhyme poem which you chanted in its beginning describing a flag:
'Yes, the flag of the army, you returned with it / On a Thursday, high of forenoon, ransom him.
I imagined a white eagle in the sides / Of the King flew with him and in his aim.
Passing, its two braids flutter on / A brown back on the day of battle, his body.
Its folds flap over a King / Who sees the chase of heroes as part of his expulsion.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "Turn away from this. As for Abu Tammam the sayer:
'And glory is not pleased that he be pleased that / He who hopes for you be pleased except with satisfaction.'
This, by God, is the raving that occupies the bellies of scrolls and extinguishes the fire of minds."
He said: "And I see he heard the verse of Muslim, so he wanted to ride the speech and interlace it like the composition of Muslim and his interlacing in his saying:
'She drew and drew, then her offspring was drawn / So the offspring of her offspring became drawn (maslul - also tubercular/wasted).'
This imagination of his made me laugh, and I said: "Muslim, even if he repeated the word, his verse has a subtle meaning I will present. Al-Bahili presented it in the book 'Al-Ma'ani', and claimed that he means this redness was drawn from the vine by picking it, then drawn from the grapes by pressing it, then the juice was drawn from the jar by broaching it. And his saying:
'So the offspring of her offspring became drawn'
He means the urine of its drinker. And he said after this verse:
'The mixture was kind to her so it adorned her cup / With a necklace made for her as a crown.'
He means the mixture raised her so it made the necklace, and it is in the eye a crown. Abu Nuwas disputed this meaning with him and expressed it well by his saying:
'The wine circulates upon us in a golden (cup) / A Persian endowed it with types of pictures.
Its bottom is Kisra and in its sides / Are wild cows the knights hunt with bows.
So for the wine is what its pockets were buttoned on / And for the water is what the caps turned on.'
As for the saying of Abu Tammam: 'And glory is not pleased that he be pleased', the likes of you criticize it while you are the sayer:
'So you shook with the worry that shook the entrails / Shakes of an eye, all of them are shakes.'
And the sayer:
'And from one ignorant of me while he is ignorant of his ignorance / And is ignorant of my knowledge that he is ignorant of me.'
And you are the sayer:

'Two standers in two stands of thanks and giving / So his gift is a stand (Waqf) and their thanks is a stand.'
And you are the sayer also:
'And not one in this creation but a group / And not the some of all but you are the double.'
'And not the double until the double reaches its double / And not the double of the double of the double but a thousand like it.'
'O our judge, is this what you are worthy of? / I erred, neither the two-thirds is this nor the half.'

I turned to him and said: "Do you think you forgive Abu Tammam in the midst of this raving of yours or do you not forgive him? In the Dad-rhyme poem Abu Tammam says:
'I have from days what, if it were / Facing the mustache of a sleeper, he would not have slept.
Do not seek provision after its shying away / To seek it a lion if it sank.
O Ahmad bin Abi Duwad, a call / I was humiliated by your thanks to me and it was untamed.
When I drew you for calamities, I was sufficed them / And the sword does not suffice you until it is drawn.
Be how you wish, in you are traits / To which hope has become delegated.'"

He said: "Is not Abu Tammam the sayer describing wine:
'If it crept in the youth, he imagined his body / When it crept in it, a village of the villages of ants.'"
I said to him: "As for the eloquent meaning, no criticism was found against it. Al-Akhtal has said:
'It creeps a creeping in the bones as if it is / The creeping of ants in a sand dune pouring down.'
The first has said:
'It creeps a creeping in the bones as if it is / The creeping of the daughters of the ants while they are spreading.'
Hassan bin Thabit said, and turned to another simile:
'It creeps in the body a creeping as / The Dubba (insect) crept in the middle of a soft sand.'
Because of its creeping it was named 'Dabbabah'. Dhu al-Rumma said describing a gazelle that leaned in its sleep:
'As if in the tribe, a creeper throws the dust with it / In the bones of the head, a trunk (nose).'
