He said: "As for me, 'village of ants' is far from my imagination and escapes my hearing. What is other than that has a face."

I said to him: "Count these trifles. Of the clearest proof that you have studied the poetry of this man, and disciplined yourself with his meanings, and followed his sect, and tracked his paths in it, is your tracking of these places against him and your specifying them, and your pointing to them and your criticism in them. Did your tracking and the tracking of your likes against him what you track brand Abu Tammam with the brand of deficiency, while he is the sayer:
'People did not see a sun before her / Which set and she did not follow them with darkness.
If they could, they would have walked on their cheeks / And their foreheads, let alone on feet.'
He is the sayer:
'Gray hair rose marking in my side-hair a plan / The path of destruction in it to death is a clear road.
He is the visitor shunned and the companion disliked / And the possessor of familiarity hated and the new patched.
He has a view in the eye, white, pure / But he is in the heart black, dark.'
He is the sayer:
'If you shoot from a life whose extent has prolonged / It betrayed you until you did not find a drawing place (for the bow) in it.'
He said: "This is taken from the saying of Al-Ba'ith:
'And we give the Mashrafiyya (swords) their right / So they cut in our right hands and are cut.'
And from his saying also:
'Time fulfilled with it from its events an honor / And the sword passes times then breaks.'
And Abu Tammam the sayer:
'For the family of Wahb are palms, whenever they were begged / They did in the drought what the rains do not do.
A people, you see them jealous over their glory / Until as if wealth without them is forbidden.'
He is the sayer:
'My companions say in Qumas, and the night travel / And the steps of the led Mahri camels have taken from us.
Is it the rising of the sun you seek to lead us to? / I said: No, but the rising of generosity.'
From the second verse you took your saying:
'And they ran a run in its orbits / So they cut its setting place and possessed the rising place.'
He is the one who says:
'The delegations of the earth departed from his grave / Empty-handed, full of hearts.
They knew what they lost; indeed / The loss of the sun is known at sunset.'
He is the one who says:
'I have not seen heights unless poetry is among them / Like the earth, unmarked, having no landmarks.
One sees as wisdom what is in it while it is humor / And he judges with what he judges with while he is unjust.
Were it not for traits enacted by poetry, seekers of dew / Would not know from where noble deeds are approached.'
He is the one who says:
'Stripped, a sword of opinion from his determination / For time, its polisher is silence and thought.'

'Sharp, if he shook it in the face of a calamity / The changes of Time came to him apologizing.'
From the first verse you took:
'The mind is bewildered in a sword whose origin is Rabi'a / And the Merciful is its maker and Glory is the polisher.'
He is the sayer also:
'Let not the enemies think your isolation is a spoil / For to the source (return) is what the goal of the watering is.
You were nothing but the sword drawn for battle / So it was praised in it, then returned to the scabbard.'
He is the sayer also:
'O King distant in his vision / And his generosity to the hoper of his generosity is near.
The veil is not distancing a hope for me from you / Indeed the sky is hoped for when it is veiled.'
He is the sayer also:
'You increased my white marks (clarity) in extension and I was not / Dark, nor an unknown earth.
But favors, their huge bodies encountered me / White-faced, so they made me white-faced, white-footed.'
He said: "It is taken from the saying of Abu Muhallim:
'Aslam, so be safe, O son of every Caliph / And O ruler of the world and O mountain of the earth.
I thanked you, for thanks is a nature of mine / And not everyone you bestowed a blessing on repays.
You revived my mention for me, and I was not obscure / But some mention is more notable than others.'"

I said: "And he is the sayer:
'And riders like the tips of spears, who stopped at night / On the like of them, and the night folds its darknesses.
For a matter upon them is that its beginnings complete / And not upon them is that its consequences complete.
To you we crossed the setting of the sun, whenever / We cut a desert, its deserts prayed for you.
To a taker of the egg of his kingdom from the tyrant / And his hoper comes early to him so he is his taker.
To a king who did not throw the bulk of his might / On a king except he humbled his side.
For in every highland in the lands and lowland / Are gifts not from him, yet they are his gifts.
He gave until he found no one to give / And fought until he found no one to fight.
O night traveler, capture without watching / The heart of darkness or death you fear.
For Abdullah has spread the fear of his vengeance / On the night until its scorpions do not creep.'"

He said: "As for his saying: 'And riders like the tips of spears', it is from the saying of Kuthayyir:
'She circumambulated disheveled ones like spears, asleep / With humble lights, dusty their courtyards.'
As for his saying: 'For a matter upon them is that its beginnings complete', it is from the saying of the first:
'A youth of battle who rushed into it so he wore out / So the treacherous time betrayed his trial.
It was upon the youth to advance in it / And not upon him is what death committed.'
As for his saying: 'Its deserts prayed for you', it is from the saying of Bashar:
'Whenever we lent a master from a tribe / The peak of a pulpit, he prayed for us and greeted.'
Bashar took it from Jarir:
'Pulpits of a kingdom, all of them Mudari / Pray for us whoever we lent a pulpit.'"

I said to him: "If Tammam was looking at these places, he surely took worn-out clothes and returned them with their embroidery fluttering, as the cheeks of gardens flutter after the rain. This was his doctrine in all the meanings he observed and pointed to. Do you not see the saying of the first:
'Swords, by my life, O Saday bin Malik / Sharp, but where is the striker with the sword?'
Abu Tammam imitated this:
'The sword named death may be blunt / And the victorious man may return failing.'
This verse is invented by him. Then he said imitating the preceding verse and explaining this verse of his:
'The bane of this is not to encounter a cutting place / And the bane of that is not to encounter a striker.'
Al-Farazdaq said, mentioning a wife of his who died in childbirth, she who dies with her child in her womb:
'And a sheath of a weapon I was stricken with, but I did not wail / Over it, nor did I send weepers over it.
And within it is one of Darim, possessor of protection / If only the nights missed him, my nights.'
Abu Tammam said regarding two small ones belonging to Abdullah bin Tahir, who died on one day, and he pointed to Al-Farazdaq's two verses a wondrous pointing, and increased subtle additions from a poem:
'Two stars God willed not to rise / Except the return of the glance until they set.
Indeed the bereavement of gardens while fresh / Is greater than of them gardens while withered.
If they were attributed, this one would be a withers / For noble deeds, and this one a shoulder.
My sorrow for those witnesses from them / If they were given respite until they became traits.
Indeed the crescent, if you saw its light / You became certain that it will be a full moon.'

This is what he imitated and generated and expanded and increased in, and expressed well. From the chapter is the saying of the other:
'I saw wealth earned by men / Deficient, if tested they are scoundrels.
Neither does the possessor of wealth earn it by intellect / Nor by wealth are intellects earned.
Just as the swamps of the earth are clothed in irrigation / And floods are turned away from its noble parts (highlands).'
Abu Tammam took this meaning and shortened it in one verse, saying, and doing well all wellness:
'Do not deny the void of the noble from wealth / For the flood is war to the high place.'
Omar bin Abi Rabi'a said:
'And when I came to her to complain to her / Some of what healed me (made me sick) and what befell me.
My mind strayed from her due to the intensity of ecstasy / And my tongue stuttered with the essence of my soul.
And I forgot what I had gathered of speech / To say to her, and my clarity was absent from me.'
Abu Hafs Al-Shatranji said following this path:
'Love was built on injustice, so if / The lover was fair in it, he would be ugly.
It is not considered good in the description of passion / A lover who is good at composing arguments.'
Abu Tammam said summarizing this meaning:
'Why do you deny when I loved my stupidity / And the skill of the yearning one is to be stupid.'
Contemplate what is between the two speeches, you will find a far difference.
Abu Tammam heard the saying of Ibn Al-Zubair at the killing of his brother Mus'ab: "Consolation and solace are for the prudent men, and panic and anxiety are for the mistresses of the curtained chambers." He organized this and did well all wellness in his copying and composition by his saying:
'We were created men for endurance and sorrow / And those beautiful women for weeping and funerals.'
He heard the saying of the sayer "Things loved are coupled with things hated", so he said, and surpassed the surpassing of the forerunner racer when the knights ask him to run in a race where horses stumble in seeking him:
'He strove and brought down hope by force / Were it not for striving, there would be no endeavor.'
Look at the saying of Aban Al-Lahiqi:
'The soul will not know bliss and its might / If it is ignorant of the state of humiliation and harm.'
Abu Tammam took this meaning and improved its molding and casting, saying:
'And accidents, even if their misery hits you / It is what informed you how their bliss is.'
Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir tried to take this meaning, but fell short of it by his saying:
'Let not a state whose height elevated you make you forget / What is in its consequences, and remember its change.
For the youth is ignorant of blessings if they are continuous / Until he is stung by trial, then he knows them.'

And of Abu Tammam's excellence in taking is his saying:
'If they raided and contained the wealth of a group / Favors raided them and contained them.'
This expression delights and pleases, and deceives and enchants. He only imitated in this verse of his the saying of Urwa bin Al-Ward in two verses:
'A noble who saw poverty as shame, so he ceased not / Roaming the lands of God until he became wealthy.
When he gained wealth, he returned with spending it / On who came to him seeking his dew, hoping.'
Contemplate Abu Tammam's abbreviation of this meaning and his good expression of it. Ibn al-Rumi undertook taking it, but could not fulfill it except in four verses, necessitating each other, which are:
'There is no one on earth more generous than Shuja' / Even if he gives the little of gifts.
That is because he gives you from what / The tips of the spears return to him.
And sufficient for you is the generosity of one who gave you wealth / He contained it by chase and combat.
He bought his blood to contain it, so when / He contained it, the praise of men fell with it.'

Al-Suli informed me, saying: I heard Abu Malik say: Whoever can take the meaning and do with it the deed of Abu Tammam, [let him do so], otherwise let him not expose himself to it. He said: So I said: Like this? He said: Like the saying of Abu Nuwas:
'Give them glad tidings before the following gift / Like the lightning appearing before a pouring rain.
And the rain, its fall is hidden to the glancer / As long as he does not find it by the indication of the lightning.'
Abu Tammam looked at this and said:
'He brings down the distant hope with his cheerfulness / The glad tidings of the cloud with the pouring spring.
And so clouds rarely call to / Their kindness the scouts as long as they do not flash.'
Then he abbreviated the meaning in one verse saying:
'Cheerfulness is only a garden, so if / It is followed by giving, then a garden and a pool.'
Al-Buhturi imitated this meaning and said, and brought it in several places where he fell short, until he said:
'Cheering, open, if he promised wealth / With cheerfulness, he followed his cheerfulness with the gift.
Like the cloud, if the flashes of its lightning laughed / They cleared with it for a continuous rain or a downpour.'

Abu al-Tayyib said: "We refrain from this. Do you find for this Abu Tammam of yours or your Buhturi a meaning they invented?"
I said: "Can their inventions be exhausted by discussion, or can research and debate cover a single part of them?"
He said: "Bring one meaning and you have the yield (victory)."
I said to him: "Of Abu Tammam's inventions on which the consensus of narrators fell is his saying:
'It refuses against restriction (Tasrid) anything but a gift / If it is not pure, unmixed, it is mixed.
Intentionally, as you forced the wandering breath / From the musk pod that was not opened.'"

He said: "This is from the saying of the Bedouin:
'When we disputed the dropped conversation / Hastily, and the affection from her softened so she gave hope.
With the event of abandonment and an hour of negligence / From the tribe, fearing eyes that might look.
She sprinkled with a speech that almost healed from passion / Our livers almost cut for it.
Just as the thirsty forced the falls of a cloud / Piled up, its cloud turned away when it quenched.'"

I said to him: "How far is the distance between the two meanings. I do not find you attracting that except because of the saying of this one 'As he forced' and the saying of Abu Tammam 'Intentionally as you forced'. Words are permissible, except a subtle metaphor or a pun or an antithesis, for these are specific to their owners. If another comes with them after a first, he is judged with theft, although it is within the metaphor that a last and a first arrive at some of that."
Al-Muhallabi said: "O Abu al-Tayyib, you wronged Abu Tammam in this claim against him a wrong in which there is no doubt." He turned to me and said: "Complete your speech."

I said: "And of his inventions is his saying:
'If God wants to publish a virtue / That was folded, He makes available for it the tongue of an envious one.
Were it not for the burning of fire in what it neighbored / The good scent of the oud would not be known.'"

Abu al-Tayyib said: "As for the first verse, the meaning is common."
Al-Muhallabi said: "Like what?"
He said: "The saying of Zuhair:
'Envied for what was of generosity / God does not strip from them what they were envied for.'
And the saying of the other:
'And blessings and envy do not separate.'
And the saying of the other:
'Envied, and the worst of people in station / Is he who did not spend a day while he is envied.'"

Al-Muhallabi said: "This is also prejudice. The two meanings do not correspond, even if they are both about envy. Do you not see that his saying:
'If God wants to publish a virtue / That was folded, He makes available for it the tongue of an envious one'
Is not from the saying of Zuhair: 'Envied, God does not strip from them what they were envied for', nor from the saying of the other: 'The worst of people is he who is not envied', nor from the saying of the other: 'And blessings and envy do not separate', even if all of that is in one meaning and one way?"
I said to him: "This is a chapter of expansion in meaning which resembles the taken but is not taken, and this is a station only the rough-footed climbs."
Abu al-Tayyib said: "He took his saying: 'Were it not for the burning of fire' from the saying of Bashar:
'Like the holder of musk, a puff indicated him.'"
Ali bin Isa the Grammarian said: "If he did that, then by God he did well, all wellness."

Al-Muhallabi said, turning to me: "Bring what is present with you of his inventions."
I said: "And of his inventions is his saying:
'The seeker went astray with you from where he is guided / And the days harmed with you from where they benefit.'
And of his marvels:
'It pleases you to meet him in the front of a council / And in the throat of enemies and in the heart of a procession.
He has a character, if it were in water it would not decrease / And in the rain, no man would see a lightning of deception.'
And his saying:
'My two friends, after sorrow and burning, stop / And do not stop the overflow of pouring tears.
If the sword of death is black, rusty / The edge of a white sharp sword has been notched from it.
It struck a man whose precious wealth was / Upon him, when asked, not precious.
And no calamity missed a great thing with him / But it is of the mothers of great things.'
And of his inventions is his saying describing spears:
'Educated (straightened), they robbed the Romans of their blueness / And the Arabs of their brownness and the lover of leanness.'
And his saying:
'The sword, as long as no polisher is found in it / From itself, does not benefit from polishing.'"

He said: "This is from the saying of Imru' al-Qais:
'He is called polished while he has no / Covenant with polishing nor polisher.'"

And his saying:
'And accidents, even if their misery hits you / It is what informed you how their bliss is.'
And his saying:

'And the sword is nothing but a piece of iron; if you left it / On the first creation, it would not cut.'
And his saying:
'The sweetest of men to women in locations / Is he who is most similar to them in cheeks.'"
He said: "This is from the saying of Al-A'sha:
'And I see beautiful women do not connect with a man / Who lost youth, and they may connect with the beardless.'"
Abu Sa'id the Grammarian said: "Abu Tammam's verse, if you were fair to him, is more poetic, even if Al-A'sha's verse is more traveling (famous)."

And of his inventions is his saying:
'My denial of whiteness (gray hair) has been long, and if I lived / A thing (time), I would deny the color of blackness.'
And his saying:
'Whoever returned returned, he did not win his need / And a seeker of success did not fail who did not fail.'
And his saying:
'They said: Do you weep over a trace? I said to them / He whom the eye missed, the trace guided his longing.'
And his saying:
'And whoever does not submit to calamities, his / Traits all become calamities upon him.'
And his saying:
'Traces upon which the tears of the cloud met / For long, and the tears of lovers.'
And of his marvels is his saying in the descriptions of camels:
'The pleasing you whatever you compelled their noses / And the guiding you while they are the fleeing straying ones.
If I complained of a land I became in / It was the might, except that they are humble.'
And his saying:
'Whenever the decree comes to you, you will not be found perishing / But a time that assassinated your like is perishing.'"

Al-Muhallabi said: "In some of this is sufficiency. Does any of Al-Buhturi's inventions occur to you?"
I said: "His saying:
'If she strutted, her sides diffused fragrance / As the acceptance (east wind) strutted on the garden.
Her coquetry is beautiful, and death is in it / And the polished sword may be deemed beautiful.'"
Abu al-Tayyib said: "The first verse is from the saying of Abu Nuwas describing wine:
'As if we are with it between the sides of a garden / If we robbed it of its scent from the night.'"
Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi said: "How far is this meaning."
He said: "Say what is closer to it and more similar."
He said: "It is more similar to the saying of Al-Shanfara Al-Azdi:
'So we spent the night as if the house was perfumed around us / With a basil that was watered in the evening and bedewed.'
And the saying of the other:
'Indeed I have at every breath of a garden / Of roses or of jasmine.
A look and a turning, I hope / That you have settled in what follows us.'
Similar to it is the saying of Salm Al-Khasir:
'As if she is a blossoming garden / The early morning breathed in it.'
Salm took it from Bashar:
'As if she is a blossoming garden / Gathering goodness and a beautiful view.
She appeared to my heart yellow (pale), scented / She poured upon us from her love a temptation.'
Habib bin Isa the Scribe did well in his saying:
'Your scent reminds me of a sick wind / That ran with the breeze of the garden in the darkness of dawn.'"

Then he said: "And so is his saying:
'And the polished sword may be deemed beautiful.'
It is from the saying of Abu al-Shis:
'And like the sword, if it is not forbidden, its blade softens / And its two edges, if you roughened it, are rough.'"
I said: "How far is this valley from that mountain path. If it be, it is a look and observation. But look at the moist, sweet words of Al-Buhturi, and at his sect in what he imitates and points to. For he did not summon from speech a repulsive one, nor sought the sympathy of one turning away, nor recited a stray one, nor felt at ease with a wild one. His words were above his meanings, and his ends were not separated from his beginnings. But Abu al-Shis took his saying from the saying of the other:
'He is the sword; if he desists, his edge softens / And between his two edges are the looming deaths.'"

Then I said: "And of Al-Buhturi's inventions also is his saying:
'When we met and Al-Naqa was an appointment for us / The viewer of pearls wondered at goodness and its picker.
From pearls she reveals at her smiling / And from pearls at conversation, its falling.'"
Abu al-Tayyib said: "This is taken from the saying of the other:
'She is pearls scattered when she speaks / And like pearls strung when she does not speak.'"
Al-Muhallabi said: "And who is there for you who does well the wellness of Al-Buhturi in this taking of his, if he took it from him? Is he in that except like one who picked the bitterness of a fruit, or took a dung and returned it a jewel?"

I said: "And of Al-Buhturi's inventions is his saying describing the phantom:
'Are you serious? A phantom does not cease traveling to Zainab / If the darkness returns, it returns.
It traveled from the highlands of Sham, slumber brings it / The blowing of the breeze of the wind, the East wind brings it.'
And of his invention is his saying:
'Accustomed to wearing armor, you think them / In the cold silk, and in the midday heats mist.'
And his saying:

'Anemones carrying dew as if it is / Tears of youthful passion on the cheeks of the virgins.'
And his saying describing [a pool]:
'As if its streams in the low ground / Play with backgammon from its bubbles.'

Abu al-Tayyib was dazzled by what I presented, and his obstruction (speechlessness) was reckoned, and his tongue was tied from answering, and he almost [spoke] were it not that the awe of the Vizier Abu Muhammad filled his heart. He was before dodging the debater the dodging of the debtor from tracking. When he reached in speech to this place, he rose angrily, and it was the last covenant with him in that house. He went out passing on his face, straying like the ostrich, and he did not stay except the time he prepared for travel. So he departed from Iraq heading to Kufa.

The young students of literature had belittled him, coveting him, until his skin was torn, and his honor was fabricated the fabrication of terrorism. A fool of the fools of the Baghdadis, a small one of their smallest scholars known as Ibn al-Hajjaj, became fond of satirizing him; he has no share in virtue nor foot in literature. It suffices him that he forced him, despite the baseness of his value and silliness of his ambition, to flee, and the goal was thrown, and the mounts were anxious in every direction. I had led him with the rein of belittlement the leading of the led horse. So he could not stay in the City of Peace, so he went out from it to Kufa, and from there to Fars, seeking Adud al-Dawla, and visiting Ibn al-Amid, and hoping to stay in their shelter, and shade himself with their shade or the shade of one of them. He did well in some of what he praised them with and did badly in some, and his material was restricted and his breath cut off before the goal. For he had exhausted his excellence in Sayf al-Dawla, and drowned his reach in his praise. So he was forced to depart and return to Iraq, but he was snatched away before that, and that was the last covenant with him.

I append to this treatise what I tracked of his flaws, and stood upon of his theft, and of the lapse of his wording and silliness of his meanings. I mention also of the beauties of his poetry, and of the eyes of his eulogies—for praise was his food and the straying of his verses—what I run in all of it with the truth which cannot be transgressed, fair and seeking justice from him, not decreasing his right, nor attributing to him what is not his. I single out a book for that and exhaust it, and reach the limit that ability reaches in it, by the power of God and His strength, favor, and compassion. The treatise is completed, and praise be to God, and the favor is to God alone, and His blessings be upon our master Muhammad the Prophet and upon his family and companions and peace be upon them completely. The completion of copying it was agreed upon by the hand of the poorest of God's servants and most in need of His pardon and forgiveness, Muhammad bin Abdul Malik bin Asakir Al-Shafi'i Al-Ba'labakki, may God forgive him, on Friday the ninth of Shawwal, the year seven hundred and seventeen, praising and praying.
